trial_title: A Phase 2 Study Combining Ipilimumab With Abiraterone Acetate Plus Prednisone in Chemotherapy and Immunotherapy-naïve Patients With Progressive Metastatic Castration-resistant Prostate Cancer
inclusion_criteria: Chemotherapy- and immunotherapy-naive metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer | Age >= 18 years | Histologically or cytologically confirmed adenocarcinoma of the prostate | Castrate serum testosterone <= 50 ng/dL | Ongoing androgen deprivation therapy with a GnRH analogue or prior bilateral orchiectomy | Metastatic disease on imaging; if lymph node-only metastasis, at least one node >= 2 cm in diameter | Progressive disease at study entry per PCWG2 by PSA and/or radiographic criteria | Karnofsky performance status >= 80% | Estimated life expectancy >= 6 months | Toxicities from prior therapy resolved to <= Grade 1 or baseline or deemed irreversible and stable | Able to swallow study drug and comply with study requirements
exclusion_criteria: History of another malignancy within the previous 5 years other than nonmelanoma skin cancer | Absolute neutrophil count < 1500/µL | Platelet count < 75000/µL | Hemoglobin < 9 g/dL | Serum bilirubin >= 1.5 x ULN or, with Gilbert's disease, >= 3 mg/dL | AST or ALT >= 2.5 x ULN (<= 5 x ULN allowed with known liver metastases) | Creatinine > 2 mg/dL | Albumin < 3.0 g/dL | Potassium <= 3.5 mEq/L | Clinically significant cardiovascular disease (myocardial infarction within 6 months, uncontrolled angina within 3 months, NYHA class 3 or 4 heart failure, uncontrolled hypertension with SBP > 160 mmHg or DBP > 95 mmHg) | Major surgery or radiation therapy within 4 weeks of enrollment | Treatment with antiandrogens (bicalutamide, flutamide, nilutamide) within 4 weeks of enrollment | History of progression of prostate cancer while receiving ketoconazole | Prior use or participation in a trial of androgen synthesis inhibitors (e.g., abiraterone, TAK-700, TAK-683, TAK-448), chemotherapy, or immunologic agents (immune modulators, cytokines, vaccines, antibody-delivered chemotherapy) | Known allergy to any study compounds | Uncontrolled or significant medical condition that would make participation hazardous in the investigator's opinion | Autoimmune disease (e.g., inflammatory bowel disease, rheumatoid arthritis, systemic sclerosis, systemic lupus erythematosus, autoimmune vasculitis, motor neuropathy of autoimmune origin) | Known or suspected brain metastasis or untreated leptomeningeal disease | Active infection or other medical condition making prednisone use contraindicated | Active or symptomatic viral hepatitis or chronic liver disease | Disease limited to regional pelvic lymph nodes only | Use of hematopoietic growth factors within 7 days or blood transfusions within 28 days prior to screening labs
prior_therapies: Chemotherapy-naive required; Immunotherapy-naive required; Ongoing androgen deprivation therapy required; Antiandrogens discontinued >= 4 weeks before enrollment; No major surgery or radiation therapy within 4 weeks before enrollment; No hematopoietic growth factors within 7 days and no blood transfusions within 28 days before screening labs
reasoning: The trial explicitly excludes patients with prior use of androgen synthesis inhibitors such as abiraterone, which this patient received for 3 years. This is a hard exclusion despite other matching factors.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 66 years; Male sex; Metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer; Progression on enzalutamide; PSMA PET avid liver and bone metastases
patient_prior_therapies: Progression on enzalutamide; Prior abiraterone (Zytiga) with leuprolide (Lupron) for 3 years
judge_comment: The trial explicitly excludes prior use of androgen synthesis inhibitors (e.g., abiraterone). The patient received abiraterone for 3 years, triggering a hard exclusion per rubric → F. The grader’s reasoning correctly identified this.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
trial_title: A Randomized Phase II Trial of Erlotinib, Cabozantinib, or Erlotinib Plus Cabozantinib as 2nd or 3rd Line Therapy in Patients With EGFR Wild-Type NSCLC
inclusion_criteria: Non-small cell lung carcinoma confirmed cytologically or histologically | Predominant non-squamous histology; small cell components excluded | Stage IV or recurrent disease by AJCC 7th edition | Measurable disease per RECIST v1.1 | Tumor tissue available for MET IHC testing | One to two prior lines of chemotherapy for advanced disease | Any prior chemotherapy completed per required washout | Discontinued investigational agents >= 4 weeks before registration | Recovered to baseline or CTCAE v4.0 <= grade 1 from prior therapy toxicities (except alopecia and non-clinically significant AEs) | Brain metastases status meeting protocol criteria (stable if present); baseline brain imaging per protocol | Radiation-related toxicities resolved to <= grade 1 | ECOG performance status 0-2 | Anticipated life expectancy > 3 months | Acceptable bone marrow, renal, and hepatic function within 2 weeks prior to registration | QTcF <= 500 ms within 28 days before registration | Able to swallow tablets | Step 2: Radiographic progressive disease after >= 2 courses on Arm A or Arm B | Step 2: Registered within 4 weeks of last dose from Step 1 | Step 2: ECOG performance status 0-2 | Step 2: Recovered to baseline (pre-Step 1) or CTCAE v4.0 <= grade 1 from prior therapy toxicities
exclusion_criteria: Insufficient tumor pathology material (tumor block or 10 unstained slides) for required testing | Prior erlotinib or other EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor therapy | Prior VEGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor therapy | Prior MET tyrosine kinase inhibitor therapy or MET monoclonal antibody | Radiation therapy to thoracic cavity, abdomen, or pelvis within 3 months; to bone or brain within 14 days; or to any other site within 28 days prior to registration | Clinically significant gastrointestinal bleeding within 6 months | Hemoptysis >= 2.5 mL within 3 months | Other signs of pulmonary hemorrhage within 3 months | Tumor invading the gastrointestinal tract or endotracheal/endobronchial tumor within 28 days prior to registration | Cavitating pulmonary lesion(s) within 28 days prior to registration | Tumor in contact with, invading, or encasing major blood vessels within 28 days prior to registration | History of major thrombotic events (deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism) within 6 months | Therapeutic anticoagulation or antiplatelet therapy (except low-dose aspirin <= 81 mg/day and prophylactic LMWH) | Concomitant strong CYP3A4 inducers | Congestive heart failure NYHA class III or IV | Uncontrolled hypertension | History of congenital long QT syndrome | Unstable angina within 6 months | Clinically significant cardiac arrhythmias within 6 months | Stroke or transient ischemic attack or other ischemic event within 6 months | Myocardial infarction within 6 months | Gastrointestinal disorders with high risk of perforation or fistula | High risk of fistula including PEG tube placement within 3 months | Uncontrolled, significant intercurrent or recent illness | Prior malignancy within 2 years requiring systemic treatment or currently active | Pregnant or breastfeeding | HIV infection on antiretroviral therapy | Chronic active hepatitis B | Step 2: Intervening anticancer treatment or major surgery between Step 1 and Step 2 (except palliative bone radiation finished >= 2 weeks before Step 2 registration) | Step 2: Central nervous system progression | Step 2: Intercurrent illness or complication limiting ability to safely tolerate erlotinib plus cabozantinib
prior_therapies: Required: 1-2 prior lines of chemotherapy for advanced NSCLC; Prior adjuvant chemotherapy allowed if > 12 months before first-line systemic therapy (otherwise counts as one line); Discontinue investigational agents >= 4 weeks before registration
reasoning: Explicit exclusion: the trial bars prior EGFR TKI therapy, and the patient received osimertinib. Additionally, the trial requires 1–2 prior lines of chemotherapy for advanced disease, which the patient lacks.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Non-small cell lung cancer; De novo metastatic disease (bone, liver); EGFR exon 19 deletion; ECOG 0; Age 40 years
judge_comment: Hard exclusion applies: the trial excludes any prior EGFR TKI therapy, and the patient received osimertinib (an EGFR TKI). The noted lack of required prior chemotherapy would also be a mismatch, but the explicit exclusion alone warrants grade F.

question_text: What are trial options for a 66 year old male with hx hypertension, afib, T2DM and mCRPC, now progressing on enzalutamide? He has been on Lupron+Zytiga for 3 years, with new liver and bone metastases which are all PSMA PET avid. He’s tolerated therapy well overall except for grade 2 fatigue.
trial_title: A Phase III Randomized Trial Comparing Androgen Deprivation Therapy + TAK-700 With Androgen Deprivation Therapy + Bicalutamide in Patients With Newly Diagnosed Metastatic Sensitive Prostate Cancer
inclusion_criteria: Clinical diagnosis of metastatic prostate cancer | Serum testosterone within normal limits | PSA >= 2 ng/mL | QTc <= 460 msec on ECG | LVEF within normal limits | Adequate hepatic function: bilirubin <= 2 x ULN; AST and ALT <= 3 x ULN (<= 5 x ULN if liver metastases present) | Creatinine clearance >= 40 mL/min | Leukocytes >= 3,000/µL, ANC >= 1,500/µL, hemoglobin >= 9 g/dL, platelets >= 100,000/µL | Zubrod performance status 0–2; 3 allowed if due to bone pain only | Age >= 18 years
exclusion_criteria: Known brain metastases | More than 36 months of prior neoadjuvant and/or adjuvant hormonal therapy | 6 months or more since completion of androgen deprivation therapy | Prior or concurrent therapy with ketoconazole | Prior or concurrent therapy with aminoglutethimide | Prior or concurrent therapy with abiraterone acetate | Prior or concurrent therapy with enzalutamide | Prior chemotherapy for metastatic prostate cancer | Less than 2 years since completion of neoadjuvant or adjuvant chemotherapy | Concurrent use of experimental therapy | 30 days or more since prior medical castration for metastatic prostate cancer | Prior bilateral orchiectomy | Concurrent use of LHRH antagonists (e.g., degarelix) | NYHA class III/IV cardiac disease, thromboembolic event, unstable angina, myocardial infarction within 6 months, or serious uncontrolled arrhythmia | Uncontrolled hypertension > 160/90 mmHg despite therapy | Known HIV infection, active chronic hepatitis B or C, life-threatening illness unrelated to cancer, or serious medical/psychiatric illness interfering with participation | History of primary or secondary adrenal insufficiency | Hypersensitivity to TAK-700, TAK-700 metabolites, bicalutamide, or LHRH agonists | Gastrointestinal disease or procedure interfering with oral absorption or tolerance of TAK-700, including difficulty swallowing | Other prior malignancy except adequately treated basal/squamous cell skin cancer, adequately treated stage I/II cancer in complete remission, or any other cancer disease-free for 5 years
prior_therapies: Prior neoadjuvant/adjuvant hormonal therapy allowed (<= 36 months total); Prior neoadjuvant/adjuvant chemotherapy allowed (>= 2 years since completion)
reasoning: The trial explicitly excludes patients with prior abiraterone or enzalutamide, both of which this patient has received. Additionally, the study targets newly diagnosed metastatic hormone-sensitive disease, not castration-resistant.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 66 years; Male sex; Metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer; Progression on enzalutamide; PSMA PET avid liver and bone metastases
patient_prior_therapies: Progression on enzalutamide; Prior abiraterone (Zytiga) with leuprolide (Lupron) for 3 years
judge_comment: Explicit hard exclusions apply: the trial excludes any prior abiraterone or enzalutamide, both of which the patient received. Thus F is correct; the noted stage/setting mismatch further supports ineligibility but is not needed once the hard exclusion is present.

question_text: 40 year old man with recurrent glioblastoma. Diagnosed 1 year ago, underwent gross total resection with confirmation of GBM, IDH wildtype. Completed adjuvant radiation + concurrent temozolomide and then adjuvant temozolomide. Three months after completing adjuvant therapy, MRI shows recurrence. ECOG 1 and no other medical issues. What are trial options?
trial_title: Pilot Study of Optune (NovoTTF-100A) for Recurrent Atypical and Anaplastic Meningioma
inclusion_criteria: Histologically proven recurrent WHO grade II (atypical) or grade III (anaplastic) supratentorial meningioma | Radiographic evidence of progression by MRI (or CT if MRI contraindicated) within 14 days of registration | Stable or decreased dose of steroids for >=5 days prior to baseline imaging | Recovered from effects of recent resection; start treatment >=28 days after surgery | Measurable disease >=1 cm x 1 cm contrast-enhancing lesion | Prior radiotherapy for meningioma required; interval >4 weeks from completion with subsequent progression documented | Confirmation of true progression (not radiation necrosis) required after prior brachytherapy or stereotactic radiosurgery (via PET/MR-perfusion/MR-spectroscopy or surgery) | Age >=18 years | Karnofsky performance status >=60% | >=4 weeks from any radiation, stereotactic radiosurgery, conventional surgery, or chemotherapy | Life expectancy >=3 months | Neurofibromatosis patients eligible; other CNS tumors allowed if stable for >=6 months
exclusion_criteria: History of other cancer unless in complete remission off therapy for >=3 years (except non-melanoma skin cancer or cervical carcinoma in situ) | Concomitant use of investigational drugs | Concurrent treatment on another therapeutic clinical trial | Pregnancy or breastfeeding | Implanted active medical device (e.g., pacemaker, defibrillator, deep brain stimulator, vagus nerve stimulator) or significant arrhythmia | Evidence of increased intracranial pressure (midline shift >5 mm, clinically significant papilledema, vomiting/nausea, or reduced consciousness) | Infratentorial meningioma without a concurrent growing supratentorial target lesion | Coagulopathy: PT or APTT >1.5 x ULN (if not on anticoagulation) | Thrombocytopenia: platelets <100 x 10^3/µL | Neutropenia: ANC <1 x 10^3/µL | Severe acute infection | Skull defect with missing bone | Ventricular shunt or catheter | Intracranial foreign body (e.g., bullet fragment)
prior_therapies: Prior radiotherapy for meningioma required; No limit on number of prior surgeries, radiotherapy treatments, radiosurgery treatments, or chemotherapy; Washout >=4 weeks from any radiation treatment, stereotactic radiosurgery, conventional surgery, or chemotherapy before study entry; Start treatment >=28 days after surgery with recovery from surgical effects
reasoning: The trial is specifically for recurrent WHO grade II/III meningioma, while the patient has recurrent glioblastoma (IDH wildtype). This disease mismatch is a hard exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 40 years; Male; Recurrent glioblastoma; IDH wildtype; Status post gross total resection; Completed radiation with concurrent temozolomide and adjuvant temozolomide; ECOG 1; No other medical issues
patient_prior_therapies: Gross total resection; Adjuvant radiation with concurrent temozolomide; Adjuvant temozolomide
judge_comment: Disease mismatch: trial is for recurrent atypical/anaplastic meningioma, while patient has recurrent glioblastoma. This is a hard exclusion per rubric; F is correct.

question_text: What are trial options for a 66 year old male with hx hypertension, afib, T2DM and mCRPC, now progressing on enzalutamide? He has been on Lupron+Zytiga for 3 years, with new liver and bone metastases which are all PSMA PET avid. He’s tolerated therapy well overall except for grade 2 fatigue.
trial_title: A Multicenter, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled, Phase III Study of ARN-509 in Men With Non-Metastatic (M0) Castration-Resistant Prostate Cancer
inclusion_criteria: Histologically or cytologically confirmed prostate adenocarcinoma without neuroendocrine or small cell features | High risk for metastasis defined as PSA doubling time <= 10 months during continuous ADT | Castration-resistant prostate cancer on continuous ADT with 3 PSA rises >= 1 week apart and last PSA > 2 ng/mL | Maintain castrate levels of testosterone within 4 weeks prior to randomization and throughout the study | Bone-sparing agents allowed if on stable doses for >= 4 weeks prior to randomization | Washout from first-generation anti-androgen (e.g., bicalutamide, flutamide, nilutamide) for >= 4 weeks with PSA progression after washout | >= 4 weeks since 5-alpha reductase inhibitors, estrogens, and any other anti-cancer therapy prior to randomization | >= 4 weeks since major surgery or radiation therapy prior to randomization | ECOG performance status 0 or 1 | Resolution of acute toxicities from prior therapy or surgery to Grade <= 1 or baseline before randomization | Adequate organ function per protocol-defined criteria | No growth factors or blood transfusions within 4 weeks before hematology labs for eligibility
exclusion_criteria: Confirmed distant metastases, including CNS, vertebral, or meningeal involvement | Symptomatic local or regional disease requiring medical intervention | Prior treatment with second-generation anti-androgens | Prior treatment with CYP17 inhibitors | Prior treatment with radiopharmaceutical agents or any other investigational agent for non-metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer | Prior chemotherapy for prostate cancer except if given in the adjuvant or neoadjuvant setting | History of seizure or condition predisposing to seizure | Concurrent therapy with protocol-defined excluded medications | Any prior malignancy within 5 years except adequately treated basal cell or squamous cell skin cancer, superficial bladder cancer, or cancer in situ in complete remission | Severe or unstable angina within 6 months prior to randomization | Myocardial infarction within 6 months prior to randomization | Symptomatic congestive heart failure within 6 months prior to randomization | Arterial or venous thromboembolic events within 6 months prior to randomization | Clinically significant ventricular arrhythmias within 6 months prior to randomization | Uncontrolled hypertension | Gastrointestinal disorder affecting absorption | Active infection | Any other condition that would impair the patient's ability to comply with study procedures
prior_therapies: Continuous ADT required; Washout from first-generation anti-androgens >= 4 weeks with PSA progression after washout; >= 4 weeks since 5-alpha reductase inhibitors or estrogens; >= 4 weeks since any other anti-cancer therapy; >= 4 weeks since major surgery; >= 4 weeks since radiation therapy; Bone-sparing agents allowed if stable for >= 4 weeks
reasoning: The trial is for non-metastatic (M0) CRPC and explicitly excludes patients with distant metastases, while the patient has metastatic CRPC with liver and bone involvement. It also excludes prior treatment with second-generation anti-androgens and CYP17 inhibitors, which the patient received (enzalutamide and abiraterone).
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 66 years; Male sex; Metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer; Progression on enzalutamide; PSMA PET avid liver and bone metastases
patient_prior_therapies: Progression on enzalutamide; Prior abiraterone (Zytiga) with leuprolide (Lupron) for 3 years
judge_comment: Explicit exclusion criteria disqualify the patient: the trial excludes distant metastases and prior second-generation anti-androgens/CYP17 inhibitors; the patient has metastatic disease and received enzalutamide and abiraterone. F is correct per hard exclusions.

question_text: A 55-year-old female has severe, seropositive rheumatoid arthritis refractory to methotrexate and two prior biologic agents (adalimumab and tocilizumab). She has active disease with a DAS28 score of 5.5. Critically, she has a history of treated Hepatitis B (HBsAg negative, anti-HBc positive) and moderate chronic kidney disease with an eGFR of 45 mL/min/1.73m². What are trial options for her?
trial_title: A Phase II Study of Reduced Intensity Conditioning in Pediatric Patients and Young Adults ≤55 Years of Age With Non-Malignant Disorders Undergoing Umbilical Cord Blood, Bone Marrow, or Peripheral Blood Stem Cell Transplantation
diseases_targeted: Primary Immunodeficiency; Congenital Bone Marrow Failure Syndrome; Inherited Metabolic Disorder; Hereditary Anemia; Crohn's Disease; Inflammatory Bowel Disease; Juvenile Rheumatoid Arthritis; Systemic Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis
inclusion_criteria: Availability of a suitable graft: 4/6–6/6 HLA matched related or unrelated UCB unit with total nucleated cells >= 3 x 10^7/kg (or double units each >= 2 x 10^7/kg) or 8/8 or 7/8 HLA allele-matched unrelated donor bone marrow or peripheral blood progenitor graft | Serum creatinine <= 2.0 mg/dL | Creatinine clearance >= 50 mL/min | ALT <= 4 x ULN | AST <= 4 x ULN | Cardiac function adequate: shortening fraction > 26% or ejection fraction > 40% or > 80% of normal for age | Pulmonary function: FEV1/FVC >= 50% predicted for age | Pulmonary function: DLCO (hemoglobin-corrected) >= 50% predicted (adults, if obtainable) | Resting pulse oximetry >= 92% on room air | HIV negative | Negative pregnancy test if pubertal and/or menstruating | Non-malignant disorder amenable to HSCT, including primary immunodeficiency syndromes (e.g., SCID with NK activity, Omenn, BLS, CID, CVID, Wiskott-Aldrich, leukocyte adhesion deficiency, CGD, X-linked hyper IgM, IPEX, Chediak-Higashi, ALPS, HLH, lymphocyte signaling defects) | Congenital bone marrow failure syndromes (e.g., dyskeratosis congenita, congenital amegakaryocytic thrombocytopenia, osteopetrosis) | Inherited metabolic disorders (e.g., mucopolysaccharidoses [Hurler, Hunter], leukodystrophies [Krabbe, metachromatic leukodystrophy, X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy, HDLS], alpha mannosidosis, Gaucher disease) | Hereditary anemias (e.g., thalassemia major, sickle cell disease with qualifying complications, Diamond-Blackfan anemia, other congenital transfusion-dependent anemias) | Inflammatory conditions (e.g., Crohn's disease/Inflammatory Bowel Disease)
exclusion_criteria: Allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant within the previous 6 months | Active malignancy or myelodysplastic syndrome | Severe acquired aplastic anemia | Uncontrolled bacterial, viral, or fungal infection with progression of clinical symptoms despite therapy | Pregnancy or nursing | Poorly controlled pulmonary hypertension | Any condition that precludes serial follow-up
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets non-malignant disorders including juvenile rheumatoid arthritis/systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis, not adult rheumatoid arthritis. While the patient is within the age and sex parameters, their disease is not an eligible cohort.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 55 years; Female; Seropositive rheumatoid arthritis; Active disease (DAS28 5.5)
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to methotrexate; Prior adalimumab; Prior tocilizumab; Failed two prior biologic agents
judge_comment: Disease mismatch is a hard exclusion: the trial lists juvenile rheumatoid arthritis/systemic JIA and other non-malignant disorders, not adult rheumatoid arthritis. Age and sex fit, but per rubric disease mismatch → F. The grader’s reasoning aligns with this.

question_text: What are trial options for a 66 year old male with hx hypertension, afib, T2DM and mCRPC, now progressing on enzalutamide? He has been on Lupron+Zytiga for 3 years, with new liver and bone metastases which are all PSMA PET avid. He’s tolerated therapy well overall except for grade 2 fatigue.
trial_title: PROSPER: A MULTINATIONAL, PHASE 3, RANDOMIZED, DOUBLE-BLIND, PLACEBO-CONTROLLED, EFFICACY AND SAFETY STUDY OF ENZALUTAMIDE IN PATIENTS WITH NONMETASTATIC CASTRATION-RESISTANT PROSTATE CANCER
inclusion_criteria: Histologically or cytologically confirmed prostate adenocarcinoma without neuroendocrine, signet cell, or small cell features | Ongoing androgen deprivation therapy with GnRH agonist/antagonist or prior bilateral orchiectomy | Testosterone <= 50 ng/dL at screening | Progressive disease on androgen deprivation therapy at enrollment | PSA >= 2 ng/mL (central) | PSA doubling time <= 10 months | No prior or present evidence of metastatic disease | Asymptomatic prostate cancer | ECOG performance status 0–1 | Estimated life expectancy >= 12 months
exclusion_criteria: Prior cytotoxic chemotherapy | Hormonal therapy or biologic therapy for prostate cancer (other than approved bone-targeting agents and GnRH therapy) within 4 weeks of randomization | Investigational agent within 4 weeks of randomization | Known or suspected brain metastasis or active leptomeningeal disease | History of another invasive cancer within 3 years of randomization | Absolute neutrophil count < 1000/µL | Platelet count < 100,000/µL | Hemoglobin < 10 g/dL | Total bilirubin >= 1.5 x ULN | Creatinine > 2 mg/dL | Albumin < 3.0 g/dL | History of seizure or condition predisposing to seizure | Clinically significant cardiovascular disease | Gastrointestinal disorder affecting absorption | Major surgery within 4 weeks of randomization | Hypersensitivity to enzalutamide or capsule components (including Labrasol, butylated hydroxyanisole, butylated hydroxytoluene) | Any concurrent disease, infection, or comorbidity that interferes with participation or data interpretation
prior_therapies: Ongoing androgen deprivation therapy with GnRH agonist/antagonist or prior bilateral orchiectomy required; Washout >= 4 weeks since hormonal/biologic therapy for prostate cancer or any investigational agent
reasoning: This trial enrolls nonmetastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer and requires no evidence of metastases, whereas the patient has metastatic CRPC with liver and bone metastases. This disease/stage mismatch is a hard exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 66 years; Male sex; Metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer; Progression on enzalutamide; PSMA PET avid liver and bone metastases
patient_prior_therapies: Progression on enzalutamide; Prior abiraterone (Zytiga) with leuprolide (Lupron) for 3 years
judge_comment: The trial is for nonmetastatic CRPC and explicitly requires no evidence of metastases, while the patient has metastatic CRPC with liver and bone mets. This is a hard disease/stage exclusion, so F is correct.

question_text: What are trial options for a 66 year old male with hx hypertension, afib, T2DM and mCRPC, now progressing on enzalutamide? He has been on Lupron+Zytiga for 3 years, with new liver and bone metastases which are all PSMA PET avid. He’s tolerated therapy well overall except for grade 2 fatigue.
trial_title: A Phase 2 Study Combining Ipilimumab, Degarelix, and Radical Prostatectomy in Men With Newly Diagnosed Metastatic Castration Sensitive Prostate Cancer or Ipilimumab and Degarelix in Men With Biochemically Recurrent Castration Sensitive Prostate Cancer After Radical Prostatectomy
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Histologically confirmed adenocarcinoma of the prostate | Newly diagnosed metastatic prostate cancer (Cohort A) | Castration-sensitive disease | <= 10 bony metastatic lesions allowed (biopsy-proven lesions without clear bone imaging permitted) | Distant metastatic lymph nodes allowed; regional pelvic lymph nodes count as metastasis if > 1.5 cm short axis | Medically fit for radical prostatectomy (Cohort A) | Karnofsky performance status 80-100 | WBC >= 2000/µL | ANC >= 1000/µL | Platelets >= 75000/µL | Creatinine <= 2.0 x ULN | AST <= 2.5 x ULN | ALT <= 2.5 x ULN | Bilirubin <= 1.5 x ULN (Gilbert's syndrome allowed if total bilirubin < 3.0 mg/dL) | Negative HIV, Hepatitis B, and Hepatitis C screening tests | No more than 5 months of prior androgen deprivation therapy; no prior primary local therapy (radiation or surgery) to the prostate (Cohort A) | Biochemical recurrence after radical prostatectomy with progressive disease defined by rising PSA (>= 50% increase to >= 1 ng/mL based on >= 3 determinations >= 1 week apart) or PSA doubling time <= 12 months (Cohort B) | Prior prostate radiotherapy allowed (Cohort B)
exclusion_criteria: Other malignancy within 5 years (except adequately treated basal/squamous cell skin cancer or superficial bladder cancer) | Major surgery within 4 weeks of enrollment | Prior radiation therapy to the prostate (Cohort A); prior palliative radiation to metastatic sites allowed | > 5 months of prior hormonal therapy for prostate cancer | Use of megestrol acetate or anti-androgen within 2 weeks of enrollment | Use of 5-alpha reductase inhibitor within 2 weeks of enrollment | Prior ketoconazole, abiraterone, or enzalutamide for prostate cancer | Current or prior investigational therapies for prostate cancer | Prior chemotherapy administered with intent to treat prostate cancer | Concomitant therapy with any other experimental drug | Autoimmune disease (e.g., inflammatory bowel disease, rheumatoid arthritis, scleroderma, systemic lupus erythematosus, autoimmune vasculitis) | Motor neuropathy of autoimmune origin (e.g., Guillain-Barre syndrome, myasthenia gravis) | Medical or psychiatric condition that would make ipilimumab hazardous or obscure adverse event interpretation (e.g., frequent diarrhea) | Underlying heart conditions rendering patient ineligible for surgery (Cohort A) | Non-oncology vaccine therapy within 1 month before or after any dose of ipilimumab (inactivated vaccines allowed) | Prior treatment with ipilimumab, CTLA-4 inhibitor/agonist, or CD137 agonist | Concomitant or prior IL-2, interferon, or other non-study immunotherapy regimens | Immunosuppressive agents or chronic systemic corticosteroids within 6 weeks of study entry | Visceral metastatic disease (Cohort B) | > 3 cycles of intermittent androgen deprivation therapy (Cohort B) | History of acute diverticulitis, intra-abdominal abscess, gastrointestinal obstruction, or abdominal carcinomatosis
prior_therapies: <= 5 months of prior androgen deprivation therapy allowed (Cohort A); No prior primary local therapy to the prostate (radiation or surgery) required (Cohort A); Prior prostate radiotherapy allowed (Cohort B); <= 3 cycles of intermittent androgen deprivation therapy allowed (Cohort B); No washout required for GnRH analogs; 2-week washout required for megestrol acetate or anti-androgens; 2-week washout required for 5-alpha reductase inhibitors
reasoning: Disease/setting mismatch: the trial enrolls castration-sensitive or biochemically recurrent disease, while the patient has metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer. The trial also explicitly excludes prior abiraterone or enzalutamide, both of which the patient received.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 66 years; Male sex; Metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer; Progression on enzalutamide; PSMA PET avid liver and bone metastases
patient_prior_therapies: Progression on enzalutamide; Prior abiraterone (Zytiga) with leuprolide (Lupron) for 3 years
judge_comment: Correct: the trial requires castration-sensitive disease and explicitly excludes prior abiraterone or enzalutamide; the patient is castration-resistant and has received both drugs. These are hard exclusions → F.

question_text: 36 female with stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma, who initially received optimal debulking and adjuvant carboplatin+paclitaxel +bevacizumab. After 5 months, she had a new pleural effusion that was cytology positive for ovarian carcinoma. She was found to be BRCA1 positive. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Randomized Phase II/III Study to Assess the Efficacy of Trametinib (GSK 1120212) in Patients With Recurrent or Progressive Low-Grade Serous Ovarian Cancer or Peritoneal Cancer
diseases_targeted: Ovarian Low-Grade Serous Carcinoma (recurrent); Primary Peritoneal Low-Grade Serous Carcinoma (recurrent)
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Recurrent low-grade serous ovarian or peritoneal carcinoma (including invasive micropapillary serous carcinoma or invasive grade I serous carcinomas) after initial diagnosis of low-grade serous disease | Recurrent low-grade serous carcinoma after initial diagnosis of serous borderline ovarian or peritoneal carcinoma | Prospective pathology confirmation of low-grade serous carcinoma prior to study entry | Measurable disease per RECIST 1.1 with required lesion size; imaging within 28 days prior to registration | At least 4 weeks since any major surgery | Progression/recurrence after at least one platinum-based chemotherapy regimen | Unlimited number of prior therapy regimens allowed | Hormonal therapy for malignancy discontinued >= 1 week prior to registration | Chemotherapy and radiation therapy discontinued >= 4 weeks prior to registration | Investigational agents discontinued >= 28 days prior to registration | Women of childbearing potential and men agree to use highly effective contraception during treatment and for 6 months after last dose; negative serum pregnancy test within 14 days prior to randomization; not breastfeeding | Ability to understand and sign informed consent | GOG performance status 0 or 1 | Able to swallow and retain oral medication; no clinically significant GI abnormalities that may alter absorption | All prior treatment-related toxicities <= grade 1 (except alopecia) at randomization | Left ventricular ejection fraction >= lower limit of normal by ECHO or MUGA | Serum creatinine <= 1.5 mg/dL or creatinine clearance >= 50 mL/min | Total bilirubin <= 1.5 x ULN | ALT <= 2.5 x ULN | AST <= 2.5 x ULN | Albumin >= 2.5 g/dL | PT and APTT <= 1.5 x ULN | Absolute neutrophil count >= 1500/µL | Platelet count >= 100000/µL | Hemoglobin >= 9.0 g/dL | If letrozole selected: patient must be postmenopausal (bilateral oophorectomy or >= 5 years after spontaneous menopause, or postmenopausal LH/FSH if within 5 years or hysterectomy without oophorectomy); discontinue HRT before letrozole
exclusion_criteria: Chemotherapy or radiotherapy within 4 weeks prior to entry (6 weeks for nitrosoureas or mitomycin C) or unresolved toxicities from prior therapy > grade 1 | Use of other investigational drugs within 28 days (or five half-lives, whichever shorter; minimum 14 days) before first dose | Index lesion previously irradiated must have progressed post-radiation to be measurable | Prior therapy with MEK, KRAS, or BRAF inhibitors | Concurrent use of other anticancer agents or investigational agents | Concurrent use of herbal supplements (e.g., St. John's wort, kava, ephedra, ginkgo biloba, DHEA, yohimbe, saw palmetto, ginseng) | Known leptomeningeal or brain metastases or spinal cord compression | Bowel obstruction or GI conditions affecting absorption (malabsorption, inability to swallow, major gastric or bowel resection) | History of interstitial lung disease or pneumonitis | Previous or current malignancy at other sites, except curatively treated in-situ cervix or non-melanoma skin cancer, or cancers without relapse for 5 years | Active HBV or HCV infection (chronic or cleared HBV/HCV allowed); prior_therapies: Progression after at least one platinum-based chemotherapy regimen required; Unlimited prior therapy regimens allowed; Hormonal therapy for malignancy discontinued >= 1 week before registration; Chemotherapy and radiation therapy discontinued >= 4 weeks before registration; Investigational agents discontinued >= 28 days before registration; At least 4 weeks since major surgery before registration

patient_prior_therapies: Optimal debulking surgery; Adjuvant carboplatin plus paclitaxel plus bevacizumab

patient_prior_therapies: Optimal debulking surgery; Adjuvant carboplatin plus paclitaxel plus bevacizumab

question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.
trial_title: Repetitive Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation for Dementia
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 55 years | Diagnosed with mild cognitive impairment or dementia likely due to Alzheimer's disease | Ability to obtain motor threshold during screening | If on prescription cognition medication, dose stable for >= 4 weeks prior to randomization
exclusion_criteria: Prior exposure to repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation or electroconvulsive therapy | Unable to safely withdraw from medications that substantially increase seizure risk >= 2 weeks before treatment | Cardiac pacemaker or cochlear implant | Implanted deep brain stimulation device or metal in the brain | Current substance abuse (excluding caffeine or nicotine) | Active current suicidal intent or plan | Current or prior seizure disorder | Traumatic brain injury within the last 2 months | Participation in another concurrent interventional clinical trial | Known current psychosis | Current or prior mass lesion, cerebral infarct, or other active CNS disease increasing seizure risk | Not fluent in English or severe hearing impairment impairing comprehension
prior_therapies: Cognition medications allowed if dose stable for >= 4 weeks prior to randomization; Washout of medications that increase seizure risk for >= 2 weeks before treatment
reasoning: The trial requires mild cognitive impairment or dementia likely due to Alzheimer’s disease, whereas the patient has unspecified dementia with amyloid PET and CSF amyloid negative findings, which is inconsistent with AD. Age and sex fit, but the required disease subtype is not met.
patient_biomarkers: Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 68 years; Male; Two-year history of progressive cognitive decline; MMSE score 19; Moderate-stage dementia; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
judge_comment: Hard exclusion applies: the trial requires MCI or dementia likely due to Alzheimer’s disease, while the patient has unspecified dementia with amyloid PET and CSF amyloid negative results, indicating they definitively lack the required AD subtype. Age and sex fit, but disease/subtype requirement is not met. F is appropriate.

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: Phase II Single Arm Study of Gemcitabine and Cisplatin Plus Pembrolizumab as Neoadjuvant Therapy Prior to Radical Cystectomy in Patients With Muscle-Invasive Bladder Cancer
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | ECOG performance status 0–1 | Histologically confirmed urothelial carcinoma of the bladder (mixed histology allowed if component of urothelial carcinoma; excludes pure small cell, pure adenocarcinoma, pure squamous) | Clinical stage T2–T4a N0/X M0 urothelial carcinoma | Medically appropriate candidate for radical cystectomy and planning to receive cystectomy | No prior systemic cytotoxic chemotherapy for urothelial carcinoma (prior intravesical chemotherapy permitted) | Adequate organ function per protocol laboratory criteria | Life expectancy > 3 months
exclusion_criteria: Participation in another investigational study or use of an investigational device within 4 weeks prior to first dose | Immunodeficiency or systemic steroid/immunosuppressive therapy within 7 days prior to first dose (except allowed prophylactic antiemetic steroids, inhaled/topical steroids) | Active tuberculosis | Hypersensitivity to pembrolizumab or its excipients | Prior monoclonal antibody therapy within 4 weeks prior to Day 1 or not recovered to <= Grade 1 from prior adverse events | Prior chemotherapy, targeted small molecule therapy, or radiation therapy within 2 weeks prior to Day 1 or not recovered to <= Grade 1 from prior adverse events | Additional malignancy that is progressing or requires active treatment (except certain skin cancers or in situ cervical cancer after curative therapy) | Active autoimmune disease requiring systemic treatment within the past 2 years | Interstitial lung disease or active, non-infectious pneumonitis | Active infection requiring systemic therapy | Pregnant or breastfeeding, or planning conception/fathering during study and for 120 days after last dose | Prior therapy with anti-PD-1, anti-PD-L1, anti-PD-L2, anti-CD137, or anti-CTLA-4 antibodies | Prior radiation therapy to the bladder for urothelial carcinoma | Known HIV infection | Active hepatitis B or hepatitis C infection | Clinically relevant hearing impairment > Grade 2 | Live vaccine within 30 days prior to first dose
prior_therapies: No prior systemic cytotoxic chemotherapy for urothelial carcinoma; No prior checkpoint inhibitor therapy (anti-PD-1/PD-L1/PD-L2, anti-CD137, anti-CTLA-4); Washout >= 4 weeks from prior monoclonal antibody therapy; Washout >= 2 weeks from prior chemotherapy, targeted therapy, or radiation therapy; No prior radiation therapy to the bladder for urothelial carcinoma; No investigational agents/devices within 4 weeks prior to first dose
reasoning: The trial requires non-metastatic (T2–T4a N0/X M0) muscle-invasive bladder cancer eligible for neoadjuvant therapy prior to cystectomy, while the patient has metastatic disease after second-line therapy. This is a definitive stage/setting mismatch to a required criterion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: (none)
judge_comment: The trial requires non-metastatic (T2–T4a N0/X M0) neoadjuvant setting prior to cystectomy. The patient has metastatic disease (M1). This is a required stage/setting mismatch, which is a hard exclusion per the rubric, so F is correct.

He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. trial_title: Pembrolizumab Prior to Surgery for Stage 1B, 2 or 3A Non-small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC): A Phase II Study
inclusion_criteria: Histologically or cytologically confirmed non-small cell lung cancer | Clinical stage IB (>= 3 cm), stage IIA/IIB, or stage IIIA (N0-2) amenable to surgical resection | Primary tumor >= 3 cm | Deemed a surgical candidate | ECOG performance status 0–1 | No active invasive malignancy in the past 2 years other than non-melanoma skin cancer; in-situ cancers allowed | Age >= 18 years | Negative pregnancy test for females of childbearing potential within 48 hours prior to initial study procedures | Measurable disease per RECIST 1.1 | Post-operative predicted FEV1 > 40% predicted | Post-operative predicted DLCO > 40% predicted | Adequate organ function
exclusion_criteria: Treatment within the last 30 days with an investigational drug or use of an investigational device within 4 weeks of first dose | Known history of active tuberculosis | Hypersensitivity to pembrolizumab or any of its excipients | Concurrent administration of any other anti-tumor therapy | Prior therapy with an anti-PD-1, anti-PD-L1, or anti-PD-L2 agent | Known active hepatitis B or active hepatitis C infection | Active infection requiring antibiotics, antifungal, or antiviral therapy | History of or evidence of active, non-infectious pneumonitis | Known history of HIV infection | Active autoimmune disease requiring systemic treatment in the past 2 years | Autoimmune motor neuropathy (e.g., Guillain-Barre syndrome, myasthenia gravis) | Systemic steroid therapy or other immunosuppressive therapy within 7 days prior to first dose | Known additional invasive malignancy that is progressing or requires active treatment (exceptions for certain skin cancers and in situ cervical cancer) | Pregnant or breastfeeding, or planning to conceive/father children during treatment and for 120 days after last dose | Major surgery (other than definitive lung cancer surgery) within 2 weeks prior to study | Receipt of non-oncology vaccine within 30 days before or after any dose of pembrolizumab (inactivated injectable influenza vaccines allowed; live attenuated intranasal vaccines not allowed) | History of myocardial infarction within 6 months, uncontrolled arrhythmia, symptomatic angina, active ischemia, or uncontrolled heart failure | History of interstitial lung disease | Inability to comply with study procedures | Prisoners or subjects involuntarily detained
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: The trial requires resectable stage IB–IIIA NSCLC for neoadjuvant therapy, whereas the patient has de novo metastatic (stage IV) disease. This is a required stage/setting mismatch.

inclusion_criteria: Acquired severe or very severe aplastic anemia: bone marrow cellularity <25% or hypocellular for age with reductions in any two lineages (myeloid, erythroid, megakaryocyte) | Dyskeratosis congenita/telomere disorder: bone marrow cellularity <25% with cytopenias and lymphocyte telomere length <1%ile for age (CLIA-certified) | Shwachman-Diamond syndrome: SBDS mutation and/or classic clinical features with trilineage bone marrow failure (cellularity <25%) | Severe congenital neutropenia: baseline ANC <500/µL prior to G-CSF therapy | Severe congenital neutropenia: requires inclusion_criteria: Low risk stratum: no age limit | Standard risk 1: age < 11 years at enrollment | Standard risk 2: age >= 11 and < 25 years at enrollment | Low risk arms: newly diagnosed stage I germ cell tumor | Standard risk arms: newly diagnosed malignant germ cell tumor (stage II or higher) | Histologic confirmation of primary extracranial germ cell tumor required unless markedly elevated tumor markers (AFP >= 500 ng/mL or HCG >= 500 IU/L) with imaging consistent with GCT and biopsy not feasible/urgent therapy needed | Low risk ovarian immature teratoma: ovarian site; any stage/grade; pure or mixed immature/mature teratoma; may contain microscopic foci of yolk sac tumor (< 3 mm); AFP <= 1,000 ng/mL; beta-HCG normal; all ages | Low risk stage I non-seminoma MGCT: ovarian, testicular, or extragonadal; all ages | Standard risk 1: ovarian, testicular, or extragonadal; COG stage II–IV or FIGO IC–IV; must contain yolk sac tumor, embryonal carcinoma, or choriocarcinoma; age < 11 years | Standard risk 2 ovarian: COG stage II, III, III-X or FIGO IC–III; must contain yolk sac tumor, embryonal carcinoma, or choriocarcinoma; age >= 11 and < 25 years | Standard risk 2 testicular: COG stage II–IV, AJCC II–III, IGCCC good risk; must contain yolk sac tumor, embryonal carcinoma, or choriocarcinoma; post-op AFP < 1,000 ng/mL, beta-HCG < 5,000 IU/mL, LDH < 3 x ULN; age >= 11 and < 25 years | ECOG performance status 0–3 (Karnofsky for > 16 years; Lansky for <= 16 years) | Organ function requirements apply only to chemotherapy recipients (SR1 and SR2) | Adequate renal function: creatinine clearance or GFR >= 70 mL/min/1.73 m^2 within 7 days prior to enrollment or age/sex-specific serum creatinine threshold | Total bilirubin <= 2 x ULN (unless due to Gilbert's disease, malignant liver involvement, or vanishing bile duct syndrome) | AST and ALT < 3 x ULN (unless due to Gilbert's disease, malignant liver involvement, or vanishing bile duct syndrome) | Absolute neutrophil count >= 750/µL and platelets >= 75,000/µL within 7 days prior to enrollment | Standard risk arms: medically fit for protocol treatment with no contraindications to chemotherapy | AYA-HEARS substudy: age >= 11 and < 25 years; fluent in English; prior cisplatin- or carboplatin-based chemotherapy for any malignancy; followed for care at specified participating institutions
exclusion_criteria: Stage I testicular cancer with prior primary retroperitoneal lymph node dissection | Pure ovarian or extragonadal dysgerminoma/seminoma | Pure mature teratoma | Pure immature teratoma with AFP >= 1000 ng/mL | Poor-risk germ cell tumor (age >= 11 years with COG stage IV ovarian, COG stage II–IV extragonadal, or IGCCC intermediate/poor-risk testicular) | Primary central nervous system germ cell tumor | Germ cell tumor with somatic malignant transformation | Spermatocytic seminoma | Prior systemic therapy for the current cancer diagnosis | Prior radiation therapy (except CNS irradiation for brain metastases in SR1 patients) | Significant pre-existing respiratory disease contraindicating bleomycin (ineligible for standard risk chemotherapy arms) | Pregnancy (for patients receiving chemotherapy) | Lactation with intent to breastfeed (for patients receiving chemotherapy) | Sexually active patients of reproductive potential not agreeing to effective contraception during study participation (for patients receiving chemotherapy)

Additionally, the trial generally targets pediatric/AYA populations and often requires newly diagnosed disease without prior systemic therapy.

This triggers an immediate F per rubric. The grader’s added notes on age/prior therapy are ancillary but do not affect the hard exclusion decision.

criteria | Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma responding to therapy prior to enrollment | Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma with relapse after prior autologous transplant or ineligible for autologous transplant | Multiple Myeloma relapsed after autologous stem cell transplantation with at least partial response after additional chemotherapy | Multiple Myeloma with high-risk cytogenetics at diagnosis (complex karyotype, del17p, t(4;14), t(14;16) by FISH and/or del13 by karyotype) and at least partial response after autologous transplant | Karnofsky performance status >= 70% | Cardiac function: asymptomatic or, if patient_biomarkers: Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau

prior_therapies: Stable methotrexate for >=12 weeks with stable dose <=20 mg/m2 for >=8 weeks; Folic acid or folinic acid supplementation with methotrexate; Stable oral glucocorticoids (<=10 mg/day or 0.2 mg/kg/day) for >=1 week
reasoning: Hard exclusions: The trial is for pediatric polyarticular-course JIA (ages 2–17), while the patient has rheumatoid arthritis and is 55 years old. This is both a disease mismatch and an age window conflict.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 55 years; Female; Seropositive rheumatoid arthritis; Active disease (DAS28 5.5)
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to methotrexate; Prior adalimumab; Prior tocilizumab; Failed two prior biologic agents
judge_comment: Correct: The patient has adult rheumatoid arthritis and is 55 years old, while the trial targets pediatric polyarticular-course JIA with an age range of 2–17. Both disease mismatch and age window conflict are hard exclusions, warranting an F.

question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.
trial_title: The Brain Health Champion Study: Promoting Non-pharmacological Interventions in Cognitive Disorders and Those at Risk
diseases_targeted: Mild Cognitive Impairment; Mild Dementia; Subjective Cognitive Decline
inclusion_criteria: Age 60–79 years | Neurology participants: Diagnosis of Subjective Cognitive Disorder; Mild Cognitive Impairment due to Alzheimer disease, cerebrovascular disease, or mixed AD/CVD; or mild dementia due to AD, CVD, or mixed AD/CVD. | Primary care participants: CAIDE dementia risk score >= 6, or CAIDE = 5 plus a first-degree relative with ADRD, or type 2 diabetes or prediabetes (A1C >= 5.7).
exclusion_criteria: Enrolled in another health behavior or non-pharmacologic intervention for a neurocognitive disorder. | Unable or unwilling to carry out regular physical exercise multiple times weekly. | Not recommended to participate by their Internist/Primary Care Provider due to health-related concerns.
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: The trial enrolls only SCD, MCI, or mild dementia, while the patient has moderate-stage dementia (MMSE 19), which does not meet the required stage. Although age and sex fit, this stage mismatch is a hard exclusion.
patient_biomarkers: Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 68 years; Male; Two-year history of progressive cognitive decline; MMSE score 19; Moderate-stage dementia; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
judge_comment: Trial explicitly requires SCD, MCI, or mild dementia; patient has moderate-stage dementia. That is a required stage/setting the patient definitively lacks, which is a hard exclusion per rubric. Age and sex match do not overcome this. Grade F is correct.

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 8-year-old female with PMM2-CDG (Congenital Disorder of Glycosylation). She has confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2 and exhibits moderate cerebellar dysfunction with a recent ICARS score of 35. Her family is highly motivated for research participation.
trial_title: Piloting an Early Intervention Program for Infants With Rare Neurogenetic Disorders
diseases_targeted: Angelman Syndrome; Chromosome 22q11.2 Deletion Syndrome; Down Syndrome; Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy; Dup15Q Syndrome; Fragile X Syndrome; Klinefelter Syndrome; Phelan-McDermid Syndrome; Prader-Willi Syndrome; Rett Syndrome; Smith Magenis Syndrome; Tuberous Sclerosis; Turner Syndrome; Williams Syndrome
inclusion_criteria: Age <= 15 months at enrollment | Genetic diagnosis established not solely due to parental concerns (e.g., via prenatal/newborn screening or cascade testing)
exclusion_criteria: Blindness | Severe hearing impairment
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets specific neurogenetic syndromes (e.g., Angelman, Rett) and does not include PMM2-CDG. Additionally, the trial requires infants ≤15 months, while the patient is 8 years old.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of PMM2-CDG; Confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2; ICARS score 35 (moderate cerebellar dysfunction); Age 8 years
judge_comment: Disease mismatch is a hard exclusion because PMM2-CDG is not among the trial’s listed diseases; thus F is correct. The grader also noted the infant age requirement (≤15 months) versus patient age (8 years), which further supports ineligibility, though the disease mismatch alone suffices.

question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.
trial_title: A Placebo-Controlled, Double-Blind, Parallel-Group, 18-Month Study With an Open-Label Extension Phase to Confirm Safety and Efficacy of BAN2401 in Subjects With Early Alzheimer's Disease
inclusion_criteria: MCI due to Alzheimer's disease meeting NIA-AA core clinical criteria (intermediate likelihood) | Global CDR = 0.5 and CDR Memory Box >= 0.5 at Screening and Baseline (for MCI cohort) | Probable Alzheimer's disease dementia (mild) meeting NIA-AA core clinical criteria | Global CDR 0.5–1.0 and CDR Memory Box >= 0.5 at Screening and Baseline (for mild AD dementia cohort) | Objective episodic memory impairment: WMS-IV Logical Memory II at least 1 SD below age-adjusted mean | Positive biomarker for brain amyloid pathology | Age >= 50 and <= 90 years | MMSE score >= 22 and <= 30 at Screening and Baseline | BMI > 17 and < 35 at Screening | If on acetylcholinesterase inhibitor or memantine, must be on a stable dose for >= 12 weeks prior to Baseline
exclusion_criteria: Any neurological condition contributing to cognitive impairment beyond Alzheimer's disease | History of transient ischemic attack, stroke, or seizures within 12 months of Screening | Psychiatric diagnosis or symptoms that could interfere with study procedures (e.g., hallucinations, major depression, delusions) | Geriatric Depression Scale score >= 8 at Screening | Contraindications to MRI scanning (e.g., pacemaker/defibrillator, ferromagnetic implants not approved for MRI) | Clinically significant brain MRI lesions suggesting non-AD dementia | More than 4 microhemorrhages (<= 10 mm), a single macrohemorrhage > 10 mm, superficial siderosis, vasogenic edema on MRI | Evidence on MRI of cerebral contusion, encephalomalacia, aneurysm, vascular malformation, infective lesion, multiple lacunar infarcts, major territorial stroke, severe small vessel disease, severe white matter disease, space-occupying lesion, or brain tumor (except meningioma or arachnoid cyst < 1 cm) | Immunological disease not adequately controlled or requiring treatment with immunoglobulins, systemic monoclonal antibodies (or derivatives), systemic immunosuppressants, or plasmapheresis during the study | Bleeding disorder not adequately controlled, including platelet count < 50,000/µL or INR > 1.5 if not on anticoagulant treatment | Other significant uncontrolled medical conditions (cardiac, respiratory, gastrointestinal, renal) that could affect safety or assessments | Participation in a clinical study with any therapeutic monoclonal antibody, antibody-derived protein, immunoglobulin therapy, or vaccine within 6 months before Screening unless randomized to placebo | Participation in a clinical study with any anti-amyloid therapy (including monoclonal antibodies or BACE inhibitors) unless only placebo was received | Any known prior exposure to lecanemab | Participation in a clinical study with any new chemical entity for Alzheimer's disease within 6 months prior to Screening unless in a placebo arm | Hypersensitivity to lecanemab (BAN2401) or any monoclonal antibody treatment | Malignant neoplasms not stably and adequately controlled (except basal/squamous cell carcinoma in situ of skin or localized prostate cancer) | Severe visual or hearing impairment preventing accurate psychometric testing
prior_therapies: Stable dose of acetylcholinesterase inhibitor and/or memantine for >= 12 weeks prior to Baseline (treatment-naive also allowed); For autoinjector substudy: at least 6 months prior exposure to lecanemab 10 mg/kg IV biweekly or lecanemab Dose 1 subcutaneous weekly; For subcutaneous Dose 3 autoinjector substudy: prior lecanemab (IV and/or SC) and completion of Extension Week 79 or later
reasoning: The trial requires early Alzheimer's disease with a positive amyloid biomarker and MMSE 22–30; the patient is amyloid PET/CSF negative with MMSE 19 and moderate-stage dementia, failing required eligibility.
patient_biomarkers: Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 68 years; Male; Two-year history of progressive cognitive decline; MMSE score 19; Moderate-stage dementia; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
judge_comment: The trial requires a positive amyloid biomarker; the patient is definitively amyloid-negative (PET and CSF), which is a hard exclusion. MMSE 19 and moderate-stage (vs early AD) further support ineligibility but are not needed for the F. The grader correctly applied the rubric.

question_text: What are trial options for a 66 year old male with hx hypertension, afib, T2DM and mCRPC, now progressing on enzalutamide? He has been on Lupron+Zytiga for 3 years, with new liver and bone metastases which are all PSMA PET avid. He’s tolerated therapy well overall except for grade 2 fatigue.
trial_title: A Single-Arm, Open-Label, Phase II Study of Systemic and Tumor Directed Therapy for Recurrent Oligometastatic M1 Prostate Cancer
diseases_targeted: Metastatic Prostate Adenocarcinoma; Prostate Adenocarcinoma With Focal Neuroendocrine Differentiation; Recurrent Prostate Carcinoma; Prostate Cancer (Stage IVB)
inclusion_criteria: Histologically confirmed prostate adenocarcinoma after radical prostatectomy (adenocarcinoma with neuroendocrine differentiation allowed; primary small cell not allowed) | 1–5 visible metastases by PSMA PET-CT | At least one metastasis M1a–M1b | No visceral metastases | Any number of pelvic nodal metastases allowed if largest < 2 cm | Metastases amenable to SBRT | Biopsy of one metastasis attempted unless unsafe | Fit to undergo SBRT to all visible sites and ADT | Total testosterone > 150 ng/dL prior to ADT | ECOG 0–1 | Hemoglobin >= 9.0 g/dL (independent of transfusion/growth factors within 3 months) | Platelet count >= 100,000/µL (independent of transfusion/growth factors within 3 months) | Serum albumin >= 3.0 g/dL | Glomerular filtration rate >= 45 mL/min | Serum potassium >= 3.5 mmol/L | Total bilirubin <= 1.5 x ULN (Gilbert syndrome exception allowed if direct bilirubin <= 1.5 x ULN) | AST or ALT <= 2.5 x ULN | Medications that lower seizure threshold discontinued or substituted >= 4 weeks prior to study entry
exclusion_criteria: Evidence of spinal cord compression (radiologic or clinical) | Prior pelvic malignancy | Prior pelvic radiation aside from salvage prostate radiation | Concurrent malignancy aside from superficial skin cancers or superficial bladder tumors | Inability to undergo radiotherapy or ADT | Primary small cell carcinoma of the prostate | Inflammatory bowel disease or active collagen vascular disease | History of seizure or condition predisposing to seizure | Prior stroke within 1 year prior to randomization | Brain arteriovenous malformation, Schwannoma, meningioma, or other benign CNS/meningeal disease which may require surgery or radiotherapy | Severe or unstable angina within 6 months prior to randomization | Myocardial infarction within 6 months prior to randomization | Symptomatic congestive heart failure within 6 months prior to randomization | Arterial or venous thromboembolic events within 6 months prior to randomization | Clinically significant ventricular arrhythmias within 6 months prior to randomization | Uncontrolled hypertension | Gastrointestinal disorder affecting absorption | Active infection including HIV or viral hepatitis | Chronic corticosteroid requirement > 10 mg prednisone/prednisolone once daily | Concomitant strong CYP3A4 inducers | Treatment with CYP2D6 substrates with a narrow therapeutic index (unless an alternative or dose reduction is used) | Baseline moderate or severe hepatic impairment (Child-Pugh Class B or C) | Presence of visceral metastases (M1c)
prior_therapies: Discontinue or substitute medications that lower the seizure threshold >= 4 weeks before study entry
reasoning: The trial explicitly excludes patients with visceral metastases (M1c), and the patient has PSMA PET–avid liver metastases. This is a definitive exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 66 years; Male sex; Metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer; Progression on enzalutamide; PSMA PET avid liver and bone metastases
patient_prior_therapies: Progression on enzalutamide; Prior abiraterone (Zytiga) with leuprolide (Lupron) for 3 years
judge_comment: The trial explicitly excludes patients with visceral metastases (M1c). The patient has liver metastases, a visceral site, so this is a hard exclusion. The grader correctly applied the rubric and assigned F for this explicit exclusion.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?

inclusion_criteria: Histologically confirmed non-small cell lung cancer, Stage IV | BRAF V600 mutation in tumor (V600E; V600K/D allowed) | Treatment-naive or one prior line of systemic therapy for advanced/metastatic disease | Measurable disease per RECIST v1.1 | ECOG performance status 0–1 | Adequate bone marrow, hepatic, and renal function
exclusion_criteria: EGFR mutation, ALK fusion, or ROS1 rearrangement | More than one prior line of systemic therapy in the advanced/metastatic setting | Prior treatment with any BRAF inhibitor | Prior treatment with any MEK inhibitor | Impaired cardiovascular function or clinically significant cardiovascular disease | Thromboembolic or cerebrovascular events within 12 weeks prior to first dose | History or current evidence of retinal vein occlusion or risk factors for RVO | History of retinal degenerative disease | Concurrent neuromuscular disorder associated with elevated CK | Symptomatic brain metastases, leptomeningeal disease, or other active CNS metastases
prior_therapies: Treatment-naive allowed; One prior line with platinum-based chemotherapy allowed; One prior line with PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitor allowed
reasoning: The trial requires a BRAF V600 mutation and explicitly excludes patients with EGFR mutations; the patient has an EGFR exon 19 deletion, which is a hard exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Non-small cell lung cancer; De novo metastatic disease (bone, liver); EGFR exon 19 deletion; ECOG 0; Age 40 years
judge_comment: The trial explicitly excludes EGFR mutations and requires BRAF V600; the patient has an EGFR exon 19 mutation and lacks BRAF V600. This is a hard exclusion, so F is correct.

question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.
