patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 68 years; Male; Two-year history of progressive cognitive decline; MMSE score 19; Moderate-stage dementia; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
judge_comment: Disease mismatch is a hard exclusion: the trial requires Parkinson’s disease/parkinsonism (incl. DLB), while the patient has unspecified dementia with no PD/parkinsonism/DLB specified. Thus F is correct.

question_text: What are trial options for a 66 year old male with hx hypertension, afib, T2DM and mCRPC, now progressing on enzalutamide? He has been on Lupron+Zytiga for 3 years, with new liver and bone metastases which are all PSMA PET avid. He’s tolerated therapy well overall except for grade 2 fatigue.
trial_title: A Phase II Study of Carboplatin, Cabazitaxel and Abiraterone in High Volume Metastatic Castration Sensitive Prostate Cancer
inclusion_criteria: Histologically confirmed prostate cancer | High-volume metastatic disease (visceral metastases or >=3 bone lesions) | Androgen deprivation therapy for <=3 months by day 1 of study chemotherapy; prior courses of ADT with radiation allowed | Testosterone <=50 ng/dL; continue primary ADT with an LHRH analogue if no orchiectomy | ECOG Performance Status 0–1 | Age >= 18 years
exclusion_criteria: Prior chemotherapy, PARP inhibitor, or immunotherapy for prostate cancer | Prior abiraterone or enzalutamide unless therapy was <2 weeks | Radiation therapy within 14 days prior to first dose | Major surgery within 28 days prior to first dose | Other systemic therapies for prostate cancer within 28 days or 5 half-lives (whichever is shorter) prior to day 1 of chemotherapy, except anti-androgens like bicalutamide | PSA <2.0 ng/mL at diagnosis | Peripheral neuropathy > Grade 1 | Active second malignancy that could interfere with participation | Central nervous system involvement unless >=4 weeks from prior therapy, clinically stable, and only if symptomatic screening is indicated | Severe psychiatric illness or social situation limiting compliance | History of non-compliance to medical regimens or inability to grant consent
prior_therapies: Androgen deprivation therapy <= 3 months before day 1; prior ADT courses with radiation allowed; Must continue androgen deprivation therapy with LHRH analogue or have undergone orchiectomy; Radiation therapy washout >=14 days before first dose; Major surgery washout >=28 days before first dose; Other systemic prostate cancer therapies require washout of >=28 days or 5 half-lives (whichever is shorter), except bicalutamide; Prior abiraterone or enzalutamide allowed only if <2 weeks exposure
reasoning: The trial is for metastatic castration-sensitive prostate cancer and excludes prior abiraterone or enzalutamide use >2 weeks, whereas the patient has metastatic castration-resistant disease with long prior exposure to both. This is a hard disease-setting mismatch and an explicit exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 66 years; Male sex; Metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer; Progression on enzalutamide; PSMA PET avid liver and bone metastases
patient_prior_therapies: Progression on enzalutamide; Prior abiraterone (Zytiga) with leuprolide (Lupron) for 3 years
judge_comment: Hard exclusions apply: (1) Disease-setting mismatch (trial is for metastatic castration-sensitive; patient has metastatic castration-resistant). (2) Explicit exclusion: prior abiraterone/enzalutamide only allowed if <2 weeks; patient had long prior exposure to both. Therefore F is correct.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
trial_title: A Phase 3 Study of Pembrolizumab in Combination With Pemetrexed/Platinum (Carboplatin or Cisplatin) Followed by Pembrolizumab and Maintenance Olaparib vs Maintenance Pemetrexed in the First-Line Treatment of Participants With Metastatic Nonsquamous Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC)
inclusion_criteria: Histologically or cytologically confirmed nonsquamous non-small cell lung cancer | Stage IV nonsquamous non-small cell lung cancer | EGFR/ALK/ROS1-directed therapy not indicated | Measurable disease per RECIST 1.1 | Archival or newly obtained tumor tissue available; adequate sample confirmation by central lab | Life expectancy >= 3 months | ECOG performance status 0 or 1 | No prior systemic treatment for advanced/metastatic NSCLC | Adequate organ function
exclusion_criteria: Predominantly squamous cell histology NSCLC | Active additional malignancy requiring treatment or progressed within past 3 years | Known active CNS metastases and/or carcinomatous meningitis | Severe hypersensitivity (>= Grade 3) to pembrolizumab or its excipients | Known hypersensitivity to cisplatin, carboplatin, pemetrexed, or olaparib components/excipients | Active autoimmune disease requiring systemic treatment within past 2 years | Diagnosis of immunodeficiency or chronic systemic steroid therapy | Known history of HIV infection | Known history of hepatitis B infection | Known active hepatitis C virus infection | Interstitial lung disease or history of pneumonitis requiring systemic steroids | Prior therapy with olaparib or any PARP inhibitor | Prior therapy with PD-L1, anti PD-L2, CTLA-4, OX-40, CD137, or other stimulatory/co-inhibitory T-cell agents | Myelodysplastic syndrome or acute myeloid leukemia or features suggestive of MDS/AML | History of a second malignancy unless curatively treated with no evidence of disease for 2 years | Completed palliative radiotherapy within 7 days of first study dose or not recovered from radiation-related toxicities or requiring corticosteroids
prior_therapies: No prior systemic therapy for advanced/metastatic NSCLC; No prior PARP inhibitor; No prior anti–PD-(L)1/PD-L2/CTLA-4 or other T-cell targeting agents; Palliative radiotherapy washout >= 7 days
reasoning: The trial requires no prior systemic therapy for advanced/metastatic NSCLC and that EGFR-directed therapy not be indicated; the patient has received osimertinib and has an EGFR exon 19 deletion, violating these criteria.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Non-small cell lung cancer; De novo metastatic disease (bone, liver); EGFR exon 19 deletion; ECOG 0; Age 40 years
judge_comment: Correct. The trial requires EGFR/ALK/ROS1-directed therapy not be indicated; the patient has EGFR exon 19 deletion (required biomarker mismatch → hard exclusion). Additionally, the trial is first-line only and the patient has prior osimertinib, reinforcing ineligibility.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
trial_title: A Phase 3 Study of Pembrolizumab in Combination With Carboplatin/Taxane (Paclitaxel or Nab-paclitaxel) Followed by Pembrolizumab With or Without Maintenance Olaparib in the First-line Treatment of Metastatic Squamous Non-small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC)
inclusion_criteria: Histologically or cytologically confirmed squamous non-small cell lung cancer | Stage IV disease | Measurable disease per RECIST 1.1 | No prior systemic therapy for advanced/metastatic NSCLC | Archival or newly obtained tumor tissue available for central adequacy confirmation | ECOG performance status 0–1 | Life expectancy >= 3 months | Adequate organ function
exclusion_criteria: Non-squamous histology NSCLC | Additional malignancy requiring active treatment within past 3 years | Known active central nervous system metastases or carcinomatous meningitis | Hypersensitivity to carboplatin, paclitaxel, nab-paclitaxel, or olaparib | Severe hypersensitivity (>= Grade 3) to pembrolizumab or its excipients | Active autoimmune disease requiring systemic treatment within past 2 years | Immunodeficiency or chronic systemic steroid therapy | Known HIV infection | Known hepatitis B infection | Known active hepatitis C virus infection | Interstitial lung disease or history of pneumonitis requiring systemic steroids | Prior therapy with olaparib or any PARP inhibitor | Prior therapy with PD-1/PD-L1/PD-L2 or CTLA-4/OX-40/CD137 agents | Myelodysplastic syndrome or acute myeloid leukemia, or features suggestive of MDS/AML
prior_therapies: No prior systemic therapy for advanced/metastatic NSCLC
reasoning: The trial requires no prior systemic therapy for advanced/metastatic NSCLC (first-line only), but the patient has received osimertinib in the metastatic setting. Additionally, the trial requires squamous histology, which is not confirmed for this patient.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Non-small cell lung cancer; De novo metastatic disease (bone, liver); EGFR exon 19 deletion; ECOG 0; Age 40 years
judge_comment: Correct. The trial requires first-line treatment (no prior systemic therapy for advanced/metastatic NSCLC), but the patient has received osimertinib in the metastatic setting—this is a hard exclusion (required setting not met). Histology is unknown and should not trigger F by itself, but the prior-therapy requirement alone justifies F.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: Fecal Microbiota Transplantation (FMT) for Immune-Checkpoint Inhibitor Induced-Diarrhea/Colitis in Genitourinary Cancer Patients
diseases_targeted: Breast Cancer; Cervical Cancer; Colitis; Diarrhea; Lung Cancer; Malignant Genitourinary System Neoplasm; Melanoma; Ovarian Cancer; Uterine Cancer
inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of malignancy in genitourinary, melanoma, non-melanoma skin, lung, head and neck, sarcoma/lymphoma, gastrointestinal (luminal GI, hepatobiliary, pancreas), gynecologic (ovarian, uterine, cervical), or breast cancer | Treatment with any immune checkpoint inhibitor (ICPI) agent(s) | New onset of >= grade 2 ICPI-induced diarrhea and/or colitis within 45 days prior to FMT, without involvement of non-GI toxicity | Prior steroid use allowed if last dose > 30 days before FMT or treatment duration < 7 days beyond one week prior to FMT | Prior immunosuppressant (e.g., infliximab, vedolizumab) use allowed if last dose >= 3 months prior when used for conditions other than ICI-induced GI toxicities | No active concomitant GI infection at initiation of protocol therapy as confirmed by stool tests or treating physician assessment | Cleared for enrollment by Infectious Diseases consultant or treating physician if positive infection workup or screening tests prior to therapy | Life expectancy > 6 months
exclusion_criteria: Age < 18 years | Persistent GI infection with positive stool test(s) despite completing 5 days of antibiotics before protocol therapy | History of inflammatory bowel disease or radiation enteritis/colitis with active disease at treatment initiation | Pregnant or breastfeeding | Positive urine or serum pregnancy test or refusal to test unless clearly peri- or post-menopausal or objective evidence of no pregnancy within 30 days prior to treatment | Immunosuppressive treatment at onset of ICPI-induced diarrhea/colitis | Medical conditions high risk for colonoscopy (e.g., severe heart failure, brain hemorrhage, septic shock) | Concurrent non-GI toxicity at time of study treatment | Donors at risk for monkeypox infection or exposure
prior_therapies: Prior treatment with any ICPI agent(s) required; Prior corticosteroids permitted with washout/restrictions as specified; Prior immunosuppressants (e.g., infliximab, vedolizumab) permitted if last dose >= 3 months and used for non-ICI GI indications
reasoning: The trial is for cancer patients with immune checkpoint inhibitor–induced diarrhea/colitis; the patient has Crohn's disease without malignancy or ICI exposure, and active inflammatory bowel disease is explicitly excluded.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe Crohn's disease; Fistulizing disease; CDAI score 350; Active perianal fistula with draining seton in place
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab
judge_comment: Hard exclusions apply: explicit exclusion of active inflammatory bowel disease (patient has active Crohn’s) and required prior ICPI exposure/malignancy not met. Disease mismatch also present. Grader correctly assigned F and cited key reasons.

question_text: 36 female with stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma, who initially received optimal debulking and adjuvant carboplatin+paclitaxel +bevacizumab. After 5 months, she had a new pleural effusion that was cytology positive for ovarian carcinoma. She was found to be BRCA1 positive. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Randomized Phase III, Two-Arm Trial of Paclitaxel/Carboplatin/Maintenance Letrozole Versus Letrozole Monotherapy in Patients With Stage II-IV, Primary Low-Grade Serous Carcinoma of the Ovary or Peritoneum
diseases_targeted: Ovarian Low Grade Serous Carcinoma; Fallopian Tube Low Grade Serous Carcinoma; Primary Peritoneal Low Grade Serous Carcinoma
inclusion_criteria: Newly diagnosed stage II–IV low-grade serous ovarian cancer (ovarian, fallopian tube, or primary peritoneal) | Prior history of serous borderline tumor allowed | p53 immunohistochemistry nonaberrant (consistent with TP53 wildtype) | Age >= 18 years | Attempt at maximal upfront cytoreductive surgery (optimal or suboptimal residual allowed) | Bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy performed | ECOG performance status 0–2 | Able to take oral medications | ANC >= 1500/µL | Platelets >= 100000/µL | Creatinine <= 1.5 x ULN | Bilirubin <= 1.5 x ULN | AST <= 3 x ULN | ALT <= 3 x ULN | Prior or concurrent malignancy allowed if not interfering with safety or efficacy assessment | HIV-infected patients on effective antiretroviral therapy with undetectable viral load within 6 months are eligible
exclusion_criteria: Prior neoadjuvant or adjuvant chemotherapy for this disease | Prior radiotherapy for this disease | Previous hormonal therapy for this disease | Hypersensitivity to letrozole or intolerance/hypersensitivity to carboplatin/paclitaxel | Myocardial infarction or unstable angina within 6 months | New York Heart Association class II or greater congestive heart failure | Known central nervous system metastases | Active or uncontrolled systemic infection (except uncomplicated urinary tract infection) | Baseline neuropathy grade >= 2 | Aberrant p53 expression on IHC (consistent with TP53 mutation/high-grade serous ovarian cancer)
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: The trial is for newly diagnosed low-grade serous ovarian/peritoneal carcinoma (TP53 wildtype), whereas the patient has recurrent clear cell ovarian carcinoma—a disease/histology mismatch. Additionally, the trial excludes patients with prior adjuvant chemotherapy for this disease, which the patient received (carboplatin/paclitaxel).
patient_inclusion_criteria: Stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma; Cytology-positive pleural effusion; BRCA1 positive; Female; Age 36 years
patient_prior_therapies: Optimal debulking surgery; Adjuvant carboplatin plus paclitaxel plus bevacizumab
judge_comment: Hard exclusion applies: disease/histology mismatch (trial is for low-grade serous ovarian/peritoneal carcinoma; patient has clear cell ovarian carcinoma). This alone mandates F. The grader’s added note about prior adjuvant chemotherapy also conflicts with trial exclusions but is secondary. Grade F is correct.

question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.
trial_title: Atherosclerosis Intervention With Novel Tissue Selective Estrogen Complex Therapy
inclusion_criteria: Women 45-59 years old | <6 years postmenopausal | Serum estradiol <30 pg/mL | Cessation of regular menses >6 months
exclusion_criteria: Hysterectomy | Clinical signs, symptoms, or personal history of cardiovascular disease | Diabetes mellitus or fasting serum glucose >126 mg/dL | Life-threatening illness with prognosis <5 years | Cirrhosis or liver disease | History of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism | History of breast cancer | Current use of postmenopausal hormone replacement therapy within 1 month of randomization | Uncontrolled hypertension (>180/>110 mmHg) | Plasma triglycerides >500 mg/dL | Serum creatinine >2.0 mg/dL
prior_therapies: Discontinue postmenopausal hormone replacement therapy >=1 month before randomization
reasoning: The trial enrolls only females aged 45–59 years (<6 years postmenopausal), whereas the patient is a 68-year-old male; both sex and age are hard exclusions.
patient_biomarkers: Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 68 years; Male; Two-year history of progressive cognitive decline; MMSE score 19; Moderate-stage dementia; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
judge_comment: Sex restriction (female only) and age window (45–59) both exclude a 68-year-old male. These are hard exclusions per rubric, so F is correct.

question_text: What are trial options for a 3-month-old male infant with genetically confirmed Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency? He presented on day 3 of life with a severe hyperammonemic crisis (ammonia 720 μmol/L) and is now stable on a regimen of dietary protein restriction and ammonia scavengers.
trial_title: A Global, Phase 1/2, Open-Label, Dose Optimization Study to Evaluate the Safety, Pharmacodynamics, and Pharmacokinetics of mRNA-3927 in Participants With Propionic Acidemia
inclusion_criteria: Age criteria for Part 1 (>=8 years if among first 2 participants; otherwise >=1 year) | Confirmed diagnosis of propionic acidemia by molecular genetic testing (PCCA and/or PCCB mutations) | Part 2: At least one documented metabolic decompensation event in the 12 months prior to consent | Participants <1 year: Identified by newborn screening or suspected PA with an affected sibling; enrollment requires confirmed genetic diagnosis | Participants <1 year (NICU only): Gestational age >=37 weeks at birth without other conditions/comorbidities that may interfere with study | Participants <1 year: Body weight >=3 kg at Screening | Participants <1 year: At least one PA-related event prior to Screening (clinical signs of metabolic deterioration, meeting MDE definition, or laboratory abnormalities such as metabolic acidosis with elevated anion gap, acute hyperammonemia, neutropenia, or thrombocytopenia)
exclusion_criteria: Clinically significant laboratory abnormalities that could interfere with or limit participation, per investigator or sponsor | Estimated glomerular filtration rate <30 mL/min/1.73 m^2 for participants of all ages receiving chronic dialysis | History of organ transplantation or planned organ transplantation during study participation | Corrected QT interval (Bazett) >480 ms | Grade 3 or 4 heart failure (Modified Ross for Children or NYHA) | Pregnant or breastfeeding | Other clinically significant conditions that could interfere with safety, interpretation of results, or participation, per investigator
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Hard disease mismatch: the trial enrolls patients with propionic acidemia requiring PCCA/PCCB mutations, while the patient has ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency with an OTC mutation.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Genetically confirmed ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency; History of severe neonatal hyperammonemic crisis; Currently clinically stable on therapy; Male; Age 3 months
judge_comment: The trial targets propionic acidemia (PCCA/PCCB mutations), while the patient has ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency with an OTC mutation. This is a clear disease mismatch, a hard exclusion per the rubric, so grade F is correct.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
trial_title: A Randomized, Double Blind, Phase 3 Study of Platinum-Based Chemotherapy With or Without INCMGA00012 in First-Line Metastatic Squamous and Nonsquamous Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (POD1UM-304)
diseases_targeted: Squamous Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (metastatic); Nonsquamous Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (metastatic)
inclusion_criteria: Histologically or cytologically confirmed non-small cell lung cancer (squamous or nonsquamous) that is Stage IV (AJCC v8) | No prior systemic treatment for advanced/metastatic non-small cell lung cancer | Measurable disease per RECIST v1.1 | ECOG performance status 0–1 | Life expectancy >= 3 months | Adequate organ function per protocol-specified laboratory values
exclusion_criteria: Clinically significant cardiac disease within 6 months | Major surgery within 3 weeks before first dose | Thoracic radiation therapy > 30 Gy within 6 months | Peripheral neuropathy >= Grade 2 (for participants who may receive cisplatin, paclitaxel, or nab-paclitaxel) | Untreated central nervous system metastases or carcinomatous meningitis | History of interstitial lung disease or noninfectious pneumonitis that required systemic steroids | Active infection requiring systemic therapy or active tuberculosis | Superficial bladder cancer, squamous cell carcinoma of the skin, in situ cervical cancer, or other in situ cancers | Contraindications to study chemotherapy agents | Active autoimmune disease requiring systemic treatment in the past 2 years | Receiving systemic antibiotics or steroid therapy <= 7 days prior to first dose | Receipt of a live vaccine within 30 days before the first dose (and until 90 days after last dose of study drug) | Known active hepatitis B virus or hepatitis C virus infection
prior_therapies: No prior systemic therapy for advanced/metastatic non-small cell lung cancer
reasoning: The trial requires no prior systemic therapy for advanced/metastatic NSCLC, but the patient has previously received osimertinib for metastatic disease, which is an explicit exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Non-small cell lung cancer; De novo metastatic disease (bone, liver); EGFR exon 19 deletion; ECOG 0; Age 40 years
judge_comment: Trial explicitly requires no prior systemic therapy for advanced/metastatic NSCLC; the patient received osimertinib for metastatic disease. This is a hard exclusion → F per rubric.

question_text: A 55-year-old female has severe, seropositive rheumatoid arthritis refractory to methotrexate and two prior biologic agents (adalimumab and tocilizumab). She has active disease with a DAS28 score of 5.5. Critically, she has a history of treated Hepatitis B (HBsAg negative, anti-HBc positive) and moderate chronic kidney disease with an eGFR of 45 mL/min/1.73m². What are trial options for her?
trial_title: Adipose-Derived Biocellular Regenerative Therapy in Treatment of Osteoarthritis (OA) and Associated Connective Tissue Degeneration and Pain
diseases_targeted: Osteoarthritis; Knee Osteoarthritis; Shoulder Osteoarthritis; Ankle/Foot Osteoarthritis; Hip Osteoarthritis; Osteoarthritis (multiple joints)
inclusion_criteria: Documented osteoarthritic inflammatory and/or degenerative changes in the knee, hip, shoulder, Achilles tendon, sacroiliac joint, wrist/hand, foot/ankle, or plantar fasciitis | No systemic disorders that would preclude safely undergoing the procedures | Adequate perivascular and extracellular matrix donor tissues available
exclusion_criteria: Systemic or psychological impairment that would preclude tolerance and understanding of procedures and follow-up | Active cancer or receiving chemotherapy or radiation therapy | Pregnancy | Active infections increasing risk for treatment | High-dose steroid use or receipt of corticosteroids within 6 months before treatment | Medication or opiate addiction or active treatment for drug rehabilitation | History of severe traumatic brain injuries | Investigator judges medical issues would prevent completing study requirements
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: The trial targets osteoarthritis (various joints), while the patient has rheumatoid arthritis, which is not included in the trial’s disease cohorts. This is a disease mismatch hard exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 55 years; Female; Seropositive rheumatoid arthritis; Active disease (DAS28 5.5)
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to methotrexate; Prior adalimumab; Prior tocilizumab; Failed two prior biologic agents
judge_comment: Disease mismatch hard exclusion applies: patient has rheumatoid arthritis, trial targets osteoarthritis cohorts only. The grader correctly assigned F based on this hard exclusion; other anchors need not be assessed.

question_text: What are trial options for a 3-month-old male infant with genetically confirmed Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency? He presented on day 3 of life with a severe hyperammonemic crisis (ammonia 720 μmol/L) and is now stable on a regimen of dietary protein restriction and ammonia scavengers.
trial_title: Open-Label Extension Study of Theophylline for Treatment of Pseudohypoparathyroidism
diseases_targeted: Pseudohypoparathyroidism; Pseudohypoparathyroidism Type 1a; Albright Hereditary Osteodystrophy
inclusion_criteria: Successful completion of the randomized clinical trial "Phase 2 Study of Theophylline Treatment of Pseudohypoparathyroidism IND 133103 (11/1/2016)"
exclusion_criteria: History of a seizure disorder unrelated to hypocalcemia | History of a cardiac arrhythmia (not including bradycardia) | Hepatic insufficiency including cirrhosis or acute hepatitis | AST or ALT > 3 x ULN | Congestive heart failure | Current cigarette use | Alcohol abuse | Pregnancy or intention to become pregnant during the next year | Active peptic ulcer disease | Current use of medications known to affect theophylline levels | History of hypersensitivity to theophylline or other medication components | Unable to comply with study procedures in the opinion of the investigator
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets pseudohypoparathyroidism, not ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency. Additionally, the patient is 3 months old, below the trial's minimum age of 2 years.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Genetically confirmed ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency; History of severe neonatal hyperammonemic crisis; Currently clinically stable on therapy; Male; Age 3 months
judge_comment: Correct: Hard exclusions apply. Disease mismatch (OTC deficiency vs pseudohypoparathyroidism) and patient age (3 months) below trial minimum (2 years) both independently trigger an F. Grader’s reasoning aligns with the rubric.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
trial_title: Phase II Pilot Study of Performance Status 2 vs. Performance Status 0-1 Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer Patients Treated With Chemo/Immunotherapy
diseases_targeted: Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (metastatic or unresectable)
inclusion_criteria: Histologic or cytologic diagnosis of non-small cell lung cancer that is metastatic or unresectable with no curative options | No prior systemic treatment (chemotherapy or immunotherapy) for non-curative intent | Age >= 18 years | ECOG performance status 0-2 | Life expectancy > 3 months | Adequate organ and marrow function | Absolute neutrophil count >= 1000/µL | Platelets >= 100000/µL | Women of child-bearing potential and men agree to use adequate contraception during study treatment
exclusion_criteria: Presence of a targetable activating alteration for which first-line targeted therapy is indicated (e.g., EGFR activating mutation, ALK rearrangement, ROS1 rearrangement, BRAF mutation) | Active autoimmune disease requiring systemic treatment within the past 2 years | History of non-infectious pneumonitis that required systemic corticosteroids | Uncontrolled intercurrent illness (e.g., active infection, symptomatic congestive heart failure, unstable angina, clinically significant arrhythmia, or significant psychiatric illness) | Pregnancy or breastfeeding
prior_therapies: No prior systemic therapy for advanced/metastatic disease; Prior curative-intent therapy allowed
reasoning: The trial excludes patients with targetable EGFR activating mutations and requires no prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease; this patient has an EGFR exon 19 deletion and has received osimertinib.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Non-small cell lung cancer; De novo metastatic disease (bone, liver); EGFR exon 19 deletion; ECOG 0; Age 40 years
judge_comment: The trial explicitly excludes patients with targetable EGFR activating mutations; the patient has an EGFR exon 19 deletion, triggering a hard exclusion. Additionally, the trial requires no prior systemic therapy for advanced disease, while the patient received osimertinib. F is correct.

question_text: What are trial options for a 66 year old male with hx hypertension, afib, T2DM and mCRPC, now progressing on enzalutamide? He has been on Lupron+Zytiga for 3 years, with new liver and bone metastases which are all PSMA PET avid. He’s tolerated therapy well overall except for grade 2 fatigue.
trial_title: Advanced ChemoHormonal Therapy for Treatment Naïve Metastatic Prostate Cancer: Apalutamide and Abiraterone Acetate With Prednisone and Androgen Deprivation Therapy After Treatment With Docetaxel and Androgen Deprivation Therapy
inclusion_criteria: Histologically or cytologically confirmed prostate cancer or strong clinical suspicion with metastatic pattern and PSA > 50 ng/mL | High-risk disease: either (a) at least 2 of visceral metastases, >=3 bone lesions, Gleason 8–10; or (b) >=4 bone lesions with >=1 outside vertebral column or pelvis and/or visceral metastases | Prior neoadjuvant or adjuvant ADT allowed if >= 24 months elapsed before restarting ADT for metastatic castration-sensitive disease | ADT-sensitive disease with no PSA progression or new metastatic deposits since starting ADT | Completed up to 6 cycles of docetaxel for metastatic castration-sensitive disease with <= 16 weeks since day 21 of the final cycle | Life expectancy > 18 months | ECOG performance status <= 2 | Hemoglobin > 9.0 g/dL | Leukocytes > 3,000/µL | Absolute neutrophil count > 1,500/µL | Platelets >= 100,000/µL | Total bilirubin <= 1.5 x ULN | AST/ALT < 2.5 x ULN | Albumin > 3 g/dL | eGFR > 30 mL/min | Potassium >= 3.5 mmol/L | Medications known to lower the seizure threshold discontinued or substituted >= 4 weeks prior to day 1
exclusion_criteria: Unwilling to stop saw palmetto, PC-SPECs, or other herbal agents known to affect PSA | Receipt of other investigational agents within 30 days prior to day 1 | Prior exposure to apalutamide, enzalutamide, abiraterone, darolutamide, or any other second-generation antiandrogen therapy | History of allergic reactions to compounds similar to apalutamide or study agents | Another active malignancy other than non-melanoma skin cancer (unless metastatic) or superficial bladder cancer | Seizure or condition predisposing to seizure (e.g., prior stroke within 1 year, brain AVM, schwannoma, meningioma, or other benign CNS/meningeal disease requiring treatment) | Severe or unstable angina, recent myocardial infarction, symptomatic congestive heart failure or LVEF < 50%, thromboembolic events, or clinically significant ventricular arrhythmias within 6 months prior to day 1 | Uncontrolled hypertension | Gastrointestinal disorder affecting absorption | Active infection (e.g., HIV or viral hepatitis) | Chronic medical condition requiring > 10 mg prednisone/prednisolone daily | Baseline moderate or severe hepatic impairment (Child-Pugh Class B or C) | Inability to stop prohibited medications: atypical antipsychotics, bupropion, lithium, meperidine/pethidine, phenothiazine antipsychotics, tricyclic antidepressants, tramadol
prior_therapies: Up to 6 cycles of docetaxel for metastatic castration-sensitive disease completed; <= 16 weeks since day 21 of final cycle; Prior neoadjuvant or adjuvant ADT allowed if >= 24 months elapsed before restarting ADT for metastatic castration-sensitive disease; Ongoing ADT with castration-sensitive disease and no PSA progression or new metastases since starting ADT
reasoning: Trial targets metastatic castration-sensitive prostate cancer and requires ADT-sensitive disease, but the patient has metastatic castration-resistant disease. It also explicitly excludes prior enzalutamide or abiraterone exposure, both of which the patient received.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 66 years; Male sex; Metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer; Progression on enzalutamide; PSMA PET avid liver and bone metastases
patient_prior_therapies: Progression on enzalutamide; Prior abiraterone (Zytiga) with leuprolide (Lupron) for 3 years
judge_comment: Hard exclusions apply: disease mismatch (mCRPC patient vs mCSPC trial) and explicit exclusion of prior enzalutamide/abiraterone exposure. The grader correctly identified these and assigned F.

question_text: A 55-year-old female has severe, seropositive rheumatoid arthritis refractory to methotrexate and two prior biologic agents (adalimumab and tocilizumab). She has active disease with a DAS28 score of 5.5. Critically, she has a history of treated Hepatitis B (HBsAg negative, anti-HBc positive) and moderate chronic kidney disease with an eGFR of 45 mL/min/1.73m². What are trial options for her?
trial_title: A Phase III, Randomized, Double-Blind, Single-Dose, Placebo-Controlled Study to Demonstrate the Efficacy and Safety of Tildrakizumab in Subjects With Active Psoriatic Arthritis I (INSPIRE 1)
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Rheumatoid factor negative | Anti-CCP antibody negative | Prior exposure to anti-TNF agent(s) for psoriasis or psoriatic arthritis
exclusion_criteria: Planned surgical intervention for a pretreatment condition between baseline and Week 24 | Active infection requiring systemic anti-infectives within 28 days before first dose | Serious infection requiring hospitalization or IV anti-infectives within 8 weeks before first dose | Recurrent or chronic infections (e.g., chronic pyelonephritis, chronic osteomyelitis, bronchiectasis) | History of hepatitis B infection | History of hepatitis C infection | History of HIV infection | Myocardial infarction, unstable angina, or ischemic stroke within 6 months before first dose | Active malignancy, including cutaneous basal or squamous cell carcinoma or melanoma | History of malignancy within 5 years except treated and cured cutaneous basal or squamous cell carcinoma, in situ cervical carcinoma, or in situ ductal breast carcinoma | History of alcohol or drug abuse within the previous 2 years | Unwilling or unable to use adequate contraception as specified | Donation or loss of >= 400 mL of blood within 8 weeks before dosing
prior_therapies: Prior anti-TNF therapy for psoriasis or psoriatic arthritis
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets active psoriatic arthritis, while the patient has rheumatoid arthritis.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 55 years; Female; Seropositive rheumatoid arthritis; Active disease (DAS28 5.5)
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to methotrexate; Prior adalimumab; Prior tocilizumab; Failed two prior biologic agents
judge_comment: Disease mismatch is a hard exclusion: the trial is for psoriatic arthritis, while the patient has rheumatoid arthritis. The grader correctly assigned F based on this.

question_text: 36 female with stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma, who initially received optimal debulking and adjuvant carboplatin+paclitaxel +bevacizumab. After 5 months, she had a new pleural effusion that was cytology positive for ovarian carcinoma. She was found to be BRCA1 positive. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Phase I/Ib Trial of the CDK4/6 Antagonist Ribociclib And The HDAC Inhibitor Belinostat In Patients With Metastatic Triple Negative Breast Cancer And Recurrent Ovarian Cancer With Response Prediction By Genomics (CHARGE)
diseases_targeted: Triple-Negative Breast Cancer (metastatic); Ovarian Carcinoma (serous, recurrent)
inclusion_criteria: Dose escalation: Pathologically confirmed metastatic or unresectable triple-negative breast cancer with measurable disease by RECIST 1.1, ER and PR <= 1% by IHC, HER2 negative, not amenable to curative therapy. | Dose escalation: Pathologically confirmed recurrent, unresectable serous ovarian carcinoma. | Dose expansion: Pathologically confirmed metastatic or unresectable triple-negative breast cancer with measurable disease by RECIST 1.1, ER and PR <= 1% by IHC, HER2 negative, not amenable to curative therapy. | Age >= 18. | ECOG performance status <= 2. | Able to swallow pills. | Adequate organ function per protocol thresholds. | At least one safely accessible metastatic site for biopsy and willingness to undergo up to 3 biopsies. | Negative pregnancy test for women of childbearing potential. | Agrees to use effective contraception for at least 6 months after last dose. | Able to provide informed consent.
exclusion_criteria: Prior treatment with CDK4/6 inhibitors or HDAC inhibitors for cancer. | Major surgery, radiotherapy, anticancer therapy, or investigational agents within 4 weeks or <= 5 half-lives (whichever is shorter). | Active or progressive brain metastases or leptomeningeal disease unless CNS-specific treatment not required during first cycle per treating physician. | Requirement for valproic acid within 5 days before first belinostat dose or during study. | Active infection requiring systemic therapy. | Allergy or hypersensitivity to belinostat, ribociclib, or their binders. | Uncontrolled arrhythmia, congestive heart failure, or angina; MI, symptomatic pericarditis, or cardiac surgery within 6 months. | Left ventricular ejection fraction < 50%. | Clinically significant cardiac arrhythmias, complete left bundle branch block, or high-grade AV block. | Congenital long QT syndrome. | Baseline QTcF > 450 msec with heart rate 50–90 BPM required on qualifying ECG. | Concurrent use of UGT1A1 inhibitors within 7 days prior to day 1. | Concurrent herbal supplements unless approved; must discontinue >= 7 days prior to day 1. | Concurrent medications with known risk of Torsades de Pointes that cannot be discontinued or switched >= 7 days prior to start. | Unresolved diarrhea >= Grade 2 (CTCAE v5.0). | Use within 7 days prior to start of strong/moderate CYP3A4/5 inducers or inhibitors, certain narrow-therapeutic-index CYP3A4/5 substrates, or grapefruit/pomelo/star-fruit/Seville orange. | Current treatment with warfarin or other coumarin anticoagulants (other anticoagulants allowed). | Impaired GI function that may alter drug absorption (e.g., uncontrolled IBD, uncontrolled vomiting, major stomach or small bowel resection). | Pregnant or breastfeeding. | Women or men of childbearing potential not using highly effective contraception during treatment and for 6 months after. | Known HIV infection with detectable viral load within 6 months (controlled on ART with undetectable load eligible). | Known chronic HBV or HCV infection with detectable viral load (suppressed/undetectable viral load eligible). | Another malignancy (other than breast or ovarian in dose escalation) anticipated to need systemic treatment within 1 year.
prior_therapies: Washout >= 4 weeks (or >= 5 half-lives) from major surgery, radiotherapy, anticancer therapy, or investigational agents before day 1.
reasoning: The ovarian cohort requires recurrent unresectable serous ovarian carcinoma, while the patient has clear cell ovarian carcinoma, a non-included subtype. This is a disease/subtype mismatch and a hard exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma; Cytology-positive pleural effusion; BRCA1 positive; Female; Age 36 years
patient_prior_therapies: Optimal debulking surgery; Adjuvant carboplatin plus paclitaxel plus bevacizumab
judge_comment: Trial ovarian cohort explicitly requires serous histology; patient has clear cell ovarian carcinoma. This is a required subtype mismatch, which is a hard exclusion per rubric, so F is appropriate.

question_text: What are trial options for a 66 year old male with hx hypertension, afib, T2DM and mCRPC, now progressing on enzalutamide? He has been on Lupron+Zytiga for 3 years, with new liver and bone metastases which are all PSMA PET avid. He’s tolerated therapy well overall except for grade 2 fatigue.
trial_title: A Randomized Phase II Study Comparing Sequential High Dose Testosterone and Enzalutamide to Enzalutamide Alone in Asymptomatic Men With Castration Resistant Metastatic Prostate Cancer
inclusion_criteria: ECOG performance status <=2 | Age >=18 years | Histologically confirmed prostate adenocarcinoma | On continuous androgen deprivation therapy (surgical castration or LHRH agonist/antagonist) | Castrate serum testosterone <50 ng/dL | Metastatic disease documented by CT or bone scan | Disease progression on abiraterone acetate plus ADT (PSA and/or radiographic per RECIST 1.1 or PCWG3) | Screening PSA >= 1.0 ng/mL | Biopsy required if soft tissue lesion amenable (pre-treatment and on-treatment) | No prior enzalutamide, apalutamide, darolutamide, or investigational AR-targeted therapy | Prior testosterone allowed | Prior docetaxel for hormone-sensitive disease allowed (<=6 doses) | Prior sipuleucel-T and radium-223 allowed if >4 weeks from last dose | Abiraterone discontinued >=2 weeks before starting therapy | Attempt to wean off prednisone; continue lowest achievable dose if unable to fully wean | Bilirubin < 2.5 x ULN | AST < 2.5 x ULN | ALT < 2.5 x ULN | Serum creatinine < 2.5 x ULN | Absolute neutrophil count >= 1500 /µL | Platelet count >= 100000 /µL | Hemoglobin >= 8 g/dL | At least 4 weeks since prior radiation or chemotherapy
exclusion_criteria: Pain due to metastatic prostate cancer requiring treatment intervention with pain medication | ECOG performance status >=3 | Prior enzalutamide therapy | Prior chemotherapy with docetaxel or cabazitaxel for castration-resistant prostate cancer | Requires urinary self-catheterization for voiding due to obstruction from prostate cancer or BPH (indwelling Foley or suprapubic catheter allowed) | Disease sites/extent that increase risk from testosterone therapy (e.g., femoral metastases with fracture risk, severe/extensive spinal metastases with cord compression risk, extensive liver metastases) | Serious or unstable medical, psychiatric, or other condition that could interfere with safety or consent | Active uncontrolled infection, including known HIV/AIDS, hepatitis B, or hepatitis C | Any condition or mental impairment compromising consent, safety, or compliance | Current anticoagulation with warfarin, rivaroxaban, or apixaban (unless transitioned to enoxaparin prior to treatment) | History of thromboembolic event within 12 months not on systemic anticoagulation | Hematocrit >51% | Untreated severe obstructive sleep apnea | Uncontrolled or poorly controlled heart failure | Allergy to sesame seed oil or cottonseed oil | Major surgery within 3 weeks before screening or not fully recovered from prior surgery
prior_therapies: Continuous androgen deprivation therapy required; Progression on abiraterone acetate plus ADT required; No prior enzalutamide, apalutamide, darolutamide, or investigational AR-targeted therapy; Prior testosterone allowed; Prior docetaxel for hormone-sensitive disease allowed (<=6 doses); Prior sipuleucel-T allowed (>4 weeks washout); Prior radium-223 allowed (>4 weeks washout); Abiraterone washout >=2 weeks before starting study therapy; At least 4 weeks since prior radiation or chemotherapy; Attempt to taper prednisone to lowest feasible dose before starting therapy
reasoning: The trial explicitly excludes patients with any prior enzalutamide therapy, and this patient has progressed on enzalutamide. Additionally, the trial requires progression on abiraterone + ADT, which is not confirmed for this patient.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 66 years; Male sex; Metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer; Progression on enzalutamide; PSMA PET avid liver and bone metastases
patient_prior_therapies: Progression on enzalutamide; Prior abiraterone (Zytiga) with leuprolide (Lupron) for 3 years
judge_comment: Correct: The trial explicitly excludes any prior enzalutamide, and the patient has progressed on enzalutamide. That is a hard exclusion → F. The note about abiraterone progression being unconfirmed is not needed for the F but does not affect the outcome.

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 8-year-old female with PMM2-CDG (Congenital Disorder of Glycosylation). She has confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2 and exhibits moderate cerebellar dysfunction with a recent ICARS score of 35. Her family is highly motivated for research participation.
trial_title: An Open-label, Phase 1/2 Study to Evaluate the Safety and Efficacy of Single-dose LY3884961 in Infants With Type 2 Gaucher Disease
inclusion_criteria: Bi-allelic GBA1 mutations consistent with Gaucher Disease Type 2 confirmed by central laboratory | Clinical diagnosis of Gaucher Disease Type 2
exclusion_criteria: Significant CNS disease other than Gaucher Disease Type 2 | Achieved independent gait | Severe peripheral symptoms of Gaucher Disease posing unacceptable risk or interfering with study conduct | Concomitant disease, condition, or treatment posing unacceptable risk or interfering with study conduct | Use of any substrate reduction therapy for Gaucher Disease treatment | Use of prohibited medications, herbal, or over-the-counter agents | Any prior gene or cell therapy | Use of systemic immunosuppressant or corticosteroid therapy other than protocol-specified immunosuppression | Participation in another investigational drug or device study within the past 3 months | Brain MRI/MRA showing clinically significant abnormality that contraindicates intracisternal injection | Clinically significant laboratory test result abnormalities at screening | Contraindications or intolerance to MRI, MRA, CT, or contrast agents | Contraindications to general anesthesia or sedation
prior_therapies: No investigational drug or device within 3 months
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial is for Gaucher Disease Type 2 with required bi-allelic GBA1 mutations, while the patient has PMM2-CDG with PMM2 variants. Additionally, the trial enrolls infants ≤24 months, and the patient is 8 years old.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of PMM2-CDG; Confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2; ICARS score 35 (moderate cerebellar dysfunction); Age 8 years
judge_comment: Clear hard exclusions: disease mismatch (Gaucher type 2 vs PMM2-CDG) and required biomarker mismatch (GBA1 vs PMM2). Additionally, age 8 years exceeds trial’s ≤24 months cap. F is appropriate per rubric.

question_text: A 55-year-old female has severe, seropositive rheumatoid arthritis refractory to methotrexate and two prior biologic agents (adalimumab and tocilizumab). She has active disease with a DAS28 score of 5.5. Critically, she has a history of treated Hepatitis B (HBsAg negative, anti-HBc positive) and moderate chronic kidney disease with an eGFR of 45 mL/min/1.73m². What are trial options for her?
trial_title: A Multicenter, Open-Label Extension Study to Asses the Long-Term Safety, Tolerability, and Efficacy of Bimekizumab in the Treatment of Study Participants With Active Axial Spondyloarthritis, Ankylosing Spondylitis, and Nonradiographic Axial Spondyloarthritis
diseases_targeted: Axial Spondyloarthritis; Ankylosing Spondylitis; Nonradiographic Axial Spondyloarthritis
inclusion_criteria: Completed feeder study AS0010 (NCT03928704) or AS0011 (NCT03928743)
exclusion_criteria: Plans for pregnancy during the study or within 20 weeks after final dose (self or partner). | Meets withdrawal criteria in AS0010 or AS0011. | Ongoing serious adverse event or history of serious infections in feeder study (medical monitor approval required). | Positive or indeterminate interferon gamma release assay unless appropriately evaluated and treated.
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets axial spondyloarthritis/ankylosing spondylitis, while the patient has rheumatoid arthritis. Additionally, it requires completion of specific feeder studies.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 55 years; Female; Seropositive rheumatoid arthritis; Active disease (DAS28 5.5)
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to methotrexate; Prior adalimumab; Prior tocilizumab; Failed two prior biologic agents
judge_comment: Correct: Hard exclusion due to disease mismatch (RA vs axial spondyloarthritis/AS/nr-axSpA). Age/sex do not conflict. The mention of feeder-study completion is not needed (and is unknown), but the disease mismatch alone warrants F.

question_text: 40 year old man with recurrent glioblastoma. Diagnosed 1 year ago, underwent gross total resection with confirmation of GBM, IDH wildtype. Completed adjuvant radiation + concurrent temozolomide and then adjuvant temozolomide. Three months after completing adjuvant therapy, MRI shows recurrence. ECOG 1 and no other medical issues. What are trial options?
trial_title: Phase I Study of Cellular Immunotherapy Using Memory Enriched T Cells Lentivirally Transduced to Express an IL13Rα2-Targeting, Hinge-Optimized, 41BB-Costimulatory Chimeric Receptor and a Truncated CD19 for Children With Recurrent/Refractory Malignant Brain Tumors
inclusion_criteria: Karnofsky Performance Status >= 60% (except loss of mobility due to disease involvement) | Life expectancy > 4 weeks | Histologically confirmed malignant brain neoplasm progressed after prior conventional therapy | Radiographic progression/recurrence > 12 weeks after completion of initial conventional therapy (including initial radiation therapy) | IL13Ralpha2-positive tumor expression by IHC (H-score >= 50) confirmed by institutional pathology | Programmable shunt present if applicable and able to tolerate being switched off for >= 2 consecutive days | Platelets >= 50,000/µL | Total bilirubin <= 2 x ULN (unless Gilbert's disease) | AST <= 2 x ULN | ALT <= 2 x ULN | Creatinine clearance >= 75 mL/min/1.73m^2 | Seronegative for HIV Ag/Ab combo, negative for active HBV (HBsAg negative), and HCV as per RNA testing if antibody positive | Women of childbearing potential: negative pregnancy test | Females and males of childbearing potential agree to effective contraception or abstinence during study and for 6 months after last dose | Dexamethasone dose <= 0.1 mg/kg/day on day of PBMC collection | Adequate venous access for PBMC collection | At least 2 weeks since last dose of prior targeted agents, chemotherapy, or radiation before PBMC collection | Serum creatinine < 1.6 mg/dL (for CNS catheter placement eligibility) | WBC >= 2,000/µL (for CNS catheter placement eligibility) | ANC >= 1,000/µL (for CNS catheter placement eligibility) | Platelets > 50,000/µL (for CNS catheter placement eligibility) | INR <= 1.3 (for CNS catheter placement eligibility) | Bilirubin < 1.5 mg/dL (for CNS catheter placement eligibility) | ALT and AST < 2 x ULN (for CNS catheter placement eligibility) | Second-line radiation therapy completed >= 4 weeks prior to surgical resection/biopsy/catheter placement | No supplemental oxygen required to keep saturation > 95% and no progressive chest radiographic abnormalities (for lymphodepletion/infusion eligibility) | No pressor support required and no symptomatic cardiac arrhythmias (for lymphodepletion/infusion eligibility) | Afebrile (<= 38.5 C) with no positive blood cultures and no indications of meningitis within 48 hours prior to infusion | Hepatic: total bilirubin or transaminases <= 2 x ULN (for lymphodepletion/infusion eligibility) | Renal: serum creatinine < 1.8 mg/dL (for lymphodepletion/infusion eligibility) | No uncontrolled seizure activity (for lymphodepletion/infusion eligibility) | For each CAR T infusion: platelet count >= 50,000/µL (transfusion permitted to achieve >= 50,000/µL) | For each CAR T infusion: dexamethasone <= 0.1 mg/kg/day
exclusion_criteria: Requires supplemental oxygen to keep saturation > 95% and not expected to resolve within 2 weeks | Requires pressor support and/or has symptomatic cardiac arrhythmias | Requires dialysis | Uncontrolled seizure activity and/or clinically evident progressive encephalopathy | Poorly controlled non-malignant intercurrent illness or illness severity deemed unsafe by investigators | Any other active malignancy | Being treated for severe infection or recovering from major surgery until recovery is complete | Uncontrolled illness including ongoing or active infection; known active hepatitis B or C infection; signs or symptoms of active infection, positive blood cultures, or radiologic evidence of infections | Confirmed HIV positivity within 4 weeks of enrollment | Pregnant or breastfeeding
prior_therapies: Progressed after prior conventional therapy; At least 2 weeks since last targeted agent, chemotherapy, or radiation before PBMC collection; At least 6 weeks since completion of nitrosourea-containing chemotherapy before study treatment; At least 23 days since completion of temozolomide before study treatment; At least 4 weeks since completion of other non-nitrosourea cytotoxic chemotherapy before study treatment; If most recent treatment was a targeted agent only and toxicities resolved, at least 2 weeks since last dose before study treatment; At least 4 weeks since last bevacizumab dose before starting study treatment; Second-line radiation therapy completed at least 4 weeks prior to surgery/biopsy/catheter placement
reasoning: The patient is 40 years old, which is outside the trial's age range of 4–25 years, constituting a hard exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 40 years; Male; Recurrent glioblastoma; IDH wildtype; Status post gross total resection; Completed radiation with concurrent temozolomide and adjuvant temozolomide; ECOG 1; No other medical issues
patient_prior_therapies: Gross total resection; Adjuvant radiation with concurrent temozolomide; Adjuvant temozolomide
judge_comment: Age is a hard exclusion: the trial allows ages 4–25, while the patient is 40. This alone mandates an F per the rubric. Other factors need not be considered.

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 8-year-old female with PMM2-CDG (Congenital Disorder of Glycosylation). She has confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2 and exhibits moderate cerebellar dysfunction with a recent ICARS score of 35. Her family is highly motivated for research participation.
trial_title: PEARL (PrEnAtal Enzyme Replacement Therapy for Lysosomal Storage Disorders)
diseases_targeted: Gaucher Disease, Type 2; Gaucher Disease, Type 3; Mucopolysaccharidosis I; Mucopolysaccharidosis II; Mucopolysaccharidosis IVA; Mucopolysaccharidosis VI; Mucopolysaccharidosis VII; Pompe Disease (infantile-onset); Wolman Disease
inclusion_criteria: Fetus at 18 0/7 to 34 6/7 weeks gestation | Confirmed in utero diagnosis of one of the 8 lysosomal storage disorders by genetic or enzymatic testing on prenatal samples (e.g., CVS, amniocentesis, cordocentesis, cell-free fetal DNA) | Pregnant woman age 18 to 50 years carrying the affected fetus | Ability to provide written informed consent
exclusion_criteria: Fetal severe structural anomaly | Fetal additional pathogenic genetic variant unrelated to the LSD with significant risk of morbidity or mortality | Maternal inability to complete the procedure due to body habitus or placental location | Maternal significant cardiopulmonary disease | Maternal mirror syndrome | Maternal end-organ failure | Maternal altered mental status | Placental abruption | Active preterm labor | Preterm premature rupture of membranes | Maternal therapeutic anticoagulation within 24 hours prior to or following the intervention
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: PMM2-CDG is not among the trial’s lysosomal storage disorders. Additionally, the trial enrolls pregnant women (18–50 years) with affected fetuses, whereas the patient is an 8-year-old child.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of PMM2-CDG; Confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2; ICARS score 35 (moderate cerebellar dysfunction); Age 8 years
judge_comment: Correct: The trial targets different diseases and requires a pregnant woman (18–50 years), while the patient is an 8-year-old with PMM2-CDG. Disease mismatch and age window conflict are hard exclusions → F.

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: Randomized Phase II Study of Platinum-Taxane-Cetrelimab Induction Followed by Niraparib Plus or Minus Cetrelimab Maintenance in Men With Aggressive Variant Prostate Cancers
diseases_targeted: Aggressive Variant Prostate Carcinoma; Castration-Resistant Prostate Carcinoma; Metastatic Prostate Carcinoma; Metastatic Prostate Neuroendocrine Carcinoma; Metastatic Prostate Small Cell Carcinoma; Stage IV Prostate Cancer
inclusion_criteria: Histologically or cytologically confirmed prostate carcinoma | Metastatic disease documented on imaging (bone scan, CT and/or MRI) | Meets at least one aggressive variant prostate carcinoma (AVPC) criterion | Histologically proven small cell (neuroendocrine) prostate carcinoma (AVPC criterion) | Exclusive visceral metastases (AVPC criterion) | Predominantly lytic bone metastases by x-ray or CT (AVPC criterion) | Bulky (>= 5 cm) lymphadenopathy or high-grade tumor mass in prostate/pelvis (AVPC criterion) | Low PSA (<= 10 ng/mL) at initial presentation or at symptomatic progression in the castrate-setting plus high-volume (>= 20) bone metastases (AVPC criterion) | Elevated LDH (>= 2 x ULN) or elevated CEA (>= 2 x ULN) without other etiologies (AVPC criterion) | Short interval (<= 180 days) to castration-resistant progression after initiation of hormonal therapy (AVPC criterion) | Loss or mutation in at least 2 of TP53, RB1, and PTEN by CLIA-certified testing, IHC and/or DNA sequencing (AVPC criterion) | Castration-resistant progression per RECIST without PSA rising to >= 1.0 ng/mL per PCWG3 (AVPC criterion) | Documented progressive disease by PSA progression (3 measurements >= 7 days apart with last >= 1.0 ng/mL), or new/increasing measurable disease (RECIST), or >= 2 new bone lesions (PCWG3), or increasing symptoms attributed to progression | Surgically or medically castrated with baseline testosterone <= 50 ng/dL | ECOG performance status <= 2 | Hemoglobin >= 10.0 g/dL (>= 8 g/dL if due to marrow infiltration) | Absolute neutrophil count (ANC) >= 1.5 x 10^9/L (>= 1.0 x 10^9/L if due to marrow infiltration) | White blood cells (WBC) > 3 x 10^9/L (> 2 x 10^9/L if due to marrow infiltration) | Platelet count >= 100 x 10^9/L (>= 50 x 10^9/L if due to marrow infiltration) | Total bilirubin <= 1.5 x ULN (except Gilbert syndrome) | AST and ALT <= 2.5 x ULN (<= 5 x ULN with liver metastases) | Calculated creatinine clearance (Cockcroft-Gault) >= 30 mL/min | No features suggestive of MDS/AML on peripheral blood smear | Able to swallow study drugs whole (tablet/capsule)
exclusion_criteria: Any prior treatment for CRPC with carboplatin, cisplatin, cabazitaxel, a PARP inhibitor, or an anti-PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitor | More than one prior line of chemotherapy | Unresolved toxicity from prior therapy > CTCAE grade 2 (except allowed ongoing LHRH therapy, bisphosphonates, or RANK ligand inhibitors) | Any unresolved CTCAE grade >= 2 toxicity from previous anti-cancer therapy (irreversible toxicities not expected to be exacerbated may be allowed) | History or current diagnosis of myelodysplastic syndrome or acute myeloid leukemia | Active uncontrolled infection | Active or symptomatic viral hepatitis or chronic liver disease | History of pneumonitis or extensive bilateral non-malignant lung disease | Another malignancy with >= 30% probability of recurrence within 24 months (except adequately treated non-melanoma skin cancer, curatively treated in-situ cervical cancer, or Ta urothelial carcinoma) | Serious underlying medical or psychiatric condition that would make study drug hazardous or confound adverse event interpretation (e.g., uncontrolled ventricular arrhythmia, recent myocardial infarction, superior vena cava syndrome, uncontrolled seizures, history of allogeneic transplant, primary immunodeficiency) | Unable to swallow oral medication or gastrointestinal disorders likely to interfere with absorption | Symptomatic uncontrolled brain metastases or spinal cord compression | Known hypersensitivity to niraparib, carboplatin, cabazitaxel, or anti-PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitors | Current or prior use of systemic immunosuppressive medication within 28 days before first cetrelimab dose (with specified corticosteroid exceptions) | Active or prior documented autoimmune or inflammatory disorders requiring systemic therapy (with specified exceptions such as vitiligo, alopecia, controlled hypothyroidism, certain inactive diseases, or celiac disease controlled by diet) | Receipt of live attenuated vaccine within 30 days prior to cetrelimab | Compulsory detention for treatment of psychiatric or physical illness
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: this trial enrolls men with metastatic/aggressive variant prostate cancer, while the patient has metastatic urothelial carcinoma.
patient_inclusion_criteria: (none)
judge_comment: The trial targets prostate cancers only, while the patient has metastatic urothelial carcinoma. This is a disease mismatch, a hard exclusion per the rubric, so grade F is correct.

He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
