judge_comment: Correctly applied hard exclusion: the trial targets prostate cancer, while the patient has metastatic NSCLC. Disease mismatch mandates an F per rubric.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
trial_title: A Phase II/III, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Study of Tiragolumab in Combination With Atezolizumab Plus Pemetrexed and Carboplatin/Cisplatin Versus Pembrolizumab Plus Pemetrexed and Carboplatin/Cisplatin in Patients With Previously Untreated Advanced Non-Squamous Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer
diseases_targeted: Non-Squamous Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (metastatic or unresectable)
inclusion_criteria: ECOG performance status 0–1 | Histologically or cytologically documented locally advanced unresectable or metastatic non-squamous NSCLC not eligible for curative surgery and/or definitive chemoradiotherapy | No prior systemic treatment for metastatic non-squamous NSCLC | Known tumor PD-L1 status | Measurable disease per RECIST v1.1 | Life expectancy >= 12 weeks | Adequate hematologic and end-organ function | Negative HIV test at screening | Serology negative for active hepatitis B virus or active hepatitis C virus at screening
exclusion_criteria: EGFR sensitizing mutations or ALK fusion oncogene | Pulmonary lymphoepithelioma-like carcinoma subtype of NSCLC | Symptomatic, untreated, or actively progressing CNS metastases | Active or history of autoimmune disease or immune deficiency | History of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, organizing pneumonia, drug-induced pneumonitis, idiopathic pneumonitis, or evidence of active pneumonitis | History of malignancy other than NSCLC within 5 years prior to randomization, except malignancies with negligible risk of metastasis or death | Severe infection within 4 weeks prior to initiation of study treatment or any active infection that could impact patient safety | Treatment with investigational therapy within 28 days prior to initiation of study treatment | Prior treatment with CD137 agonists or immune checkpoint blockade therapies including anti-CTLA-4, anti-TIGIT, anti-PD-1, or anti-PD-L1 antibodies | Treatment with systemic immunostimulatory agents within 4 weeks or 5 half-lives (whichever is longer) prior to initiation of study treatment | Treatment with systemic immunosuppressive medication within 2 weeks prior to initiation of study treatment or anticipated need for systemic immunosuppressive medication during study treatment | Known allergy or hypersensitivity or other contraindication to any component of the chemotherapy regimen | Pregnant or breastfeeding | Known targetable ROS1 or BRAF V600E genomic aberration
prior_therapies: No prior systemic treatment for metastatic non-squamous NSCLC; Investigational therapy washout >= 28 days
reasoning: The trial explicitly excludes patients with EGFR-sensitizing mutations and requires no prior systemic therapy for metastatic NSCLC; the patient has an EGFR exon 19 deletion and has received osimertinib.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Non-small cell lung cancer; De novo metastatic disease (bone, liver); EGFR exon 19 deletion; ECOG 0; Age 40 years
judge_comment: Hard exclusion applies: the trial excludes EGFR-sensitizing mutations, and the patient has an EGFR exon 19 deletion. The prior systemic therapy (osimertinib) would also conflict with the trial’s “no prior systemic treatment for metastatic NSCLC” requirement. Thus F is correct.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
trial_title: A Phase 2 Randomized Study of Relatlimab Plus Nivolumab in Combination With Chemotherapy vs. Nivolumab in Combination With Chemotherapy as First Line Treatment for Participants With Stage IV or Recurrent Non-small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC)
diseases_targeted: Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (metastatic or recurrent)
inclusion_criteria: Histologically confirmed non-small cell lung cancer (squamous or non-squamous) that is stage IVA/IVB or recurrent after multimodal therapy for locally advanced disease. | ECOG performance status <=1 at screening and prior to randomization. | Measurable disease by CT or MRI per RECIST 1.1. | No prior systemic anti-cancer treatment given as primary therapy for advanced or metastatic disease (including EGFR or ALK inhibitors).
exclusion_criteria: EGFR, ALK, ROS1, or BRAF V600E mutations that are sensitive to available targeted therapy. | Untreated central nervous system metastases. | Leptomeningeal metastases. | Concurrent malignancy requiring treatment or prior malignancy active within 2 years before randomization. | Prior treatment with PD-1, PD-L1, PD-L2, CTLA-4, or other T-cell co-stimulation/checkpoint pathway-targeting agents.
prior_therapies: No prior systemic therapy for advanced or metastatic disease.
reasoning: The trial explicitly excludes EGFR-mutant NSCLC sensitive to targeted therapy, and the patient has an EGFR exon 19 deletion. It also requires no prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease (including EGFR inhibitors), but the patient previously received osimertinib.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Non-small cell lung cancer; De novo metastatic disease (bone, liver); EGFR exon 19 deletion; ECOG 0; Age 40 years
judge_comment: Explicit exclusions apply: trial excludes EGFR mutation sensitive to targeted therapy and requires no prior systemic therapy for advanced disease. Patient has EGFR exon 19 deletion and prior osimertinib. Hard exclusion → F. Grader applied rubric correctly.

question_text: A 55-year-old female has severe, seropositive rheumatoid arthritis refractory to methotrexate and two prior biologic agents (adalimumab and tocilizumab). She has active disease with a DAS28 score of 5.5. Critically, she has a history of treated Hepatitis B (HBsAg negative, anti-HBc positive) and moderate chronic kidney disease with an eGFR of 45 mL/min/1.73m². What are trial options for her?
trial_title: A Retrospectively Enrolled and Prospectively Followed, Post-market, Multi-center Evaluation of the Clinical Outcomes of the Triathlon All-Polyethylene Tibia
inclusion_criteria: Implanted with Triathlon All-Polyethylene Tibia with compatible Stryker femoral and patellar components; no pending revision or removal | Age >= 18 years at time of device implantation | Non-pregnant
exclusion_criteria: Active or suspected latent infection in or around the affected knee at time of implantation | Distant foci of infection that could cause hematogenous spread to the implant site at time of implantation | Skeletally immature at time of device implantation | Mental or neuromuscular disorder creating unacceptable risk of prosthesis instability, fixation failure, or postoperative complications | Bone stock compromised by disease, infection, or prior implantation that cannot provide adequate support and/or fixation | Severe knee instability secondary to absent collateral ligament integrity and function | Immunologically suppressed or receiving steroids in excess of normal physiological requirements at the time of surgery (e.g., > 30 days)
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets patients with knee arthritis who have received a specific knee implant, while the patient has rheumatoid arthritis and no indication of qualifying implant. This fails the trial’s disease/cohort requirements.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 55 years; Female; Seropositive rheumatoid arthritis; Active disease (DAS28 5.5)
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to methotrexate; Prior adalimumab; Prior tocilizumab; Failed two prior biologic agents
judge_comment: Correct: The trial targets knee arthritis patients with a specific knee implant cohort, while the patient’s condition is rheumatoid arthritis. Per rubric, this is a disease mismatch → hard exclusion → F. The implant requirement is also unmet/unknown but not needed to justify F since disease mismatch suffices.

question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.
trial_title: Phase II Clinical Trial to Evaluate the Safety and Feasibility of Senolytic Therapy in Alzheimer's Disease
diseases_targeted: Alzheimer Disease (early stage); Mild Cognitive Impairment (amnestic)
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 60 years | Amnestic mild cognitive impairment or early Alzheimer's disease | Elevated cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) tau protein | Tau PET positive | Total cholesterol < 240 mg/dL | HbA1c <= 7% | PT/PTT/INR within normal limits
exclusion_criteria: Body mass index > 40 kg/m2 | Average QTcF at screening >= 450 msec in males or >= 460 msec in females | MRI contraindications (e.g., claustrophobia, ferromagnetic implants, cardiac pacemaker) | Pregnancy or possible pregnancy | Significant neurologic disease other than prodromal or early Alzheimer's disease (e.g., Parkinson's disease, Huntington's disease, normal pressure hydrocephalus, brain tumor, progressive supranuclear palsy, seizure disorder, subdural hematoma, multiple sclerosis, or significant head trauma with persistent deficits or structural brain abnormalities) | Current or history of alcohol or substance abuse or dependence within the past 2 years | Current suicidality or suicidal ideation | Uncontrolled diabetes (HbA1c > 7% or current use of insulin or sulfonylureas) | Poorly controlled blood pressure: systolic > 160 mmHg or diastolic > 90 mmHg | eGFR < 10 mL/min/1.73 m2 | Myocardial infarction, angina, stroke, or transient ischemic attack within the past 6 months | Chronic heart failure | Significant liver disease with total bilirubin > 2 x ULN | Inability to tolerate oral medication | Use of medications that are sensitive substrates or have a narrow therapeutic range for CYP3A4, CYP2C8, CYP2C9, or CYP2D6, or strong inhibitors or inducers of CYP3A4 | Current use of drugs that induce cellular senescence (alkylating agents, anthracyclines, platinums, other chemotherapy) | Therapeutic-dose anticoagulation (e.g., warfarin, heparin, low molecular weight heparin, factor Xa inhibitors) unless can be held for 2 days prior to lumbar puncture with prescriber approval | Use of H2 antagonists or proton pump inhibitors unable or unwilling to hold for at least 2 days prior to and during each 2-day dosing course | Co-enrollment in another ADRD study with a potentially disease-modifying intervention or study drug affecting senescent cells (eligible after washout >= 6 months from last dose to screening) | Use of anti-amyloid therapies (e.g., aducanumab, lecanemab) | Any condition that, in the Investigator's judgment, would put the subject at risk or preclude successful completion of the trial
prior_therapies: Stable dose (>= 3 months) of FDA-approved Alzheimer's disease medications (e.g., donepezil, rivastigmine, galantamine) permitted; Prior disease-modifying ADRD investigational therapy allowed with washout >= 6 months before screening
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial enrolls amnestic MCI or early Alzheimer’s disease, whereas the patient has moderate-stage dementia without a confirmed Alzheimer’s diagnosis (amyloid PET/CSF negative). The trial also requires tau PET positivity and early-stage disease, which are not met.
patient_biomarkers: Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 68 years; Male; Two-year history of progressive cognitive decline; MMSE score 19; Moderate-stage dementia; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
judge_comment: Correct F: The patient has moderate-stage dementia without a specified Alzheimer’s diagnosis, while the trial only enrolls amnestic MCI or early Alzheimer’s disease. That is a disease mismatch hard exclusion. Age/sex are fine; tau PET status is unknown and shouldn’t drive F, but the disease/stage mismatch already triggers F.

question_text: What are trial options for a 66 year old male with hx hypertension, afib, T2DM and mCRPC, now progressing on enzalutamide? He has been on Lupron+Zytiga for 3 years, with new liver and bone metastases which are all PSMA PET avid. He’s tolerated therapy well overall except for grade 2 fatigue.
trial_title: Bipolar Androgen Therapy (BAT) and Radium-223 (RAD) in Metastatic Castration-resistant Prostate Cancer (mCRPC) (BAT-RAD Study)
inclusion_criteria: Histologically confirmed prostate adenocarcinoma; if mixed histology, >50% adenocarcinoma. | Bone metastases on Technetium-99m bone scan within 2 months of screening. | Castrate-resistant prostate cancer with testosterone <= 50 ng/dL and evidence of progression by PSA or new lesions. | PSA progression defined by two rising values >= 2 ng/mL at least 7 days apart or new lesions on imaging. | Serum PSA >= 2.0 ng/mL. | On bone health agents (zoledronic acid or denosumab) for >= 4 weeks before enrollment and continued during study. | ECOG performance status <= 1. | Asymptomatic or minimally symptomatic disease (no opioids). | Prior treatment with <= 1 novel AR-targeted drug permitted (abiraterone, enzalutamide, darolutamide, apalutamide). | Prior first-generation antiandrogens (bicalutamide, nilutamide) permitted. | Prior chemotherapy for hormone-sensitive prostate cancer allowed if given >= 12 months prior to entry. | Adequate bone marrow, renal, and liver function (ANC > 1,000/µL; Platelets > 100,000/µL; Hemoglobin >= 9 g/dL; AST/ALT <= 1 x ULN; Total bilirubin <= 1 x ULN). | No other malignancy within 5 years except adequately treated basal or squamous cell skin cancer. | Availability of tumor tissue for genomic analysis (archival or new biopsy).
exclusion_criteria: Known visceral metastasis (lung, liver, brain). | Spinal cord compression, imminent long bone fracture, or conditions likely to require radiation or steroids for pain during active phase. | Previous treatment with chemotherapy for mCRPC, or any chemotherapy within 12 months prior to registration (adjuvant or hormone-sensitive chemo allowed if completed > 6 months before registration). | Radiation therapy (external beam or brachytherapy) within 28 days prior to registration. | Systemic bone-seeking radiopharmaceuticals (strontium-89, samarium-153, rhenium-186, rhenium-188) within the previous 24 weeks. | Use of strong opioid analgesics for cancer-related pain (e.g., oxycodone, morphine, methadone); weak opioids like codeine or tramadol permitted. | Investigational drug use within 4 weeks of treatment. | Intact prostate with urinary obstructive symptoms (including symptomatic BPH). | Current warfarin anticoagulation (other anticoagulants such as rivaroxaban, dabigatran, apixaban permitted). | Symptomatic nodal disease (scrotal, penile, or leg edema). | Serious uncontrolled medical disorder or active infection posing poor medical risk (e.g., uncontrolled diabetes, heart failure, COPD, IBD, Paget's disease, ventricular arrhythmia, recent MI within 12 months, thromboembolic events, or psychiatric disorder interfering with consent). | Disease extent or sites posing risk from testosterone therapy (e.g., femoral metastases with fracture risk, severe extensive spinal metastases with cord compression risk); low-volume visceral metastasis permitted at investigator discretion if bone disease predominant.
prior_therapies: Bone health agents (zoledronic acid or denosumab) required for >= 4 weeks prior to enrollment and continued during study.; <= 1 prior novel AR-targeted therapy allowed (abiraterone, enzalutamide, darolutamide, apalutamide).; Prior first-generation antiandrogens permitted (bicalutamide, nilutamide).; Prior chemotherapy for hormone-sensitive prostate cancer allowed if completed >= 12 months before entry.
reasoning: The trial excludes patients with known visceral metastases (lung, liver, brain), and the patient has liver metastases. In addition, the study allows ≤1 prior novel AR-targeted therapy, whereas the patient has received both abiraterone and enzalutamide.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 66 years; Male sex; Metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer; Progression on enzalutamide; PSMA PET avid liver and bone metastases
patient_prior_therapies: Progression on enzalutamide; Prior abiraterone (Zytiga) with leuprolide (Lupron) for 3 years
judge_comment: F is not justified as a hard exclusion. Although the trial lists visceral metastases as excluded, it also permits low-volume visceral disease at investigator discretion; volume predominance is unknown, so this is not a definitive hard exclusion. However, the patient has received two novel AR-targeted therapies while the trial permits ≤1, which is a clear line/prior soft mismatch. Disease and stage match. Therefore grade should be D, not F.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: Effectiveness of Tele-rheumatology for Delivering High Quality Rheumatology Care During the COVID-19 Crisis
inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of rheumatic disease (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus)
exclusion_criteria: Unstable rheumatic disease requiring in-person visits (e.g., recent diagnosis of severe lupus nephritis) | Expected need for in-office procedures (e.g., joint injection) | Lack of access to a phone
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets rheumatic diseases, while the patient has Crohn's disease. The inclusion explicitly requires a rheumatic disease diagnosis, so the patient is ineligible.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe Crohn's disease; Fistulizing disease; CDAI score 350; Active perianal fistula with draining seton in place
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab
judge_comment: Disease mismatch is a hard exclusion. The trial requires a rheumatic disease diagnosis, while the patient has Crohn’s disease with no rheumatic diagnosis provided. The grader correctly assigned F based on the rubric.

question_text: What are trial options for a 3-month-old male infant with genetically confirmed Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency? He presented on day 3 of life with a severe hyperammonemic crisis (ammonia 720 μmol/L) and is now stable on a regimen of dietary protein restriction and ammonia scavengers.
trial_title: Study of Pyridoxal 5'-Phosphate for the Treatment of Patients With PNPO Deficiency
inclusion_criteria: Confirmed PNPO deficiency by genetic analysis | Seizures typically controlled on oral pyridoxal phosphate with multiple daily doses | On pyridoxal phosphate therapy for >=30 days prior to enrollment | Previous failed treatment on pyridoxine allowed; off pyridoxine for >=24 hours
exclusion_criteria: Any condition or abnormality that may compromise patient safety or ability to comply with study procedures | Known or suspected allergy to pyridoxal phosphate or related drugs | Participation in an interventional clinical research study within 4 weeks prior to screening or prior enrollment in this study
prior_therapies: On pyridoxal phosphate therapy for >=30 days before enrollment; Prior pyridoxine allowed with washout >=24 hours
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets PNPO deficiency and requires genetic confirmation of PNPO deficiency, while the patient has OTC deficiency. This constitutes a hard exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Genetically confirmed ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency; History of severe neonatal hyperammonemic crisis; Currently clinically stable on therapy; Male; Age 3 months
judge_comment: Disease mismatch: trial targets PNPO deficiency with required genetic confirmation, while patient has OTC deficiency. This is a hard exclusion per rubric; F is correct.

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 8-year-old female with PMM2-CDG (Congenital Disorder of Glycosylation). She has confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2 and exhibits moderate cerebellar dysfunction with a recent ICARS score of 35. Her family is highly motivated for research participation.
trial_title: Phase 1/2 Open-Label, Multicenter Study to Assess the Safety, Tolerability and Efficacy of a Single Dose of PBGM01 Delivered Into the Cisterna Magna of Pediatric Type 1 (Early Onset) and Type 2a (Late Onset) Infantile GM1 Gangliosidosis
diseases_targeted: GM1 Gangliosidosis, Type I; GM1 Gangliosidosis, Type 2
inclusion_criteria: Documented GM1 gangliosidosis with 2 pathogenic GLB1 mutations and beta-galactosidase enzyme deficiency | Type 1 (early onset infantile): age >= 1 month and < 12 months at enrollment; symptom onset < 6 months; specified minimum developmental milestones remaining | Type 2a (late onset infantile): age >= 6 months and <= 24 months at enrollment; symptom onset between 6 and 18 months; specified minimum developmental milestones remaining including ability to sit independently per WHO-MGRS (sit unsupported with head erect for >= 10 seconds)
exclusion_criteria: Clinically significant neurocognitive deficit not attributable to GM1 gangliosidosis or that may confound study results | Acute illness requiring hospitalization within 30 days prior to enrollment | History of ventilation-assisted respiratory support or need for tracheostomy; chronic invasive or noninvasive mechanical ventilation | Intractable seizures or uncontrolled epilepsy, including status epilepticus or seizures requiring hospitalization within 30 days prior to dosing | Contraindication to intra-cisterna magna administration, fluoroscopic imaging, or anesthesia, or conditions increasing ICM procedure risk (e.g., mass effect/increased intracranial pressure, posterior fossa/foramen magnum space-occupying lesion, aberrant vascular or venous anatomy, Chiari malformation) | Contraindication to MRI or lumbar puncture | Prior gene therapy | Use of miglustat within 48 hours prior to dosing; miglustat prohibited during study | Use of enzyme replacement therapy or other investigational therapy within 5 half-lives prior to dosing; enzyme replacement prohibited during study | Receipt of a vaccine within 14 days prior to dosing or scheduled vaccine within 30 days after dosing | eGFR < 30 mL/min based on creatinine | Coagulopathy: INR > 1.5 or aPTT > 40 seconds | Platelet count < 100,000/µL | AST > 3 x ULN or ALT > 3 x ULN | Total bilirubin > 1.5 x ULN | Cardiomyopathy (screening troponin above ULN) | Peripheral neuropathy | Medical conditions or abnormal labs/vital signs increasing risk from ICM injection, anesthesia, fluoroscopy, LP, and/or MRI (e.g., temperature > 38°C, oxygen saturation < 95% on room air or baseline oxygen requirement, abnormal heart or respiratory rate for age, abnormal blood pressure for age, evidence of infection) | Any condition that would put the subject at undue risk during the procedure or interfere with evaluation of PBGM01 or interpretation of safety or results
prior_therapies: Discontinue miglustat >= 48 hours before dosing; prohibited during study; No enzyme replacement therapy or other investigational therapy within 5 half-lives before dosing; enzyme replacement prohibited during study; No vaccines within 14 days before dosing and none scheduled within 30 days after dosing
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets GM1 gangliosidosis with GLB1 mutations, while the patient has PMM2-CDG with PMM2 variants. Age mismatch: trial age is 1–24 months, and the patient is 8 years old.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of PMM2-CDG; Confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2; ICARS score 35 (moderate cerebellar dysfunction); Age 8 years
judge_comment: Correct: There is a hard disease mismatch (trial is for GM1 gangliosidosis with GLB1 mutations; patient has PMM2-CDG) and an age hard exclusion (trial 1–24 months vs patient 8 years). Any one hard exclusion → F.

question_text: What are trial options for a 3-month-old male infant with genetically confirmed Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency? He presented on day 3 of life with a severe hyperammonemic crisis (ammonia 720 μmol/L) and is now stable on a regimen of dietary protein restriction and ammonia scavengers.
trial_title: A Multi-Center, Single-Dose and Repeat-Dose Over Eight Weeks, Sequential Cohort Study to Evaluate Safety and Tolerability as Well as Pharmacokinetics of Two Different Doses of Alpha1-Proteinase Inhibitor Subcutaneous (Human) 15% Administered Subcutaneously in Subjects With Alpha1-Antitrypsin Deficiency
inclusion_criteria: Congenital alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency with allelic combination ZZ, SZ, Z(null), (null)(null), S(null), or at-risk alleles (per Medical Monitor). | Pre-augmentation serum alpha-1 antitrypsin level <11 μM (80 mg/dL by radial immunodiffusion or 50 mg/dL by nephelometry). | May be naive to augmentation or previously/currently on alpha1-PI augmentation therapy; if currently treated, must discontinue for >=25 days before Week 1 and remain off other alpha1-PI during the study. | Post-bronchodilator FEV1 >=30% and <80% predicted and FEV1/FVC <70% (GOLD stage II or III).
exclusion_criteria: Moderate or severe COPD exacerbation within 4 weeks before Week 1. | History of lung or liver transplant. | Any lung surgery within the past 2 years (excluding lung biopsy). | Severe concomitant disease (e.g., congestive heart failure, clinically significant pulmonary fibrosis, malignant disease except non-melanoma skin cancer, history of acute hypersensitivity pneumonitis reaction, or current chronic hypersensitivity pneumonitis). | Pregnant or breastfeeding, or if of child-bearing potential, unwilling to use highly effective contraception during the study. | Smoked within the past 6 months or positive urine cotinine at screening due to smoking. | Participation in another investigational product study within 1 month prior to Week 1. | History of anaphylaxis or severe systemic reaction to plasma-derived alpha1-PI or other blood products. | Use of systemic steroids above a stable dose equivalent to >5 mg/day prednisone within 4 weeks prior to Week 1. | Use of systemic or aerosolized antibiotics for a chronic COPD exacerbation within 4 weeks prior to Week 1. | Known selective or severe IgA deficiency.
prior_therapies: Prior or current alpha1-proteinase inhibitor augmentation therapy allowed with washout >=25 days before Week 1; no other alpha1-PI during study participation.
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, not OTC deficiency. Additionally, the patient is 3 months old (trial requires 18–80 years) and does not have the required A1AT-deficiency genotypes.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Genetically confirmed ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency; History of severe neonatal hyperammonemic crisis; Currently clinically stable on therapy; Male; Age 3 months
judge_comment: Correct: There is a hard disease mismatch (OTC deficiency vs A1AT deficiency), which alone mandates F. Additionally, the patient is 3 months old vs trial minimum 18 years, another hard exclusion. The extra genotype note wasn’t needed but doesn’t affect the grade.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
trial_title: A Phase 3, Multicenter, Randomized, Double-Blind Study of MK-7684 With Pembrolizumab as a Coformulation (MK-7684A) Versus Pembrolizumab Monotherapy as First Line Treatment for Participants With PD-L1 Positive Metastatic Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer
inclusion_criteria: Histologically or cytologically confirmed Stage IV (M1a, M1b, or M1c) non-small cell lung cancer | Measurable disease per RECIST 1.1 | EGFR/ALK/ROS1-directed therapy not indicated; absence of ALK and ROS1 gene rearrangements | PD-L1 expression >=1% by IHC at central laboratory | ECOG performance status 0–1 | Life expectancy >=3 months | Adequate organ function
exclusion_criteria: Prior systemic chemotherapy or targeted/biologic therapy for metastatic NSCLC | Prior therapy with PD-1, PD-L1, or PD-L2 agents or agents targeting CTLA-4, OX-40, or CD137 | Previous treatment with an agent targeting the TIGIT pathway | Radiotherapy within 2 weeks of start of study intervention (1-week washout permitted for <=2 weeks of palliative non-CNS radiation) | Live or live-attenuated vaccine within 30 days prior to first dose (investigational vaccines not allowed) | Participation in another investigational agent study or investigational device use within 4 weeks prior to first dose | Active or untreated CNS metastases or carcinomatous meningitis (treated, stable >=4 weeks without steroids >=14 days allowed) | Severe hypersensitivity (>=Grade 3) to pembrolizumab/vibostolimab, pembrolizumab, or excipients | Active autoimmune disease requiring systemic treatment within the past 2 years (replacement therapy allowed) | Diagnosis of immunodeficiency or chronic systemic steroids >10 mg prednisone equivalent daily or other immunosuppressive therapy within 7 days before first dose | History of non-infectious pneumonitis requiring steroids or current pneumonitis | Known interstitial lung disease | Active infection requiring systemic therapy | Known HIV infection | Known hepatitis B infection or active hepatitis C infection | Any condition, therapy, or laboratory abnormality preventing receipt of first-line platinum-doublet chemotherapy or that may confound results per investigator | Psychiatric or substance abuse disorder that would interfere with study requirements
prior_therapies: No prior systemic therapy for metastatic NSCLC; Adjuvant/neoadjuvant or chemoradiation for nonmetastatic NSCLC allowed if completed >=6 months before metastatic diagnosis; Radiotherapy washout >=2 weeks (>=1 week for palliative non-CNS radiation <=2 weeks); Investigational agent/device washout >=4 weeks; Live vaccine washout >=30 days
reasoning: The trial requires no prior systemic therapy for metastatic NSCLC and that EGFR-directed therapy not be indicated, but the patient has an EGFR exon 19 deletion (EGFR therapy indicated) and has received osimertinib for metastatic disease.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Non-small cell lung cancer; De novo metastatic disease (bone, liver); EGFR exon 19 deletion; ECOG 0; Age 40 years
judge_comment: Hard exclusions apply: (1) Trial requires EGFR-directed therapy not indicated; patient has EGFR exon 19 deletion, so fails a required biomarker criterion. (2) Trial excludes any prior systemic therapy for metastatic NSCLC; patient has prior osimertinib in the metastatic setting. Thus F is correct and the grader’s reasoning aligns with the rubric.

question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.
trial_title: Maximizing trEatment of Neurological Dysfunction Using INtravenous Guanfacine Study
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Admitted to an ICU | Receiving treatment for respiratory failure and/or shock (e.g., mechanical ventilation, NIPPV, ECMO, optiflow, vasopressors, IABP)
exclusion_criteria: Allergy to guanfacine, clonidine, or dexmedetomidine | Home antipsychotic use requiring continuation in the hospital | Second- or third-degree heart block, or persistent bradycardia < 50 beats/min requiring intervention (unless treated with a pacemaker) | Expected death within 24 hours of enrollment | Acute or subacute neurologic deficit causing inability to live independently after discharge (e.g., stroke, intracranial hemorrhage, cranial trauma, intracranial malignancy, anoxic brain injury, cerebral edema) | Dementia or other chronic neurologic disease/disorder causing inability to live independently at baseline | Active substance abuse | Psychotic disorder | Blindness or deafness preventing outcome assessments | Pregnancy or breastfeeding | Cardiac surgery within the current hospitalization
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets delirium in ICU patients, while the patient has chronic dementia.
patient_biomarkers: Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 68 years; Male; Two-year history of progressive cognitive decline; MMSE score 19; Moderate-stage dementia; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
judge_comment: Correct: The trial targets delirium (ICU setting), while the patient has dementia. This is a disease mismatch, which is a hard exclusion per the rubric, warranting an F. The grader’s reasoning aligns with the rubric.

question_text: 40 year old man with recurrent glioblastoma. Diagnosed 1 year ago, underwent gross total resection with confirmation of GBM, IDH wildtype. Completed adjuvant radiation + concurrent temozolomide and then adjuvant temozolomide. Three months after completing adjuvant therapy, MRI shows recurrence. ECOG 1 and no other medical issues. What are trial options?
trial_title: Phase 2 Study of Intraventricular Omburtamab-based Radioimmunotherapy for Pediatric Patients With Recurrent Medulloblastoma and Ependymoma
inclusion_criteria: Recurrent, progressive, or refractory medulloblastoma with histologic verification (Stratum 1) | Recurrent, progressive, or refractory ependymoma with histologic verification (Stratum 2) | Evidence of disease by MRI (measurable or non-measurable) or diffuse leptomeningeal disease, or tumor cells in CSF (Stratum 1) | Tumor cells in CSF allowed with or without radiographic disease (Stratum 2) | Age < 22 years at enrollment/screening | Appropriate intraventricular access device (programmable VP shunt or Ommaya) required prior to radioimmunotherapy; willingness to place/modify device as needed | Prior craniospinal irradiation for medulloblastoma unless contraindicated or not in patient’s best interest; <= 2 prior recurrences or refractory disease (Stratum 1) | Prior focal or craniospinal irradiation for ependymoma unless contraindicated or declined (Stratum 2) | Recovery from prior myelosuppressive chemotherapy; last dose >= 21 days (>= 42 days if nitrosourea) | Recovery from prior biologic/investigational agent; last dose >= 7 days (longer if delayed AEs expected) | Recovery from prior monoclonal antibody or long half-life agents; last dose >= 21 days | Radiation washout: CSI/whole brain/TBI/>=50% pelvis or spine completed >= 24 weeks before enrollment; measurable target not irradiated within 12 weeks; focal RT to symptomatic metastases >= 14 days | Autologous stem cell transplant completed >= 3 months prior to enrollment (Stratum 1) | Neurologic deficits stable >= 1 week; seizure disorders controlled on non–enzyme-inducing anticonvulsants; no enzyme-inducing antiepileptics within 1 week | Karnofsky/Lansky >= 50% | Adequate organ function (ANC, platelets, hemoglobin, renal, hepatic, coagulation per protocol thresholds) | Hypertension well controlled (<= 95th percentile) on stable medication if applicable | HIV-infected patients on effective ART with undetectable viral load within 6 months eligible | Chronic HBV with undetectable viral load on suppressive therapy eligible | HCV infection cured or on treatment with undetectable viral load eligible | Stable or decreasing dexamethasone dose for >= 7 days prior to enrollment allowed | Off colony-stimulating factors >= 1 week (>= 2 weeks for pegfilgrastim) | Use of effective contraception during study and specified period after therapy | Ependymoma: B7-H3 (CD276) positive by CLIA-certified IHC (Stratum 2)
exclusion_criteria: Pregnancy | Breastfeeding (unless agrees not to breastfeed) | Prior combination therapy with bevacizumab, irinotecan, and temozolomide (Stratum 1) | Serious or non-healing wound, ulcer, or bone fracture | History of abdominal fistula, gastrointestinal perforation, or intraabdominal abscess within 6 months | Known bleeding diathesis or coagulopathy | Significant vascular disease within 6 months (e.g., aortic aneurysm requiring repair, deep venous or arterial thrombosis) | Known thrombophilia (e.g., protein C/S deficiency, antithrombin III deficiency, Factor V Leiden, Factor II G20210A mutation, homocysteinemia, antiphospholipid antibody syndrome) | New CNS hemorrhage on baseline MRI within 14 days prior to enrollment | History within 6 months of stroke, myocardial infarction, transient ischemic attack, severe or unstable angina, peripheral vascular disease, or grade II or greater congestive heart failure | Serious and inadequately controlled cardiac arrhythmia | Hypersensitivity to Chinese hamster ovary cell products or other recombinant human antibodies | Current use of NSAIDs, clopidogrel, dipyridamole, or aspirin > 81 mg/day that cannot be discontinued | Clinically significant unrelated systemic illness that would compromise tolerance of therapy or study procedures | Prior or concurrent malignancy that may interfere with safety/efficacy assessment of the investigational regimen | Concurrent anti-cancer or investigational drug therapy | Use of strong or moderate CYP3A4/5 inducers or inhibitors, or CYP3A4/5 substrates with a narrow therapeutic index, that cannot be discontinued >= 7 days prior to enrollment | Use of prohibited herbal preparations (e.g., St. John's wort, kava, ephedra, ginkgo, DHEA, yohimbe, saw palmetto, black cohosh, ginseng) that cannot be stopped >= 7 days prior to enrollment | Inability or unwillingness to comply with study visits, procedures, or drug administration plan
prior_therapies: Progression after initial surgery, radiation therapy, or other therapies for ependymoma (Stratum 2); Prior craniospinal irradiation for medulloblastoma unless contraindicated or not in patient’s best interest (Stratum 1); Last myelosuppressive chemotherapy >= 21 days prior to enrollment (>= 42 days if prior nitrosourea); Last biologic or investigational anti-neoplastic agent >= 7 days prior to enrollment (longer if delayed AEs expected); Last monoclonal antibody or long half-life agent >= 21 days prior to enrollment; Radiation washout: CSI/whole brain/TBI/>=50% pelvis or spine completed >= 24 weeks before enrollment; Focal radiation to symptomatic metastatic disease completed >= 14 days before enrollment; Autologous stem cell transplant completed >= 3 months prior to enrollment (Stratum 1); Off colony-stimulating growth factors >= 1 week (>= 2 weeks for pegfilgrastim)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial is for recurrent medulloblastoma or ependymoma, not glioblastoma. Additionally, the trial limits age to <22 years, while the patient is 40.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 40 years; Male; Recurrent glioblastoma; IDH wildtype; Status post gross total resection; Completed radiation with concurrent temozolomide and adjuvant temozolomide; ECOG 1; No other medical issues
patient_prior_therapies: Gross total resection; Adjuvant radiation with concurrent temozolomide; Adjuvant temozolomide
judge_comment: There is a clear hard exclusion: disease mismatch (glioblastoma vs medulloblastoma/ependymoma). Additionally, the patient is 40 while the trial restricts to <22 years, another hard exclusion. Grade F is correct and the reasoning identifies the key factors.

question_text: What are trial options for a 66 year old male with hx hypertension, afib, T2DM and mCRPC, now progressing on enzalutamide? He has been on Lupron+Zytiga for 3 years, with new liver and bone metastases which are all PSMA PET avid. He’s tolerated therapy well overall except for grade 2 fatigue.
trial_title: Focal Radiation With Pulsed Systemic Therapy of Abiraterone, ADT, Lynparza Towards Castration Sensitive Oligometastatic Prostate Cancer (FAALCON): A Phase II, Single Arm, Single Institution Study
inclusion_criteria: Histologic or cytologic diagnosis of prostate adenocarcinoma | Prior radical prostatectomy or external beam radiation with curative intent to the prostate; if positive margins after prostatectomy, salvage or adjuvant radiation required | Newly diagnosed oligometastatic prostate cancer on molecular imaging (e.g., PSMA PET/CT or Axumin), with 1 to <=5 radiation treatment sites; each site up to 5 cm and may contain multiple lesions | No prior image-guided radiation to sites outside the prostate bed or pelvic lymph nodes (typically treated in salvage/adjuvant settings) | Post-prostatectomy: PSA >0.2 ng/mL confirmed >=4 weeks later with subsequent rise | After prior curative radiotherapy: meets Phoenix criteria for progression (nadir PSA + 2 ng/mL) | Medically fit for radiotherapy | All molecular positive disease sites can be safely treated with radiation per radiation oncologist | Candidate for androgen deprivation therapy and abiraterone per treating oncologist | Adequate organ and bone marrow function within 28 days before treatment per protocol | Prior ADT with or without second-generation androgen receptor inhibitors or abiraterone in the curative setting allowed if testosterone >150 ng/dL | ADT for metastatic disease allowed up to 4 weeks prior to registration; if prior curative ADT, testosterone recovery >150 ng/dL or >1 year since last curative ADT before recent ADT was resumed | ECOG <=1
exclusion_criteria: Pure small cell or pure neuroendocrine prostate cancer histology | Prior orchiectomy | Prior exposure to PARP inhibitors, docetaxel, or cabazitaxel | Another malignancy within the past 3 years requiring treatment (except superficial squamous skin cancer or carcinoma in situ of bladder or head and neck) | Life expectancy <=3 years | Known parenchymal brain metastasis | Symptoms of cord compression requiring immediate radiation | Myelodysplastic syndrome or acute myeloid leukemia, or features suggestive of MDS/AML | Severe hepatic impairment (Child-Pugh Class C) | Active hepatitis B or hepatitis C infection | Concurrent use of strong or moderate CYP3A inducers (specified agents); required washout 5 weeks for phenobarbital or enzalutamide, 3 weeks for others before starting olaparib | Concurrent use of strong or moderate CYP3A inhibitors (specified agents); required washout 2 weeks before starting olaparib | Major surgery within 2 weeks prior to starting study treatment or not recovered from effects of surgery | Myocardial infarction or arterial thrombotic events (e.g., stroke) within the past 6 months | Resting EKG indicating uncontrolled, potentially reversible cardiac condition (e.g., unstable ischemia, uncontrolled symptomatic arrhythmia) or QTcF >500 ms, or congenital long QT syndrome | Severe or unstable angina, uncontrolled atrial fibrillation, or other cardiac arrhythmia requiring therapy | Active New York Heart Association Class II–IV heart failure | History of congestive heart failure requires LVEF >=50% within 6 months | Planned or scheduled cardiac surgery or percutaneous coronary intervention | Prior revascularization procedure within the past 12 months | Uncontrolled pituitary or adrenal dysfunction | Active infection or medical condition that contraindicates prednisone use | Chronic medical condition requiring systemic corticosteroid >10 mg prednisone daily | Prior allogeneic bone marrow transplant or double umbilical cord blood transplant | Participation in another clinical study with an investigational product or device within 1 month of registration | Uncontrolled hypertension (systolic >=160 mmHg or diastolic >=95 mmHg), unless white coat hypertension documented with acceptable home readings | Known hypersensitivity to olaparib, abiraterone, planned ADT agents (e.g., leuprolide, goserelin, degarelix), their excipients, or related classes | Immunocompromised state | Serious uncontrolled medical disorder or non-malignant systemic disease making the patient a poor medical risk (e.g., uncontrolled seizure disorder, superior vena cava syndrome, severe psychiatric disorder) | Persistent toxicities from prior therapy >= Grade 2 (except alopecia or sensory peripheral neuropathy) | Unable to swallow oral medications or gastrointestinal disorders likely to interfere with absorption
prior_therapies: Prior radical prostatectomy or curative-intent external beam radiotherapy to the prostate required; Prior ADT with or without second-generation AR inhibitors or abiraterone in the curative setting allowed if testosterone >150 ng/dL; ADT for metastatic disease allowed up to 4 weeks prior to registration
reasoning: The trial requires castration-sensitive, newly diagnosed oligometastatic prostate cancer, whereas the patient has metastatic castration-resistant disease with progression on enzalutamide. This is a required stage/setting mismatch, which is a hard exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 66 years; Male sex; Metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer; Progression on enzalutamide; PSMA PET avid liver and bone metastases
patient_prior_therapies: Progression on enzalutamide; Prior abiraterone (Zytiga) with leuprolide (Lupron) for 3 years
judge_comment: The trial requires castration-sensitive, newly diagnosed oligometastatic prostate cancer, while the patient has metastatic castration-resistant disease. This is a required stage/setting mismatch listed under hard exclusions, so F is correct.

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 8-year-old female with PMM2-CDG (Congenital Disorder of Glycosylation). She has confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2 and exhibits moderate cerebellar dysfunction with a recent ICARS score of 35. Her family is highly motivated for research participation.
trial_title: An Open Label Phase 2 Study of BBP-418 in Patients With Limb Girdle Muscular Dystrophy Type 2I (MLB-01-003)
inclusion_criteria: Body weight >30 kg | Genetically confirmed diagnosis of LGMD2I and clinically affected with limb-girdle or distal weakness | Able to complete the 10-meter walk test in <=12 seconds unaided or are severe/non-ambulatory (unable or >12 seconds) | Previous enrollment in the natural history study MLB-01-001
exclusion_criteria: Gastrointestinal disease or surgeries that may affect absorption after oral administration | Significant cardiac, pulmonary, renal, hepatic, or endocrine disease other than that associated with LGMD2I | Any condition other than LGMD2I requiring therapy with prescription medicine (unless permitted by the investigator) | Any laboratory, vital sign, ECG abnormality, or clinical history/finding that increases risk or may confound results per investigator judgment | Pregnant or breastfeeding or planning to conceive during the study and for 12 weeks after last dose | History of drug abuse or alcoholism within 2 years prior to consent | Use of ribose or other sugar alcohol-containing supplement within 60 days before Day 1 | Use of a corticosteroid within 60 days before Day 1 | Platelet or bleeding disorder or other contraindication to muscle biopsy | Actively on an experimental therapy or device or received an experimental therapy or device within 60 days before Day 1
prior_therapies: No ribose or other sugar alcohol supplements within 60 days before Day 1; No corticosteroids within 60 days before Day 1; No experimental therapy or device within 60 days before Day 1
reasoning: Disease mismatch (trial enrolls LGMD2I, not PMM2-CDG) and the patient is 8 years old, below the trial’s 12–55 age range.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of PMM2-CDG; Confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2; ICARS score 35 (moderate cerebellar dysfunction); Age 8 years
judge_comment: Correctly identified two hard exclusions: disease mismatch (LGMD2I trial vs PMM2-CDG patient) and age below the trial minimum (8 < 12). Per rubric, any hard exclusion → F.

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Randomized Trial Comparing Intravesical Gemcitabine to Continuous Bladder Irrigation With Sterile Water to Prevent Bladder Cancer Implantation in Patients Undergoing Excision of Upper Tract Urothelial Carcinoma
inclusion_criteria: Biopsy-proven upper tract urothelial carcinoma. | Planned excisional surgery (distal ureterectomy or nephroureterectomy) with curative intent. | Age 18–90 years. | Life expectancy > 1 year. | Agreement to use adequate contraception during study and for 90 days after.
exclusion_criteria: Concurrent or prior bladder cancer with a disease-free interval < 3 years. | Synchronous bilateral upper tract urothelial carcinoma. | Planned radical cystectomy. | Bladder capacity < 100 mL. | History of allergic reactions to gemcitabine or similar agents.
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: The trial requires biopsy-proven upper tract urothelial carcinoma with planned curative excisional surgery, whereas the patient has metastatic urothelial carcinoma after second-line therapy and is not in a surgical curative setting. This is a required stage/setting mismatch.
patient_inclusion_criteria: (none)
judge_comment: The trial requires a curative surgical setting for upper tract urothelial carcinoma. The patient has metastatic disease after second-line therapy, definitively lacking the required stage/setting. This constitutes a hard exclusion per the rubric. Age/sex fit and disease site specificity is unknown, but the setting mismatch alone warrants F.

question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.
trial_title: Establishing Evidence-based Treatment for Speech and Language in Primary Progressive Aphasia
diseases_targeted: Primary Progressive Aphasia; Logopenic Progressive Aphasia; Nonfluent Progressive Aphasia; Semantic Dementia
inclusion_criteria: Primary Progressive Aphasia diagnosis per Gorno-Tempini et al., 2011 criteria | Mini-Mental State Examination score >= 15
exclusion_criteria: Other neurological or psychiatric diagnosis contributing to cognitive-linguistic deficits | Significant uncorrected visual or hearing impairment that would interfere with participation | Mini-Mental State Examination score < 15 | Prominent initial non-speech-language impairment (cognitive, behavioral, or motoric)
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets Primary Progressive Aphasia (and its variants, including semantic dementia) requiring a PPA diagnosis per Gorno-Tempini criteria, while the patient has unspecified dementia without a PPA diagnosis. Although MMSE, age, and sex align, the core disease requirement is unmet.
patient_biomarkers: Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 68 years; Male; Two-year history of progressive cognitive decline; MMSE score 19; Moderate-stage dementia; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
judge_comment: The trial specifically targets Primary Progressive Aphasia variants per Gorno-Tempini criteria, while the patient has unspecified dementia without a PPA diagnosis. This is a disease mismatch, which is a hard exclusion per the rubric, warranting grade F. The grader’s reasoning aligns with the rubric.

question_text: What are trial options for a 3-month-old male infant with genetically confirmed Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency? He presented on day 3 of life with a severe hyperammonemic crisis (ammonia 720 μmol/L) and is now stable on a regimen of dietary protein restriction and ammonia scavengers.
trial_title: A Global, Phase 1/2, Open-Label, Dose Optimization Study to Evaluate the Safety, Tolerability, Pharmacodynamics, and Pharmacokinetics of mRNA-3705 in Participants With Isolated Methylmalonic Acidemia Due to Methylmalonyl-CoA Mutase Deficiency
inclusion_criteria: Body weight >= 11.0 kg | Diagnosis of isolated methylmalonic acidemia due to MUT deficiency confirmed by molecular genetic testing | Blood vitamin B12 level >= lower limit of normal; elevated B12 allowed if due to supplementation per Investigator | Willing and able to provide informed consent/assent and comply with study procedures | Sexually active females of childbearing potential and males of reproductive potential agree to use highly effective contraception during the study and for 3 months after last dose | (Part 2 only) At least 1 documented metabolic decompensation event in the 12 months before consent
exclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of isolated MMA cblA, cblB, or cblD subtypes, methylmalonyl-CoA epimerase deficiency, or combined MMA with homocystinuria | Prior gene therapy for the treatment of MMA | History of organ transplantation or planned organ transplantation during study participation | Active, unstable, or clinically significant medical condition not related to MMA that could increase risk, interfere with results, or limit participation (including relevant allergies; cardiovascular, central nervous system, gastrointestinal, infectious disease; clinically significant pathology; or history of cancer) | (Part 2 only) History of hepatitis B surface antigen positivity, hepatitis C virus infection, or HIV infection; participants with resolved HBV (HBcAb positive, HBsAg negative) are eligible; HCV antibody positive allowed only if HCV RNA PCR is negative
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Hard exclusions: The trial targets methylmalonic acidemia due to MUT deficiency with a minimum age of 1 year/≥11 kg, while the patient has ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency and is 3 months old. This represents both a disease mismatch and an age window conflict.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Genetically confirmed ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency; History of severe neonatal hyperammonemic crisis; Currently clinically stable on therapy; Male; Age 3 months
judge_comment: Correctly identified hard exclusions: disease mismatch (OTC deficiency vs MMA due to MUT) and age below trial minimum (3 months vs ≥1 year). Either triggers an F per the rubric.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
trial_title: A Randomized, Multi-Cohort Phase II Trial of Temozolomide and Atezolizumab as Second or Third Line Treatment for Small Cell Lung Cancer
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | ECOG performance status of 0 or 2 within 28 days prior to registration | Histologically or cytologically confirmed extensive-stage small cell lung cancer that is metastatic and/or recurrent | Progression or recurrence after platinum-based chemotherapy with immunotherapy | Maximum of 3 prior lines of systemic therapy in the metastatic setting | Measurable disease per RECIST v1.1 | ANC >= 1500/µL | Platelets >= 100000/µL | Serum bilirubin <= 1.5 x ULN or direct bilirubin <= ULN (<= 3 x ULN allowed with Gilbert syndrome) | AST <= 3 x ULN (<= 5 x ULN with liver metastases) | ALT <= 3 x ULN (<= 5 x ULN with liver metastases) | Serum creatinine <= 2.0 x ULN or creatinine clearance >= 50 mL/min | Albumin > 2.5 g/dL | INR <= 1.5 x ULN if not on therapeutic anticoagulation (stable regimen if on anticoagulation) | aPTT <= 1.5 x ULN if not on therapeutic anticoagulation (stable regimen if on anticoagulation) | Negative pregnancy test for females of childbearing potential | Ability to swallow and retain oral medication | Life expectancy > 3 months
exclusion_criteria: Prior temozolomide therapy | Participation in another investigational study with study therapy or device within 4 weeks of first dose | Prior chemotherapy, immunotherapy, targeted therapy, or radiation within 2 weeks prior to day 1 or unresolved toxicities > grade 1 (except <= grade 2 neuropathy or alopecia) | Symptomatic CNS metastases or untreated/actively progressing CNS metastases not meeting protocol criteria | History of intracranial or spinal cord hemorrhage | Recent CNS-directed therapy not meeting washout: stereotactic radiotherapy within 7 days, whole-brain radiotherapy within 14 days, or neurosurgical resection within 28 days | Ongoing requirement for corticosteroids for CNS disease at time of treatment | Active infection requiring systemic therapy, including tuberculosis, hepatitis B (HBsAg positive), active hepatitis C, or uncontrolled HIV infection | Active or history of autoimmune disease or immune deficiency requiring systemic treatment, with protocol-defined exceptions | History of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, organizing pneumonia, drug-induced pneumonitis, or active pneumonitis | Significant cardiovascular disease within 3 months (NYHA class II or greater, myocardial infarction, cerebrovascular accident), unstable arrhythmia, or unstable angina | Live attenuated vaccine within 4 weeks prior to initiation of study treatment | Pregnant or breastfeeding | Severe allergic or anaphylactic reactions to chimeric or humanized antibodies or fusion proteins | Known hypersensitivity to Chinese hamster ovary cell products or components of atezolizumab | Uncontrolled pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, or ascites requiring recurrent drainage (> once monthly) | Uncontrolled or symptomatic hypercalcemia (ionized calcium > 1.5 mmol/L, calcium > 12 mg/dL or corrected serum calcium > ULN) | History of leptomeningeal disease | Prior or concurrent malignancy that could interfere with safety or efficacy assessment | Psychiatric or substance abuse disorders that would interfere with protocol compliance
prior_therapies: Progression after platinum-based chemotherapy with immunotherapy required; <=3 prior lines of systemic therapy for metastatic disease allowed; Washout >=2 weeks from prior chemotherapy, immunotherapy, targeted therapy, or radiation
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial is for metastatic/recurrent small cell lung cancer, while the patient has metastatic non-small cell lung cancer (EGFR exon 19). Therefore the patient is ineligible.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Non-small cell lung cancer; De novo metastatic disease (bone, liver); EGFR exon 19 deletion; ECOG 0; Age 40 years
judge_comment: Correctly applied hard exclusion: the trial targets metastatic/recurrent small cell lung cancer, while the patient has metastatic non-small cell lung cancer. Disease mismatch mandates an F per rubric.

question_text: What are trial options for a 3-month-old male infant with genetically confirmed Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency? He presented on day 3 of life with a severe hyperammonemic crisis (ammonia 720 μmol/L) and is now stable on a regimen of dietary protein restriction and ammonia scavengers.

inclusion_criteria: Age >= 2 and < 18 years | Molecularly confirmed biallelic PMM2 pathogenic variants | Negative urine pregnancy test (females of child-bearing potential) | Agrees to effective contraception or abstinence from prior to randomization through 3 months after treatment (subjects of child-bearing potential)
exclusion_criteria: Other known congenital disorders of glycosylation | Allergy to aldose reductase inhibitors | Hypersensitivity to epalrestat | AST > 5 x ULN within 6 months prior to screening | ALT > 5 x ULN within 6 months prior to screening | Total bilirubin > 2 x ULN within 6 months prior to screening | Albumin < 2.8 mmol/L at screening | Liver fibrosis by elastography (Fibroscan > 7 kPa) at screening | Serum creatinine > 0.5 mg/dL (<= 6 years) | Serum creatinine > 0.7 mg/dL (7-10 years) | Serum creatinine > 1.24 mg/dL (>= 11 years) | Platelet count < 125 x10^9/L | Hemoglobin < 10 g/dL | Any other clinically significant laboratory abnormality per investigator | Use of an investigational drug (including acetazolamide) within 28 days | Use of an investigational biologic within 12 months | Concurrent or planned participation in another interventional protocol or use of other unapproved therapeutics | Any other medical condition that interferes with protocol compliance, compromises safety, or interferes with interpretation of results
prior_therapies: Washout from investigational drugs >= 28 days; Washout from investigational biologics >= 12 months
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets PMM2-CDG, not OTC deficiency. Additionally, the patient is 3 months old, below the trial’s minimum age of 2 years.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Genetically confirmed ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency; History of severe neonatal hyperammonemic crisis; Currently clinically stable on therapy; Male; Age 3 months
judge_comment: Correct: There is a hard disease mismatch (PMM2-CDG trial vs OTC deficiency patient) and an age window conflict (trial ≥2 years vs patient 3 months). Either triggers F per rubric. The grader’s reasoning aligns with the rubric.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. trial_title: A Phase 3 Open-Label, Randomized, Controlled, Global Study of Telisotuzumab Vedotin (ABBV-399) Versus Docetaxel in Subjects With Previously Treated c-Met Overexpressing, EGFR Wildtype, Locally Advanced/Metastatic Non-Squamous Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer
diseases_targeted: Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (non-squamous, locally advanced/metastatic)
inclusion_criteria: Life expectancy >= 12 weeks | c-MET overexpressing non-small cell lung cancer per IHC (VENTANA MET SP44 RxDx assay) with centrally assessed tumor tissue | Histologically or cytologically confirmed non-squamous NSCLC that is locally advanced or metastatic | Known EGFR activating mutation status | Known status of actionable gene alterations other than EGFR | Measurable disease per RECIST v1.1 | ECOG performance status 0–1 | No more than 1 prior line of systemic cytotoxic chemotherapy for locally advanced/metastatic disease | Neoadjuvant/adjuvant cytotoxic chemotherapy counts as a prior line if progression occurred within 6 months of completion | Progressed on at least 1 prior line of therapy for locally advanced/metastatic NSCLC | Without actionable gene alteration: progressed on or ineligible for platinum-based chemotherapy and an immune checkpoint inhibitor (monotherapy or in combination with chemotherapy) | With actionable gene alteration where ICI is not standard: progressed on or ineligible for targeted therapy to the driver alteration and platinum-based chemotherapy | If immune checkpoint inhibitor is standard for the actionable alteration: also progressed on or ineligible for an immune checkpoint inhibitor | Considered appropriate for docetaxel therapy by the treating physician | CNS metastases allowed if adequately treated, asymptomatic, and on stable or decreasing steroids (<= 10 mg/day prednisone equivalent) and/or anticonvulsants for >= 2 weeks before randomization
exclusion_criteria: New, untreated CNS metastases | Leptomeningeal disease | Adenosquamous histology | Neuroendocrine histology | Sarcomatoid features | Actionable EGFR activating mutations (EGFR wildtype required) | Prior c-MET–targeted antibodies | Prior telisotuzumab vedotin | Prior antibody–drug conjugates targeting c-MET or containing monomethylauristatin E | Prior docetaxel therapy | History of other malignancy unless treated with curative intent and disease-free for >= 2 years, or adequately treated non-melanoma skin cancer/lentigo maligna, or carcinoma in situ without current disease | History of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, organizing pneumonia, drug-induced pneumonitis, or idiopathic pneumonitis, or active pneumonitis on screening CT (radiation pneumonitis fibrosis permitted) | Unresolved adverse event >= Grade 2 from prior anticancer therapy (except alopecia or anemia); stable replacement hormone therapy allowed | Major surgery within 21 days prior to randomization | Clinically significant medical conditions per protocol
prior_therapies: Prior platinum-based chemotherapy required unless ineligible; Prior immune checkpoint inhibitor required unless ineligible or not standard for genotype; Prior targeted therapy to driver gene alteration required if actionable alteration present; No more than 1 prior line of systemic cytotoxic chemotherapy for advanced/metastatic disease; Neoadjuvant/adjuvant cytotoxic chemotherapy counts as a prior line if relapse within 6 months
reasoning: The trial explicitly requires EGFR wildtype and excludes EGFR activating mutations; the patient has an EGFR exon 19 deletion. Other aspects (metastatic NSCLC, ECOG 0, age) could fit, but EGFR status is a hard exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Non-small cell lung cancer; De novo metastatic disease (bone, liver); EGFR exon 19 deletion; ECOG 0; Age 40 years
judge_comment: The trial explicitly excludes EGFR activating mutations and requires EGFR wildtype; the patient has an EGFR exon 19 deletion. This is a hard exclusion per the rubric, so F is correct.

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Phase II Study to Assess the Safety and Efficacy of Tocilizumab in Combination With Ipilimumab and Nivolumab in Patients With Advanced Melanoma, Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer, or Urothelial Carcinoma
diseases_targeted: Melanoma (unresectable/metastatic); Urothelial Carcinoma (locally advanced/metastatic); Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (locally advanced/metastatic)
inclusion_criteria: Histologically confirmed unresectable stage III or stage IV cutaneous melanoma (Cohort 1) | Consent to BRAF testing or documented BRAF V600 mutation status (Cohort 1) | Treatment-naive for unresectable/metastatic melanoma; prior adjuvant therapy allowed (Cohort 1) | Histologically or cytologically confirmed locally advanced or metastatic urothelial carcinoma of renal pelvis, ureter, bladder, or urethra; dominant transitional cell pattern if mixed histology (Cohort 2) | Cisplatin-ineligible or patient refuses standard chemotherapy; no prior systemic therapy for inoperable locally advanced/metastatic urothelial carcinoma (Cohort 2) | Cisplatin ineligibility may be due to GFR <60 and >=15 mL/min, NYHA class >= III heart failure, grade >=2 neuropathy, ECOG PS 2, or grade >=2 hearing loss (Cohort 2) | Prior intravesical chemotherapy allowed if completed >=4 weeks before treatment (Cohort 2) | If prior adjuvant/neoadjuvant chemo or chemoradiation for urothelial carcinoma, recurrence >12 months to be considered treatment-naive; no prior immuno-oncology in adjuvant/neoadjuvant (Cohort 2) | Histologically or cytologically confirmed locally advanced/metastatic NSCLC with EGFR mutation sensitive to EGFR TKI (G719X, exon 19 deletion, L858R, L861Q) (Cohort 3) | Received exactly one prior EGFR TKI in the advanced setting (Cohort 3) | Progressed on first/second-generation EGFR TKI and T790M negative by approved assay at progression, or progressed on osimertinib; EGFR TKI must be the last therapy (Cohort 3) | ECOG performance status <=1 | Measurable disease per RECIST 1.1 | Stable brain metastases <=3 cm without need for local intervention or systemic corticosteroids within 10 days prior to first treatment | Tumor tissue available for submission (FFPE block or unstained slides) from biopsy within 3 months prior to enrollment or approved archival tissue | Age >=18 years | WOCBP negative pregnancy test within 24 hours prior to start of treatment and agree to contraception; males with WOCBP partners agree to contraception
exclusion_criteria: Symptomatic interstitial lung disease or condition interfering with detection/management of pulmonary toxicity | Uveal melanoma | Active or uncontrolled medical, psychiatric, or logistical condition increasing risk or interfering with study participation | Active second malignancy within 3 years except certain curable cancers (e.g., basal/squamous skin cancer, superficial bladder cancer, carcinoma in situ of prostate, cervix, or breast) | Active autoimmune disease requiring systemic treatment (exceptions: type I diabetes, hypothyroidism on replacement, skin disorders not requiring systemic treatment, or conditions not expected to recur) | Systemic corticosteroids >10 mg prednisone equivalent daily or other immunosuppressive medication within 14 days prior to first dose (exceptions allowed as specified) | History of organ or tissue transplant requiring systemic immunosuppression | Active infection requiring systemic therapy within 14 days prior to first dose | Unstable or significant cardiac disease within 12 months (e.g., unstable angina, myocardial infarction, TIA/CVA, NYHA class III/IV heart failure, uncontrolled significant arrhythmias) | Known HIV infection | Use of an investigational agent or device within 28 days prior to first dose | Live or attenuated vaccine within 30 days before first treatment | Prior treatment with anti–PD-1, anti–PD-L1, anti–PD-L2, anti–CTLA-4, or other T-cell costimulation/checkpoint agents except permitted adjuvant use | History of life-threatening toxicity from prior immune therapy unless unlikely to recur with standard countermeasures | Use of botanical preparations intended for general health support or to treat the study disease within 2 weeks prior to treatment initiation | Allergy or hypersensitivity to study drug components or severe hypersensitivity to any monoclonal antibody | Known hypersensitivity to tocilizumab, ipilimumab, or nivolumab | Prisoners or involuntarily incarcerated individuals | Compulsory detention for treatment of psychiatric or physical illness | WBC < 2000/µL | Absolute neutrophil count < 1500/µL | Platelets < 100000/µL | Hemoglobin < 9.0 g/dL (no transfusion within 14 days to meet criteria) | Serum creatinine > 1.5 x ULN unless creatinine clearance >= 40 mL/min | AST > 3.0 x ULN | ALT > 3.0 x ULN | Total bilirubin > 1.5 x ULN (except Gilbert syndrome < 3.0 x ULN) | Positive test indicating active hepatitis B or C infection
prior_therapies: No prior systemic therapy for unresectable or metastatic melanoma; prior adjuvant therapy allowed (Cohort 1); No prior chemotherapy for inoperable locally advanced or metastatic urothelial carcinoma (Cohort 2); Prior intravesical chemotherapy allowed if completed >= 4 weeks before treatment (Cohort 2); If prior adjuvant/neoadjuvant chemotherapy or chemoradiation for urothelial carcinoma, recurrence must be > 12 months to be considered treatment-naive; no prior immuno-oncology in adjuvant/neoadjuvant (Cohort 2); Exactly one prior line of EGFR TKI therapy in advanced NSCLC and progressed; EGFR TKI must be last therapy (Cohort 3)
reasoning: The urothelial carcinoma cohort requires no prior systemic therapy for inoperable locally advanced/metastatic disease (treatment-naive), but the patient is after second-line therapy, which violates this required setting.
patient_inclusion_criteria: (none)
judge_comment: The trial’s urothelial carcinoma cohort requires treatment-naive status for metastatic/inoperable disease (no prior systemic therapy). The patient is after second-line therapy, definitively lacking the required setting/line. Per hard exclusions (required stage/setting mismatch), this warrants an F. The grader’s reasoning aligns with the rubric.

What are trial options?
trial_title: A Combination Therapy Trial Using an Adaptive Platform Design for Children and Young Adults With Diffuse Midline Gliomas (DMGs) Including Diffuse Intrinsic Pontine Gliomas (DIPGs) at Initial Diagnosis, Post-Radiation Therapy and at Time of Progression
diseases_targeted: Diffuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma; Diffuse Midline Glioma (H3 K27M-mutant); WHO Grade III Glioma; Recurrent Diffuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma; Recurrent Diffuse Midline Glioma (H3 K27M-mutant); Recurrent WHO Grade III Glioma
inclusion_criteria: Age 2 to 39 years | Diagnosis of diffuse midline glioma (including spinal cord tumors) by imaging and/or pathology | Post-radiation cohorts: within 4–14 weeks of completing radiation and no additional therapy beyond radiation | Progression cohorts: evidence of progression after completing standard-of-care radiation and no prior re-irradiation | Body weight >= 10 kg | Seizure disorder allowed if well controlled | Contraception required for participants of childbearing potential | Adequate tissue available for molecular analyses (minimum 10–20 unstained slides or 1 block with >= 40% tumor content) | No dyspnea at rest or exercise intolerance due to pulmonary insufficiency | Pulse oximetry > 92% on room air | QTc < 470 msec | Karnofsky >= 50 for >16 years or Lansky >= 50 for <=16 years | For targeted therapy cohorts: tumor harbors BRAFV600E, PDGFRA alteration (point mutation or amplification with >= 5 copies), FGFR1 alteration (point mutation, fusion, or amplification with >= 5 copies), or NF1 alteration
exclusion_criteria: Histone H3 wildtype grade II diffuse astrocytoma | Thalamic or cerebellar H3K27M diffuse midline glioma (with limited specified exceptions) | Prior exposure to radiation therapy (pre-radiation cohorts) | Prior exposure to re-irradiation for tumor progression (progression cohorts) | Currently receiving another investigational drug or other anti-cancer agents | Immunodeficiency or active HIV, hepatitis B, or hepatitis C infection; autoimmune disorder requiring systemic cytotoxic or immunosuppressive therapy | Uncontrolled infection or other uncontrolled systemic illness | Pregnant or breastfeeding | Active illicit drug use or diagnosis of alcoholism | Allergy to compounds of similar composition to study agents | Evidence of disseminated disease, including diffuse leptomeningeal or CSF dissemination (except allowed in specified targeted cohorts) | Additional malignancy that is progressing or requires active treatment within 3 years | Concomitant use of potent CYP3A4/5 inhibitors within 72 hours prior to and during treatment | Concomitant use of potent CYP3A4/5 inducers (including enzyme-inducing antiepileptic drugs) within 2 weeks prior to and during treatment | History of congestive heart failure or family history of long QT syndrome
prior_therapies: Any number of prior therapies allowed; must have recovered from acute toxicities; Washout: >= 7 days after last biologic agent or beyond known AE window; Washout: >= 5 half-lives from any investigational agent; Washout: >= 4 weeks from cytotoxic therapy (>= 23 days for temozolomide; >= 6 weeks for nitrosoureas); Washout: >= 6 weeks from therapeutic antibodies (>= 21 days for bevacizumab when tumor-directed); Washout: >= 4 weeks or >= 5 half-lives (whichever is shorter) from other anti-tumor therapies; Prior temozolomide during radiation allowed at standard pediatric dosing (90 mg/m2 daily for 42 days); Bevacizumab for radiation-induced edema allowed (up to 5 doses; no required washout); Dexamethasone allowed; dose must be stable or decreasing for >= 3 days before baseline MRI
reasoning: Hard exclusions: the trial enrolls diffuse midline/DIPG or WHO grade III gliomas in ages 2–39, while the patient has recurrent glioblastoma (grade IV, non-DMG) and is 40 years old—both disease mismatch and age above the maximum.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 40 years; Male; Recurrent glioblastoma; IDH wildtype; Status post gross total resection; Completed radiation with concurrent temozolomide and adjuvant temozolomide; ECOG 1; No other medical issues
patient_prior_therapies: Gross total resection; Adjuvant radiation with concurrent temozolomide; Adjuvant temozolomide
judge_comment: Hard exclusions apply: patient age (40) exceeds trial maximum (39) and disease mismatch (trial targets DMG/DIPG/WHO grade III, not glioblastoma grade IV). Therefore F is correct per rubric.

An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.

exclusion_criteria: Taking sleep medication | Residence in a skilled nursing facility or long-term care | Obstructing cataracts | Macular degeneration | Blindness | Severe sleep apnea | Restless legs syndrome | History of severe epilepsy
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: The trial enrolls only Mild Cognitive Impairment or mild Alzheimer's disease, whereas the patient has moderate-stage dementia (MMSE 19) and is amyloid-negative; thus the patient’s disease is not included in the trial’s targeted diseases.

patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 68 years; Male; Two-year history of progressive cognitive decline; MMSE score 19; Moderate-stage dementia; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau

question_text: 36 female with stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma, who initially received optimal debulking and adjuvant carboplatin+paclitaxel +bevacizumab.
