inclusion_criteria: Histologically or cytologically confirmed recurrent primary mucinous ovarian cancer | Age >= 18 years | ECOG performance status <= 2 | ANC > 1500/µL | Platelets > 100000/µL | Total bilirubin <= 1.5 mg/dL | Creatinine <= 1.5 mg/dL | AST <= 3 x ULN | ALT <= 3 x ULN | > 2 weeks from prior chemotherapy or radiation therapy (except bevacizumab requires > 6 weeks)
exclusion_criteria: Receiving concurrent investigational therapy or received investigational therapy within 30 days of HIPEC | Mucinous tumors with pathologic confirmation of a non-gynecologic site of origin | Known active CNS metastases | Hypersensitivity to any component of cisplatin | Uncontrolled intercurrent illness (e.g., ongoing or active infection, symptomatic congestive heart failure, unstable angina pectoris, cardiac arrhythmia, psychiatric illness/social situations limiting compliance) | Pregnant or nursing | Peripheral neuropathy >= grade 2 | History of allogenic transplant | History of prior HIPEC or intraperitoneal chemotherapy | Known bulky extra-abdominopelvic disease | Hearing impairment or tinnitus >= grade 2
prior_therapies: > 2 weeks since prior chemotherapy or radiation therapy; > 6 weeks since prior bevacizumab

patient_inclusion_criteria: Stage III clear cell ovarian carcinoma; Cytology-positive pleural effusion; BRCA1 positive; Female; Age 36 years
patient_prior_therapies: Optimal debulking surgery; Adjuvant carboplatin plus paclitaxel plus bevacizumab

question_text: What are trial options for a 3-month-old male infant with genetically confirmed Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency? trial_title: A Phase 3, Multicenter, Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-Controlled Study to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of Mitapivat in Pediatric Subjects With Pyruvate Kinase Deficiency Who Are Regularly Transfused, Followed by a 5-Year Open-label Extension Period
inclusion_criteria: Age 1 to <18 years (12–24 months must weigh >=7 kg) | Clinical laboratory confirmation of pyruvate kinase deficiency with >=2 mutant PKLR alleles, including >=1 missense mutation | Received 6 to 26 red blood cell transfusion episodes in the 52 weeks prior to consent/assent | Complete transfusion records for the prior 52 weeks (dates, volumes, and pre-transfusion hemoglobin for >=80% of transfusions) | Receiving folic acid supplementation for >=21 days before first dose and continued during study participation | Post-menarche females or Tanner stage 2 breast development: abstinent or using 2 forms of contraception (>=1 highly effective) during study and for 28 days after last dose
exclusion_criteria: Pregnant or breastfeeding | PKLR genotype homozygous R479H or two nonmissense mutations without another missense mutation | History of malignancy | Active and/or uncontrolled cardiac or pulmonary disease or clinically relevant QT prolongation within 6 months | Liver disease with histopathological evidence of cirrhosis or severe fibrosis | Clinically symptomatic cholelithiasis or cholecystitis (unless prior cholecystectomy) | History of drug-induced cholestatic hepatitis | AST >2.5 x ULN (unless due to hemolysis and/or hepatic iron deposition) | ALT >2.5 x ULN (unless due to hepatic iron deposition) | Estimated glomerular filtration rate <60 mL/min/1.73 m^2 | Nonfasting triglycerides >440 mg/dL (5 mmol/L) | Active uncontrolled infection requiring systemic antimicrobial therapy | Known active hepatitis B virus infection | Known hepatitis C virus infection | Known HIV infection | Major surgery (including splenectomy) within 6 months or planned during screening or double-blind period | Current enrollment or past participation in another interventional study within 90 days or 5 half-lives (whichever longer) before first dose | Prior exposure to gene therapy | Prior bone marrow or stem cell transplantation | Currently receiving hematopoietic stimulating agents (last dose <28 days or <5 half-lives before randomization) | Use of strong CYP3A4/5 inhibitors within <5 days or <5 half-lives before randomization | Use of strong CYP3A4 inducers within <28 days or <5 half-lives before randomization | Use of anabolic steroids, including testosterone, within <28 days before randomization | Allergy or contraindication to mitapivat or its excipients | Receiving a pyruvate kinase activator within <52 weeks before consent/assent
prior_therapies: Received 6–26 RBC transfusion episodes in the prior 52 weeks; Folic acid supplementation for >=21 days before first dose; Hematopoietic stimulating agents stopped >=28 days or >=5 half-lives before randomization; Strong CYP3A4/5 inhibitors stopped >=5 days or >=5 half-lives before randomization; Strong CYP3A4 inducers stopped >=28 days or >=5 half-lives before randomization; Anabolic steroids (including testosterone) stopped >=28 days before randomization; Prior pyruvate kinase activator stopped >=52 weeks before consent/assent; No investigational drug/device within 90 days or >=5 half-lives before first dose
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial enrolls pyruvate kinase deficiency (PKLR-mutant, transfusion-dependent) patients, while the patient has ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency. Additionally, the patient is 3 months old, below the trial’s minimum age of 1 year.

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 8-year-old female with PMM2-CDG (Congenital Disorder of Glycosylation). exclusion_criteria: Prior participation in a gene or cell therapy program | Immunizations of any kind within 1 month prior to the study | Active infection based on clinical observations | Serological evidence of HIV infection, or Hepatitis B or C infection | Diagnosis of or ongoing treatment for an autoimmune disease | Persistent leukopenia or leukocytosis (WBC <= 3500/µL or >= 20000/µL) | Absolute neutrophil count < 1500/µL | Abnormal liver function: GGT > 2 x ULN (if no other laboratory abnormalities), elevated bilirubin, and/or abnormal PT/INR | Concomitant illness or requirement for chronic drug treatment that creates unnecessary risks for gene transfer per PI | AAV9 binding antibody titer > 1:50 | Abnormal laboratory values in the clinically significant range | Diagnosis of any other systemic illness that increases the risk of gene transfer or conditions that may compromise compliance, safety, or interpretability per PI | Any requirement for immunomodulatory therapy where a safe washout is not feasible | Contraindication for intrathecal injection | Positive JCV antibody test > 0.40
prior_therapies: No prior gene or cell therapy; No immunizations within 1 month prior to study
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets IGHMBP2-related disorders (CMT2S/SMARD1) and requires two pathogenic IGHMBP2 variants, while the patient has PMM2-CDG with PMM2 variants. This fails the required disease/biomarker criteria despite age eligibility.

Age and gender fit but are irrelevant once a hard exclusion applies. The grader’s reasoning correctly identified the disease mismatch (and noted the biomarker requirement mismatch, though disease mismatch alone suffices).

question_text: What are trial options for a 3-month-old male infant with genetically confirmed Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency? question_text: 40 year old man with recurrent glioblastoma. Diagnosed 1 year ago, underwent gross total resection with confirmation of GBM, IDH wildtype. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Pilot Study of Temporally-modulated Pulsed Radiation Therapy to Reirradiate Recurrent IDH-mutant Gliomas After Prior External Beam Radiation Therapy
inclusion_criteria: Histologically confirmed recurrent IDH-mutant glioma (astrocytoma or oligodendroglioma) with prior external beam radiation therapy (EBRT) to the same region | Recurrent tumor may be histologically confirmed or based on clinical assessment | Maximum tumor diameter <= 7 cm | Prior EBRT completed >= 2 years ago | Region for reirradiation received >= 45 Gy from prior EBRT | Region for reirradiation received <= 75 Gy from prior EBRT | Prior EBRT may be photon-based or proton-based | Prior stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS) to the same region permitted if cumulative EBRT+SRS dose <= 75 Gy | Prior SRS completed >= 6 months ago | Life expectancy >= 12 months | Age >= 18 years | Karnofsky performance status >= 70% | Females of childbearing potential agree to use effective contraception during the study
exclusion_criteria: Leptomeningeal or metastatic involvement | Prior grade >= 3 radiation necrosis at least possibly related to prior radiotherapy | Concurrent bevacizumab or other anti-VEGF therapy during TMPRT | Medical contraindication to MRI (e.g., unsafe metallic implants, incompatible pacemaker, inability to lie still for long periods, severe to end-stage kidney disease or on hemodialysis) | Pregnant
prior_therapies: Prior external beam radiation therapy to the same region required; Prior EBRT dose to the region between 45 Gy and 75 Gy; Prior EBRT completed >= 2 years before enrollment; Prior stereotactic radiosurgery to the same region permitted; Cumulative EBRT plus SRS dose <= 75 Gy; Prior SRS completed >= 6 months before enrollment; Bevacizumab washout >= 4 weeks before start of TMPRT
reasoning: The trial is for recurrent IDH-mutant astrocytoma/oligodendroglioma, while the patient has recurrent IDH-wildtype glioblastoma—both a disease and required biomarker mismatch.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 40 years; Male; Recurrent glioblastoma; IDH wildtype; Status post gross total resection; Completed radiation with concurrent temozolomide and adjuvant temozolomide; ECOG 1; No other medical issues
patient_prior_therapies: Gross total resection; Adjuvant radiation with concurrent temozolomide; Adjuvant temozolomide
judge_comment: Hard exclusions apply: the trial targets recurrent IDH-mutant astrocytoma/oligodendroglioma, while the patient has recurrent IDH-wildtype glioblastoma (disease mismatch) and lacks the required IDH mutation (biomarker mismatch). Thus F is appropriate.

question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.
trial_title: A Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled, Parallel-Group Study to Assess the Efficacy, Safety, and Tolerability of BIIB080 in Subjects With Mild Cognitive Impairment Due to Alzheimer's Disease or Mild Alzheimer's Disease Dementia
diseases_targeted: Mild Cognitive Impairment Due to Alzheimer's Disease; Alzheimer's Disease (mild dementia)
inclusion_criteria: Mild cognitive impairment due to Alzheimer's disease (NIA-AA Stage 3) or mild Alzheimer's disease dementia (NIA-AA Stage 4) | RBANS Delayed Memory Index score <= 85 | Clinical Dementia Rating (global) of 0.5 for MCI due to AD or 0.5–1 for mild AD dementia | Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) score 21–30 | CDR Memory Box score >= 0.5 | Evidence of amyloid pathology by PET or CSF
exclusion_criteria: Known allergy or hypersensitivity to BIIB080 or its excipients | Previous participation in a study with BIIB080 | Use of symptomatic (non-disease-modifying) AD medications at unstable doses within 8 weeks prior to screening or during screening | Use of commercially available disease-modifying AD medications (e.g., anti-amyloid monoclonal antibodies) | Prior participation in active or passive anti-amyloid immunotherapy without documentation of placebo | Prior participation in passive tau immunotherapy unless last administration >= 6 months or >= 5 half-lives before screening or documentation of placebo | Prior participation in investigational tau-targeting therapy that is not passive immunotherapy without documentation of placebo | Prior participation within 12 months in any other agent with purported disease-modifying effect in AD without documentation of placebo | Prior participation in any gene therapy with purported disease-modifying effect in AD without documentation of placebo | Current or previous use of disease-modifying AD medications outside investigational studies | Any vaccination within 10 days prior to Day -1 (except as specified for COVID-19 timing) | Contraindications to brain MRI | Current enrollment or planned enrollment in another interventional clinical study within 52 weeks prior to baseline | Any medical or psychiatric contraindication or clinically significant abnormality increasing risk (LTE period)
prior_therapies: Symptomatic Alzheimer's disease medications at stable dose >= 8 weeks before screening
reasoning: The trial requires evidence of amyloid pathology (positive PET or CSF), but the patient is amyloid-negative by both PET and CSF. Additionally, the patient has moderate dementia with MMSE 19, outside the trial’s MCI/mild AD (MMSE 21–30) range.
patient_biomarkers: Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 68 years; Male; Two-year history of progressive cognitive decline; MMSE score 19; Moderate-stage dementia; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
judge_comment: Correct. The trial requires evidence of amyloid pathology (PET or CSF); the patient is amyloid-negative, which is a hard exclusion. The MMSE/stage also mismatches but the hard biomarker requirement alone warrants an F.

trial_title: A Phase 2 Randomized Study of YONSA® (Abiraterone Acetate), Enzalutamide or Apalutamide as First Line Therapy in Veterans With Castrate-sensitive Prostate Cancer
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | ECOG performance status 0–1 | Histologically or cytologically confirmed adenocarcinoma of the prostate without neuroendocrine, signet-cell, or small-cell features | Receiving or will receive androgen-deprivation therapy with a GnRH agonist/antagonist or have undergone bilateral orchiectomy | High-risk disease with >= 3 rising PSA values at least 1 week apart | PSA >= 2 ng/mL | PSA doubling time <= 9 months during continuous androgen-deprivation therapy | Has not received abiraterone acetate, enzalutamide, or apalutamide at enrollment | Predicted life expectancy > 12 months | For patients on bisphosphonates or denosumab, dose stable for >= 4 weeks before randomization | AST <= 2.5 x ULN | ALT <= 2.5 x ULN | Creatinine clearance >= 30 mL/min or serum creatinine <= 1.8 mg/dL | Absolute neutrophil count >= 1000/µL | Platelet count >= 100000/µL | Hemoglobin > 9 g/dL
exclusion_criteria: Prior cytotoxic chemotherapy for prostate cancer | Prior aminoglutethimide or ketoconazole for prostate cancer | Prior abiraterone acetate, apalutamide, or enzalutamide for prostate cancer | Prior participation in a clinical trial of an investigational androgen receptor or androgen synthesis inhibitor (unless placebo) | Hormonal therapy for prostate cancer within 4 weeks of randomization (other than GnRH agonist/antagonist) | Biologic therapy for prostate cancer within 4 weeks of randomization (other than approved bone-targeting agents) | Active second malignancy except disease-free >= 3 years, completely resected non-melanoma skin cancer, or successfully treated in situ carcinoma | History of seizure or condition predisposing to seizure (e.g., prior cortical stroke, significant brain trauma) | Deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism within the past 3 months causing medical instability | Concurrent investigational agents
prior_therapies: Androgen-deprivation therapy with a GnRH agonist/antagonist or prior bilateral orchiectomy required; Bisphosphonates or denosumab allowed if on a stable dose for >= 4 weeks before randomization
reasoning: The trial explicitly excludes prior abiraterone or enzalutamide; this patient has received both and has mCRPC, whereas the study is for first-line castrate-sensitive disease.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 66 years; Male sex; Metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer; Progression on enzalutamide; PSMA PET avid liver and bone metastases
patient_prior_therapies: Progression on enzalutamide; Prior abiraterone (Zytiga) with leuprolide (Lupron) for 3 years
judge_comment: Explicit exclusion: trial excludes prior abiraterone or enzalutamide; patient has received both. That alone triggers a hard exclusion. Additionally, the study is for first-line castrate-sensitive disease while the patient has mCRPC, reinforcing ineligibility.

trial_title: An Open-Label Phase 1/2A Study of GV20-0251 Monotherapy and GV20-0251 in Combination With Pembrolizumab in Participants With Advanced and/or Refractory Solid Tumor Malignancies
diseases_targeted: Endometrial Carcinoma; Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma; Cutaneous Melanoma; Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer; Colorectal Adenocarcinoma (pMMR/MSS)
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Histologically confirmed advanced solid malignancy with progressive disease | Refractory or intolerant to standard therapy | Not eligible for or declined standard-of-care therapy | Measurable disease per RECIST 1.1 | Documented disease progression after prior checkpoint inhibitor if previously treated | ECOG performance status 0-1 | Life expectancy >= 12 weeks (Parts A and C) or >= 24 weeks (Parts B and D) | Disease-free of active second malignancy for >= 2 years | Eligible tumor types for expansion cohorts include: endometrial carcinoma; head and neck squamous cell carcinoma; cutaneous melanoma; non-small cell lung cancer; pMMR/MSS colorectal adenocarcinoma (Parts C and D)
exclusion_criteria: Acute leukemia or chronic lymphocytic leukemia (Parts A and B) | Clinically significant heart disease or unstable arrhythmia | Active, uncontrolled bacterial, viral, or fungal infection requiring systemic therapy | Active autoimmune disease or other conditions requiring chronic systemic steroids or immunosuppressive therapy | History of major organ transplant | History of bone marrow transplant | Symptomatic central nervous system malignancy or metastasis | Serious nonmalignant disease that could interfere with study participation | Pregnant or nursing | Treatment with PD-1 or equivalent immune modulators prior to first dose | Major surgery prior to first dose of study medication | Receipt of another investigational agent within 4 weeks before first dose | Any anticancer treatment within 2 weeks before first dose | Radiation for symptomatic lesions must be completed prior to first dose | Liver metastases unless approved by the Sponsor | History of immune-related adverse event >= Grade 3 attributed to prior cancer immunotherapy | Additional malignancy that is progressing or required active treatment within 2 years before C1D1 | Radiation therapy to the lung > 30 Gy within 6 months prior to C1D1 for NSCLC (Parts C and D) | Severe hypersensitivity (>= Grade 3) to pembrolizumab or its excipients (Parts C and D) | History of non-infectious pneumonitis/interstitial lung disease requiring steroids or current pneumonitis/ILD (Parts C and D) | Any condition or laboratory abnormality that could confound results or interfere with participation (Parts C and D) | Active substance abuse
prior_therapies: Prior standard therapy required; refractory or intolerant to standard therapy; Prior checkpoint inhibitor allowed with documented progression; No investigational agents within 4 weeks before first dose; No anticancer treatments within 2 weeks before first dose; Radiation for symptomatic lesions must be completed before first dose
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial is for specific advanced solid tumors, while the patient has PMM2-CDG. Additionally, the patient is 8 years old and the trial requires age ≥18.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of PMM2-CDG; Confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2; ICARS score 35 (moderate cerebellar dysfunction); Age 8 years
judge_comment: Two hard exclusions apply: disease mismatch (patient has PMM2-CDG, trial is for specified advanced solid tumors) and age window conflict (patient is 8; trial requires >=18). Under the rubric, any hard exclusion → F. The grader’s reasoning and grade are correct.

question_text: A 55-year-old female has severe, seropositive rheumatoid arthritis refractory to methotrexate and two prior biologic agents (adalimumab and tocilizumab). She has active disease with a DAS28 score of 5.5. Critically, she has a history of treated Hepatitis B (HBsAg negative, anti-HBc positive) and moderate chronic kidney disease with an eGFR of 45 mL/min/1.73m². What are trial options for her?
trial_title: Web-based Pain Coping Skills Training to Improve Pain and Poor Adherence Caused by Aromatase Inhibitor-Associated Arthralgia In Breast Cancer Survivors (SKIP-Arthralgia): A Randomized Controlled Trial
inclusion_criteria: Female sex | Age >= 18 years | Stage 0–III hormone receptor positive breast cancer | Completed primary cancer treatment (surgery, chemotherapy, and/or radiation therapy) | Postmenopausal | Currently taking aromatase inhibitor therapy (letrozole, exemestane, or anastrozole) | Musculoskeletal pain that developed or worsened since starting aromatase inhibitor therapy | >= 15 days of pain in the past 30 days | Worst pain rating >= 4/10 in the past week | ECOG performance status 0-2 | Stable analgesic regimen for >= 14 days prior to enrollment with no planned upward titration during the study
exclusion_criteria: Metastatic disease | Other active cancer (except non-melanoma skin cancer) | Chemotherapy or radiation therapy completed < 4 weeks prior to enrollment | Major surgery completed < 8 weeks prior to enrollment (minor surgeries may be allowed) | Diagnosed or suspected condition interfering with consent or study activities (e.g., significant cognitive impairment or uncorrected hearing/vision)
prior_therapies: Completed primary cancer treatment (surgery, chemotherapy, and/or radiation therapy); Currently receiving aromatase inhibitor therapy; Stable analgesic regimen >= 14 days before enrollment; No chemotherapy or radiation therapy within 4 weeks prior to enrollment; No major surgery within 8 weeks prior to enrollment
reasoning: The trial is for postmenopausal hormone receptor–positive breast cancer survivors on aromatase inhibitors with AI-associated arthralgia, whereas the patient has rheumatoid arthritis; this disease mismatch is a hard exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 55 years; Female; Seropositive rheumatoid arthritis; Active disease (DAS28 5.5)
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to methotrexate; Prior adalimumab; Prior tocilizumab; Failed two prior biologic agents
judge_comment: Disease mismatch is a hard exclusion: the trial targets breast cancer survivors with AI-associated arthralgia, while the patient has rheumatoid arthritis. F is appropriate per rubric.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: A Pilot Study Testing the Safety and Feasibility of Restorative Microbiota Therapy (RMT) in Patients With Refractory Immune-checkpoint Inhibitor-related Colitis
inclusion_criteria: Solid tumor treated with immune checkpoint inhibitor (PD-1/PD-L1 with or without CTLA-4) with at least two doses | ICI used as single agent or in combination with cytotoxic chemotherapy or targeted therapy | Last ICI treatment within 6 weeks of onset of IMDC symptoms | Steroid-refractory IMDC per protocol definitions (persistent Grade >= 2 diarrhea after high-dose steroids and/or after biologic agent, or relapse during/after steroid taper as specified) | Adequate organ function within 14 days prior to enrollment | Well-controlled diabetes with HbA1c < 8 within 6 months of screening | Euvolemic on physical examination | Stable vital signs at screening and enrollment (temperature 95.8–99.9 F, heart rate 60–100/min, blood pressure 90–140/60–90 mm Hg) | On standard antidiarrheal supportive care for at least 1 day prior to starting study treatment | Age >= 18 years | Body weight > 30 kg | Expected survival >= 6 months
exclusion_criteria: Concomitant infectious colitis based on standard stool screening (ova and parasites, C. difficile PCR, enteric bacterial and viral PCR panel) | Last cytotoxic chemotherapy or targeted therapy < 3 weeks prior to screening | Anticipated need for cytotoxic chemotherapy or targeted therapy through 30 days after first dose of study drug | Current pregnancy or breastfeeding | Receiving another investigational agent or received an investigational agent within 60 days of enrollment | Uncontrolled Grade >= 3 infection at the time of enrollment (systemic antibiotics for non-GI infections allowed) | History of chronic diarrhea from non-IMDC causes (e.g., Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis) | Dysphagia or inability to swallow capsules (CTCAE v5 Grade >= 2) | Known risk of aspiration | Known sensitivity to any component of study therapy | On intravenous biologic agents for other baseline autoimmune conditions | Other uncontrolled immune-related adverse events requiring systemic corticosteroids or biologic immunomodulatory agents | Chronic systemic antibiotic therapy (>= 60 consecutive days within 12 weeks of enrollment) | Receipt of over-the-counter probiotics in the last 4 weeks | Receipt of live attenuated vaccination within 30 days of study treatment | Psychiatric or social conditions limiting compliance or informed consent
prior_therapies: Prior immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy (>= 2 doses of PD-1/PD-L1 with or without CTLA-4); Washout from cytotoxic chemotherapy or targeted therapy >= 3 weeks before screening
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets immune checkpoint inhibitor-related colitis in cancer patients, not Crohn's disease. Additionally, the trial explicitly excludes patients with chronic diarrhea from non-IMDC causes, including Crohn's disease.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe Crohn's disease; Fistulizing disease; CDAI score 350; Active perianal fistula with draining seton in place
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab
judge_comment: Correct: The trial targets immune checkpoint inhibitor-related colitis and explicitly excludes Crohn’s disease. This is both a disease mismatch hard exclusion and an explicit exclusion, so F is appropriate.

question_text: What are trial options for a 3-month-old male infant with genetically confirmed Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency? He presented on day 3 of life with a severe hyperammonemic crisis (ammonia 720 μmol/L) and is now stable on a regimen of dietary protein restriction and ammonia scavengers.
trial_title: The ENERGY Study: An Open-Label Study to Evaluate the Safety, Tolerability, Pharmacokinetics, and Pharmacodynamics of INZ-701 in Infants With Ectonucleotide Pyrophosphatase/ Phosphodiesterase 1 (ENPP1) Deficiency or ATP-binding Cassette Sub-family C Member 6 (ABCC6) Deficiency
diseases_targeted: ENPP1 Deficiency; ABCC6 Deficiency; Generalized Arterial Calcification of Infancy
inclusion_criteria: Confirmed post-natal molecular genetic diagnosis of ENPP1 Deficiency or ABCC6 Deficiency with biallelic mutations | Clinical manifestations of Generalized Arterial Calcification of Infancy (GACI) or GACI-2 | Age from birth to <1 year at Baseline (Day 1) | Weight >=0.5 kg at first dose
exclusion_criteria: Clinically significant disease or laboratory abnormality unrelated to ENPP1 or ABCC6 deficiency that may preclude participation, including uncontrolled thyroid disease or unrelated connective tissue, bone, mineral, or muscle disease | Care withdrawn or receiving end of life care or hospice only | Known malignancy | Known intolerance to INZ-701 or any excipients | Concurrent participation in another non-Inozyme interventional study | Receipt of any non-Inozyme investigational new drug within 5 half-lives or within 4 weeks prior to first dose, whichever is longer, or use of an investigational device
prior_therapies: No investigational drug within 5 half-lives or 4 weeks prior to first dose
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial is for ENPP1 or ABCC6 deficiency (GACI), while the patient has ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency. Age and sex fit, but the required disease cohort is not met.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Genetically confirmed ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency; History of severe neonatal hyperammonemic crisis; Currently clinically stable on therapy; Male; Age 3 months
judge_comment: Correct: The patient has OTC deficiency, while the trial targets ENPP1 or ABCC6 deficiency (GACI). This is a hard disease mismatch per rubric, warranting an F regardless of age/sex fit.

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: Phase II Single-Arm Study of Enfortumab Vedotin (EV) Plus Pembrolizumab in the Treatment of Locally Advanced or Metastatic Bladder Cancer of Variant Histology
diseases_targeted: Bladder Adenocarcinoma; Bladder Squamous Cell Carcinoma; Bladder Cancer (locally advanced); Bladder Cancer (metastatic); Renal Pelvis Carcinoma; Ureter Carcinoma; Urethral Carcinoma; Urachal Adenocarcinoma
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | ECOG 0–1 | Metastatic disease or unresectable locally advanced disease | Variant or non-urothelial bladder cancer of epithelial origin; predominant > 50% variant or non-urothelial in mixed tumors | Eligible primary sites include ureter, urethra, urachus, or renal pelvis | Measurable disease per RECIST 1.1 | Adequate organ and marrow function within 28 days of C1D1 | Tumor tissue available for submission or agree to undergo biopsy | Female of childbearing potential: negative pregnancy test prior to therapy | Use of effective contraception during treatment and for 6 months after last dose | Completion of all prior cancer therapy >= 4 weeks before start of study therapy | Life expectancy > 12 weeks
exclusion_criteria: Neuroendocrine histology (small cell or large cell) or non-epithelial bladder tumors (e.g., bladder sarcoma, carcinosarcoma, paraganglioma, melanoma, primary lymphoma, lymphoepithelioma-like carcinoma) | Chemotherapy or radiotherapy within 4 weeks prior to study entry or unresolved >= grade 2 toxicities from prior treatment (except alopecia) | Receipt of other investigational agents or an investigational device within 21 days before first dose | Allergic reactions to compounds of similar chemical or biologic composition to study agents | Ongoing sensory or motor neuropathy grade >= 2 | Prior treatment with enfortumab vedotin or PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitors (including maintenance) | Uncontrolled diabetes mellitus with HbA1c >= 8% or HbA1c 7% to < 8% with symptomatic polyuria or polydipsia | Active central nervous system metastases | Another active malignancy within 24 months except for permitted in-situ or localized cancers | Currently receiving systemic antimicrobial therapy for active infection or high-dose steroids (> 10 mg prednisone equivalent) | Pregnancy or positive pregnancy test at baseline | Breastfeeding | Active autoimmune disease requiring systemic treatment within the past 2 years | Hepatitis B surface antigen positive | Active hepatitis C virus infection (HCV RNA detected) | Active tuberculosis | History of active keratitis or corneal ulcerations | History of allogeneic tissue or solid organ transplant | Congestive heart failure NYHA class III or IV, unstable angina, or serious cardiac arrhythmias within 6 months prior to first dose | Other uncontrolled illness (including cardiac arrhythmia or psychiatric illness) that would limit compliance
prior_therapies: Any number of prior systemic therapies allowed (including untreated); Washout >= 4 weeks from prior surgery, radiotherapy, chemotherapy, immunotherapy, or investigational therapy; Washout >= 21 days from other investigational agents
reasoning: The trial requires variant or non-urothelial epithelial bladder cancer (>50% variant), while the patient has metastatic urothelial carcinoma. This is a required histologic subtype mismatch and a hard exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: (none)
judge_comment: The trial explicitly requires variant or non-urothelial epithelial bladder cancer (>50% variant in mixed tumors). The patient has metastatic urothelial carcinoma, which definitively does not meet this required histologic subtype. This is a hard exclusion per the rubric (required biomarker/subtype mismatch), so F is correct.

question_text: A 55-year-old female has severe, seropositive rheumatoid arthritis refractory to methotrexate and two prior biologic agents (adalimumab and tocilizumab). She has active disease with a DAS28 score of 5.5. Critically, she has a history of treated Hepatitis B (HBsAg negative, anti-HBc positive) and moderate chronic kidney disease with an eGFR of 45 mL/min/1.73m². What are trial options for her?
trial_title: A Randomized, Parallel-group, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled, Multicenter Phase III Trial to Evaluate Efficacy and Safety of Secukinumab Administered Subcutaneously Versus Placebo, in Combination With a Glucocorticoid Taper Regimen, in Patients With Polymyalgia Rheumatica (PMR)
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 50 years. | Male or non-pregnant, non-lactating female. | Diagnosis of polymyalgia rheumatica per ACR/EULAR criteria with bilateral shoulder pain and elevated CRP (>= 10 mg/L) and/or ESR (>= 30 mm/hr). | ACR/EULAR optional classification criteria totaling >= 4 points: morning stiffness > 45 min; hip pain or restricted range of motion; absence of rheumatoid factor and/or anti-citrullinated protein antibodies; absence of other joint involvement. | Treated with prednisone >= 10 mg/day (or equivalent) for at least 8 consecutive weeks at any time prior to screening. | At least one PMR relapse while tapering prednisone >= 5 mg/day within the past 12 weeks prior to baseline, with relapse defined by recurrence of bilateral shoulder/hip girdle pain and inflammatory stiffness not due to mimicking diseases, and elevated ESR (>= 30 mm/hr) and/or CRP (> ULN) attributable to PMR at relapse and/or screening. | Following the latest PMR relapse, treated per local recommendations and on prednisone 7.5–25 mg/day at screening and during screening.
exclusion_criteria: Evidence or history of giant cell arteritis (cranial symptoms, extremity claudication, suggestive imaging and/or temporal artery biopsy). | Concurrent rheumatoid arthritis, other inflammatory arthritis, or other connective tissue diseases (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus, systemic sclerosis, vasculitis, myositis, mixed connective tissue disease, ankylosing spondylitis). | Concurrent diagnosis or history of neuropathic muscular diseases or fibromyalgia. | Inadequately treated hypothyroidism (e.g., persistent symptoms or non-normalized TSH despite replacement). | Previous exposure to secukinumab or other biologics directly targeting IL-17 or the IL-17 receptor. | Treatment with tocilizumab or other IL-6/IL-6 receptor inhibitors within 12 weeks or within 5 half-lives (whichever is longer) prior to baseline; non-responders or those who relapsed during such treatment are excluded.
prior_therapies: Prior prednisone >= 10 mg/day for >= 8 consecutive weeks.; On prednisone 7.5–25 mg/day at screening.; Washout from IL-6/IL-6 receptor inhibitors >= 12 weeks or >= 5 half-lives prior to baseline.
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets polymyalgia rheumatica and explicitly excludes patients with rheumatoid arthritis, while the patient has seropositive rheumatoid arthritis.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 55 years; Female; Seropositive rheumatoid arthritis; Active disease (DAS28 5.5)
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to methotrexate; Prior adalimumab; Prior tocilizumab; Failed two prior biologic agents
judge_comment: Correct: There is a hard exclusion due to disease mismatch (trial is for PMR, patient has RA) and an explicit exclusion listing concurrent rheumatoid arthritis. Grade F is appropriate.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: A Randomized, Open-label, Pilot Study to Evaluate the Fecal Microbiota Transplantation (FMT) in the Treatment of Ulcerative Colitis
inclusion_criteria: Active ulcerative colitis: Partial Mayo score >= 3 with each subscore > 1 | Sexually active males and females of childbearing potential agree to use effective contraception during the study | Females of childbearing potential must have a negative urine pregnancy test at enrollment and on Week 1 Day 1 prior to dosing
exclusion_criteria: Severe ulcerative colitis (Mayo score > 7) | Unable to take retention enema or multiple oral capsules | Pregnant, breastfeeding, or planning pregnancy during the study | Receipt of systemic non-topical antibiotics within 14 days before Day 1 | Active HIV infection | Active hepatitis B infection | Active hepatitis C infection | History of recurrent Clostridioides difficile infection | Prior fecal microbiota transplantation within 6 months | Other active gastrointestinal conditions (e.g., irritable bowel syndrome, microscopic colitis, celiac disease, short gut syndrome, colostomy, colectomy, gastrointestinal fistulae or strictures, chronic parasitic infections, diverticulitis) | Known bile acid diarrhea | Compromised immune system (primary immune disorders or clinical immunosuppression) | Current systemic corticosteroids at prednisone > 20 mg/day or equivalent | History of active cancer and/or ongoing chemotherapy (superficial non-metastatic cancers and maintenance chemotherapy are permitted) | Use of an investigational drug within 90 days before screening | Significant uncontrolled systemic disease | Life expectancy < 1 year | Absolute neutrophil count < 500/µL

patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe Crohn's disease; Fistulizing disease; CDAI score 350; Active perianal fistula with draining seton in place
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 8-year-old female with PMM2-CDG (Congenital Disorder of Glycosylation). She has confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2 and exhibits moderate cerebellar dysfunction with a recent ICARS score of 35. Her family is highly motivated for research participation.
trial_title: A Phase 2,Double-Blind,Randomized Clinical Trial to Explore the Safety,Tolerability,Efficacy, and Pharmacokinetics of PRAX-562 in Pediatric Participants With Developmental and Epileptic Encephalopathies Followed by Open-Label Extension(OLE)
inclusion_criteria: Documented rare missense variant in SCN2A with seizure onset in the first 3 months of life, or documented de novo missense variant in SCN8A with seizure onset in the first 6 months of life. | At least 8 countable motor seizures in the 4 weeks immediately prior to Screening. | At least 8 countable motor seizures during the 28-day Baseline Observation Period.
exclusion_criteria: Clinically significant or known pathogenic/likely pathogenic genetic variant other than in SCN2A or SCN8A, or a genetic variant that may explain or contribute to epilepsy and/or developmental disorder. | Documented, functionally characterized loss-of-function missense variant, or presumed loss-of-function variant (nonsense or frameshift), or clinical evidence that prior exposure to a sodium channel blocker worsened seizures. | Two or more episodes of convulsive status epilepticus requiring hospitalization and intubation in the 6 months prior to Screening.
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: The trial is for SCN2A or SCN8A encephalopathy with specific genetic requirements, while the patient has PMM2-CDG with PMM2 variants—constituting a disease and required biomarker mismatch. The trial also excludes participants with pathogenic variants other than SCN2A/SCN8A.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of PMM2-CDG; Confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2; ICARS score 35 (moderate cerebellar dysfunction); Age 8 years
judge_comment: Disease mismatch (PMM2-CDG vs SCN2A/SCN8A encephalopathy) is a hard exclusion. The trial also requires SCN2A or SCN8A variants and explicitly excludes other pathogenic variants, which the patient has (PMM2). Grade F is correct per rubric.

question_text: What are trial options for a 66 year old male with hx hypertension, afib, T2DM and mCRPC, now progressing on enzalutamide? He has been on Lupron+Zytiga for 3 years, with new liver and bone metastases which are all PSMA PET avid. He’s tolerated therapy well overall except for grade 2 fatigue.
trial_title: Intermittent Fasting Using a Fasting-Mimicking Diet to Improve Prostate Cancer Control and Metabolic Outcomes
inclusion_criteria: Metastatic castrate-sensitive prostate adenocarcinoma confirmed by biopsy | Metastatic disease confirmed by biopsy or MRI | Receiving or planning to start first-line intensified androgen deprivation therapy within 30 days with abiraterone, apalutamide, enzalutamide, or darolutamide | Current or prior chemotherapy permitted
exclusion_criteria: Allergy to any ingredients on the Xentigen Ingredient List | Diabetes not on stable doses of antihyperglycemic medication for >= 6 months or without physician consent to safely hold antihyperglycemics during the 5 days of FMD | Regularly practicing a fasting diet that would impact study participation | Significant cardiac, pulmonary, liver disease, or ongoing alcohol/drug abuse precluding enrollment | Body mass index < 20 kg/m2 | Actively trying to lose weight | Use of weight loss medications (e.g., naltrexone/bupropion, liraglutide, orlistat) | Planning to receive weight loss surgery in the next 6 months | Self-reported weight loss >= 10% in the last 6 months
prior_therapies: Receiving or planning first-line intensified ADT with abiraterone, apalutamide, enzalutamide, or darolutamide within 30 days of registration; Prior or current chemotherapy allowed
reasoning: The trial enrolls metastatic castrate-sensitive prostate cancer patients starting first-line intensified ADT, while the patient has metastatic castration-resistant disease after progression on enzalutamide—an explicit disease/setting mismatch.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 66 years; Male sex; Metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer; Progression on enzalutamide; PSMA PET avid liver and bone metastases
patient_prior_therapies: Progression on enzalutamide; Prior abiraterone (Zytiga) with leuprolide (Lupron) for 3 years
judge_comment: The trial requires metastatic castrate-sensitive prostate cancer initiating first-line intensified ADT, while the patient has metastatic castration-resistant disease after enzalutamide. This is a required stage/setting mismatch (hard exclusion), so F is appropriate.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: A Pilot Study Examining Low Sulfur Diet as Treatment for Persistent Symptoms in Quiescent Crohn's Disease
inclusion_criteria: Prior diagnosis of Crohn's disease based on endoscopic, radiographic, and/or histologic findings | Quiescent Crohn's disease defined by fecal calprotectin < 150 mcg/g stool and/or absence of inflammation on colonoscopy within 30 and 90 days of enrollment, respectively | Persistent symptoms defined by abdominal pain and/or diarrhea T-scores >= 55 on the NIH PROMIS-GI scale
exclusion_criteria: Prior total colectomy | Presence of an end ileostomy or colostomy | Changes in immunosuppressive medications within the past 4 weeks | Use of antibiotics or probiotics within the past 4 weeks | Active or suspected gastrointestinal stricture or stenosis | Habitual vegetarian or vegan diet | Unable or unwilling to follow a low sulfur diet | Underweight (BMI < 18.5 kg/m2) or significant unintentional weight loss (> 7.5% in the past 3 months) | Currently pregnant or breastfeeding
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: The trial requires quiescent Crohn's disease (remission) with objective evidence, whereas the patient has active moderate-to-severe, fistulizing Crohn's disease (CDAI 350), a definitive stage/setting mismatch.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe Crohn's disease; Fistulizing disease; CDAI score 350; Active perianal fistula with draining seton in place
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab
judge_comment: Trial requires quiescent (remission) Crohn’s, while the patient has active moderate-to-severe, fistulizing disease—this is a required stage/setting the patient definitively lacks, which is a HARD EXCLUSION per the rubric. Age/sex fit, but the setting mismatch alone warrants F. The grader’s reasoning aligns.

question_text: 40 year old man with recurrent glioblastoma. Diagnosed 1 year ago, underwent gross total resection with confirmation of GBM, IDH wildtype. Completed adjuvant radiation + concurrent temozolomide and then adjuvant temozolomide. Three months after completing adjuvant therapy, MRI shows recurrence. ECOG 1 and no other medical issues. What are trial options?
trial_title: Adopting a Functional Precision Medicine Approach For Individualized Pediatric Cancer Treatments
diseases_targeted: Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (recurrent); Acute Myeloid Leukemia (recurrent); Brain Tumor (recurrent); Brainstem Glioma (recurrent); Ependymoma (recurrent); Gliosarcoma (recurrent); Large Cell Lymphoma (recurrent); Lymphoblastic Lymphoma (recurrent); Rhabdomyosarcoma (recurrent); Soft Tissue Sarcoma (recurrent); Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (refractory); Hodgkin Lymphoma (refractory); Malignant Germ Cell Tumor (refractory); Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia, BCR-ABL1 Positive (refractory)
inclusion_criteria: Age <=21 years | Recurrent or refractory cancer (suspected or confirmed) | Scheduled for or recently had tumor biopsy/excision or bone marrow aspirate | Willing to provide blood or buccal swab for genetic testing
exclusion_criteria: No malignant tissue available or accessible | Insufficient malignant tissue for ex vivo drug testing and/or genomic profiling | Newly diagnosed tumors | Tumors with high (>90%) cure rate with safe standard therapy
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: The trial restricts enrollment to age ≤21 years, while the patient is 40, which is outside the allowed age range. Thus, the patient is ineligible despite having a recurrent brain tumor.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 40 years; Male; Recurrent glioblastoma; IDH wildtype; Status post gross total resection; Completed radiation with concurrent temozolomide and adjuvant temozolomide; ECOG 1; No other medical issues
patient_prior_therapies: Gross total resection; Adjuvant radiation with concurrent temozolomide; Adjuvant temozolomide
judge_comment: Age is a hard exclusion: trial allows ≤21 years, patient is 40. This alone mandates grade F regardless of other factors. The grader correctly identified and applied this.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. trial_title: A Sequential Multiple Assignment Randomized Trial (SMART) Feasibility Pilot Developing and Optimizing Patient-Tailored Adaptive Treatment Strategies (ATS) for Acute Severe Ulcerative Colitis (ASUC)
inclusion_criteria: Age 18–75 years | Diagnosis of ulcerative colitis confirmed by clinical history, endoscopy, and histology | Current hospitalization for ulcerative colitis treatment with expected initiation of IV corticosteroids | Acute severe ulcerative colitis: >= 4 bloody bowel movements/day plus at least one of the following—temperature > 37.5 C, pulse > 90 BPM, hemoglobin < 10.5 g/dL, ESR >= 30 mm/h, weight loss > 5 lb over 3 months, CRP >= 3.0 mg/dL, fecal calprotectin > 782 mg/kg (within 4 weeks), or oral corticosteroid use for >= 14 days at a dose equivalent to >= 30 mg/day | Prior exposure to at least one anti-TNF agent (adalimumab, certolizumab, infliximab, or golimumab; originator or biosimilar) | Able to take oral medication and adhere to the study regimen | Females of reproductive potential: negative pregnancy test at admission and agreement to use highly effective contraception during the 3-month follow-up
exclusion_criteria: Indeterminate colitis, microscopic colitis, ischemic colitis, infectious colitis, or clinical features suggestive of Crohn's disease | Receiving continuous IV corticosteroids for >= 72 hours prior to enrollment | Pregnant or breastfeeding | Toxic megacolon during current admission | Hypersensitivity to methylprednisolone, cyclosporine, tofacitinib, or upadacitinib | Prior exposure to upadacitinib | Ongoing severe infection, including untreated or inadequately treated latent or active tuberculosis | Active CMV colitis defined as > 5 inclusion bodies per high powered field at baseline (unless allowed with concomitant antiviral therapy per teams) | Investigational agent or procedure within 30 days or five half-lives prior to baseline | Current malignancy except non-metastatic basal cell or squamous cell carcinoma of the skin | History of colectomy (total or subtotal), ileoanal pouch, Kock pouch, or ileostomy, or planned bowel surgery | Neutropenia (ANC < 1200/µL) or total white blood cell count < 2500/µL | Hemoglobin < 8 mg/dL | Platelet count < 80000/µL | eGFR < 30 mL/min/1.73 m2 | ALT >= 2 x ULN or AST >= 2 x ULN | Cirrhosis with Child-Pugh score >= 5 | Uncontrolled hypertension (systolic > 160 mmHg or diastolic > 100 mmHg despite therapy) | Recent (within 6 months) cerebrovascular accident, myocardial infarction, or coronary stenting | Recent (within 6 months) moderate-to-severe congestive heart failure (NYHA class III–IV) | Inherited or acquired thrombophilia (e.g., antiphospholipid syndrome, Factor V Leiden, prothrombin G20210A, deficiencies of antithrombin, protein C, protein S, heparin cofactor II, PAI-1/plasminogen disorders, dysfibrinogenemia, Factor XII deficiency) | Total cholesterol < 80 mg/dL at baseline | Chronic HBV infection with positive HBsAg and detectable DNA not on suppressive therapy; HCV RNA positive; or HIV with CD4 < 350/µL or AIDS-defining opportunistic infection | Solid organ or bone marrow transplant within 1 year or expected within 6 months | History of more than one episode of herpes zoster, disseminated zoster, or disseminated herpes simplex | Current use of medications increasing venous thromboembolism risk (e.g., hormone replacement therapy, testosterone, tamoxifen) | Live or attenuated live vaccines within 6 weeks prior to baseline or scheduled during study or within 140 days after last dose | History of lymphoproliferative disorder, lymphoma, leukemia, myeloproliferative disorder, multiple myeloma, or signs/symptoms of current hematologic disease | History of spontaneous gastrointestinal perforation (other than appendicitis or mechanical injury), diverticulitis, or significantly increased risk of GI perforation per investigator | Concomitant strong CYP3A4 inducers or inhibitors, including grapefruit or grapefruit juice | Conditions affecting oral drug absorption (e.g., gastrectomy, significant diabetic gastroenteropathy, gastric bypass; gastric banding permitted) | Any clinically significant medical condition or other reason that, in the investigator’s opinion, would interfere with participation or pose risk
prior_therapies: Prior exposure to at least one anti-TNF agent (adalimumab, certolizumab, infliximab, or golimumab; originator or biosimilar)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets acute severe ulcerative colitis and excludes Crohn’s disease. Additionally, the trial is restricted to females, whereas the patient is male.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe Crohn's disease; Fistulizing disease; CDAI score 350; Active perianal fistula with draining seton in place
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab
judge_comment: Hard exclusions apply: disease mismatch (Crohn’s vs trial for acute severe ulcerative colitis) and sex restriction (trial limited to females; patient is male). F is correct per rubric.

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 8-year-old female with PMM2-CDG (Congenital Disorder of Glycosylation). She has confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2 and exhibits moderate cerebellar dysfunction with a recent ICARS score of 35. Her family is highly motivated for research participation.
trial_title: A Phase 1 Dose Escalation Trial Evaluating an Intravenously Administered Recombinant Adeno-Associated Virus Serotype rh.74 (AAVrh.74) Vector Containing the Human Plakophilin-2a (PKP2a) Coding Sequence (RP-A601; AAVrh.74-PKP2a) in Subjects With Arrhythmogenic Cardiomyopathy Arising From Pathogenic PKP2 Variants (PKP2-ACM)
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Clinical diagnosis of arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy per 2010 revised Task Force Criteria | Pathogenic or likely pathogenic truncating variant in PKP2 | Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator in place for >= 6 months | Premature ventricular contraction frequency >= 500 per 24 hours by ambulatory monitoring | Left ventricular ejection fraction >= 50%
exclusion_criteria: Anti-AAVrh.74 neutralizing antibody titer > 1:40 | Cardiomyopathy due to a genetic etiology other than PKP2 truncating variant | Previous participation in a gene transfer or gene editing study | Severe right ventricular dysfunction | New York Heart Association Class IV heart failure
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: The trial targets arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy with pathogenic PKP2 variants and requires adults ≥18, while the patient has PMM2-CDG with PMM2 variants and is 8 years old. This is a clear disease, biomarker, and age mismatch.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of PMM2-CDG; Confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2; ICARS score 35 (moderate cerebellar dysfunction); Age 8 years
judge_comment: Clear hard exclusions: disease mismatch (PMM2-CDG vs trial for PKP2-related ACM), age window conflict (8 < 18), and required biomarker mismatch (PKP2 truncating variants required; patient has PMM2). Grader’s F and reasoning are correct.

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 8-year-old female with PMM2-CDG (Congenital Disorder of Glycosylation). She has confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2 and exhibits moderate cerebellar dysfunction with a recent ICARS score of 35. Her family is highly motivated for research participation.
trial_title: A Phase 1b Study of Menin Inhibitor SNDX-5613 in Combination With Daunorubicin and Cytarabine in Newly Diagnosed Patients With Acute Myeloid Leukemia and NPM1 Mutated/FLT3 Wildtype or MLL/KMT2A Rearranged Disease.
diseases_targeted: Acute Myeloid Leukemia (NPM1 mutated, FLT3 wildtype); Acute Myeloid Leukemia (KMT2A rearranged)
inclusion_criteria: Age 18-75 years with untreated acute myeloid leukemia that is NPM1-mutated/FLT3-ITD wildtype and FLT3-TKD wildtype, or KMT2A-rearranged, and candidate for intensive induction chemotherapy | ECOG performance status <= 2 (Karnofsky >= 60%) | Total bilirubin <= 2 x ULN (except Gilbert's syndrome) | AST <= 3 x ULN | ALT <= 3 x ULN | Glomerular filtration rate >= 60 mL/min | HIV infection allowed if on effective antiretroviral therapy with undetectable viral load within 6 months | Chronic hepatitis B allowed if viral load undetectable on suppressive therapy | History of hepatitis C allowed if treated and cured, or on treatment with undetectable viral load | Prior or concurrent malignancy allowed if it will not interfere with assessment of the investigational regimen | If cardiac disease/history of cardiotoxic therapy: NYHA class 2B or better | Left ventricular ejection fraction >= 50% (or >= 45% if no CHF or cardiac symptoms) by TTE or MUGA | White blood cells < 25 x 10^9/L; hydroxyurea and leukapheresis permitted prior to enrollment and must stop within 24 hours before protocol therapy | Previously untreated AML with no prior therapy other than hydroxyurea (or ATRA given for suspected APL that is later ruled out)
exclusion_criteria: Allergic reactions to compounds similar to SNDX-5613 (revumenib), daunorubicin, or cytarabine | Uncontrolled intercurrent illness making participation unsafe | Use of strong or moderate CYP3A4 inhibitors, strong CYP3A4 inducers (except antifungal as specified), or sensitive/narrow therapeutic index MATE1 substrates within 7 days of enrollment | Pregnancy or breastfeeding | Isolated myeloid sarcoma without blood or marrow AML involvement | Acute promyelocytic leukemia (FAB M3) | Active central nervous system involvement by AML | Uncontrolled symptomatic disseminated intravascular coagulopathy with active bleeding or thrombosis | QTcF >= 450 ms at screening or factors conferring high risk of QT prolongation/arrhythmia (unless cleared by cardiology as specified) | Projected to exceed lifetime anthracycline exposure > 550 mg/m^2 daunorubicin equivalent (> 400 mg/m^2 with prior mediastinal radiation) | Upper gastrointestinal conditions that may affect oral drug absorption or ingestion (e.g., gastric bypass, gastroparesis) | Cirrhosis with Child-Pugh class B or C | Down syndrome | Myelodysplastic syndromes previously treated with intensive induction regimens similar to 7+3
prior_therapies: No prior AML therapy except hydroxyurea; All-trans retinoic acid allowed if given for suspected APL that is later ruled out; Hydroxyurea and leukapheresis permitted for WBC control prior to enrollment (must stop within 24 hours before protocol therapy); Antiretroviral therapy allowed if HIV viral load is undetectable
reasoning: The trial enrolls adults (18–75) with specific subtypes of acute myeloid leukemia, while the patient is an 8-year-old with PMM2-CDG, so both disease and age do not meet required criteria.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of PMM2-CDG; Confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2; ICARS score 35 (moderate cerebellar dysfunction); Age 8 years
judge_comment: Hard exclusions apply: disease mismatch (PMM2-CDG vs AML cohorts) and age outside 18–75 window. F is correct and the reasoning identifies both key exclusions.

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 8-year-old female with PMM2-CDG (Congenital Disorder of Glycosylation). She has confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2 and exhibits moderate cerebellar dysfunction with a recent ICARS score of 35. Her family is highly motivated for research participation.
trial_title: A Phase II Study of Allogeneic Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation With Briquilimab-Based Conditioning in Participants With GATA2 Deficiency
inclusion_criteria: Age 6–70 years | Germline deleterious mutation in GATA2 confirmed by targeted sequencing | Clinical manifestations consistent with GATA2 deficiency (e.g., severe/recurrent infections; monocytes <190/µL, B cells <61/µL, NK cells <126/µL; myelodysplastic syndrome by WHO) | Early-stage GATA2 deficiency: hypocellular marrow for age, <5% blasts, and normal/favorable cytogenetics (good/very good risk groups plus trisomy 8) | Availability of suitable donor: 8/8 HLA-matched related or unrelated, 7/8 HLA-matched unrelated, or haploidentical related donor | Karnofsky or Lansky performance status >= 40% | Left ventricular ejection fraction > 40% | Total bilirubin <= 2.5 x ULN | AST and ALT <= 5 x ULN | Adult creatinine <= 2.0 mg/dL and creatinine clearance >= 30 mL/min | Pediatric creatinine < 1.5 mg/dL and creatinine clearance > 30 mL/min/1.73m^2 | Pulmonary function: FEV1 and adjusted DLCO > 30%; if unable to perform due to age, no dyspnea at rest and no supplemental oxygen requirement | HBV or HCV seropositive allowed if HBV DNA <100 IU/mL or HCV RNA undetectable and hepatology approval
exclusion_criteria: Hematopoietic Cell Transplantation-Comorbidity Index (HCT-CI) score > 8 | Receipt of investigational agents within 4 weeks before treatment initiation (except virus-specific T cells for treatment of viral infection/reactivation prior to allogeneic HCT) | History of hematologic malignancy (e.g., AML, CMML); MDS allowed | History of allergic reactions to compounds similar to study agents (fludarabine, cyclophosphamide, tacrolimus, mycophenolate, G-CSF) | Presence of active malignancy (virus-driven malignancies allowed); MDS allowed | HIV infection | Pregnancy | Uncontrolled intercurrent illness or social situations limiting compliance with study requirements
prior_therapies: No investigational agents within 4 weeks before treatment initiation (except virus-specific T cells for viral infection/reactivation)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial is for GATA2 deficiency with a required germline GATA2 mutation, while the patient has PMM2-CDG with PMM2 variants. This fails the trial’s disease/biomarker requirement.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of PMM2-CDG; Confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2; ICARS score 35 (moderate cerebellar dysfunction); Age 8 years
judge_comment: Clear hard exclusion: the trial targets GATA2 deficiency and requires a germline GATA2 mutation, while the patient has PMM2-CDG with PMM2 variants. Disease and required biomarker mismatch → F. Grader applied rubric correctly.

question_text: What are trial options for a 3-month-old male infant with genetically confirmed Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency? He presented on day 3 of life with a severe hyperammonemic crisis (ammonia 720 μmol/L) and is now stable on a regimen of dietary protein restriction and ammonia scavengers.
trial_title: A Phase II Study of Allogeneic Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation With Briquilimab-Based Conditioning in Participants With GATA2 Deficiency
inclusion_criteria: Age 6–70 years | Germline deleterious mutation in GATA2 confirmed by targeted sequencing | Clinical manifestations consistent with GATA2 deficiency (e.g., severe/recurrent infections; monocytes <190/µL, B cells <61/µL, NK cells <126/µL; myelodysplastic syndrome by WHO) | Early-stage GATA2 deficiency: hypocellular marrow for age, <5% blasts, and normal/favorable cytogenetics (good/very good risk groups plus trisomy 8) | Availability of suitable donor: 8/8 HLA-matched related or unrelated, 7/8 HLA-matched unrelated, or haploidentical related donor | Karnofsky or Lansky performance status >= 40% | Left ventricular ejection fraction > 40% | Total bilirubin <= 2.5 x ULN | AST and ALT <= 5 x ULN | Adult creatinine <= 2.0 mg/dL and creatinine clearance >= 30 mL/min | Pediatric creatinine < 1.5 mg/dL and creatinine clearance > 30 mL/min/1.73m^2 | Pulmonary function: FEV1 and adjusted DLCO > 30%; if unable to perform due to age, no dyspnea at rest and no supplemental oxygen requirement | HBV or HCV seropositive allowed if HBV DNA <100 IU/mL or HCV RNA undetectable and hepatology approval
exclusion_criteria: Hematopoietic Cell Transplantation-Comorbidity Index (HCT-CI) score > 8 | Receipt of investigational agents within 4 weeks before treatment initiation (except virus-specific T cells for treatment of viral infection/reactivation prior to allogeneic HCT) | History of hematologic malignancy (e.g., AML, CMML); MDS allowed | History of allergic reactions to compounds similar to study agents (fludarabine, cyclophosphamide, tacrolimus, mycophenolate, G-CSF) | Presence of active malignancy (virus-driven malignancies allowed); MDS allowed | HIV infection | Pregnancy | Uncontrolled intercurrent illness or social situations limiting compliance with study requirements
prior_therapies: No investigational agents within 4 weeks before treatment initiation (except virus-specific T cells for viral infection/reactivation)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets GATA2 deficiency with a required GATA2 germline mutation, while the patient has OTC deficiency with an OTC mutation. Additionally, the patient is 3 months old, outside the trial’s 6–70 years age range.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Genetically confirmed ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency; History of severe neonatal hyperammonemic crisis; Currently clinically stable on therapy; Male; Age 3 months
judge_comment: Hard exclusions apply: disease mismatch (OTC vs GATA2) and age outside trial range (3 months vs 6–70 years). Grader correctly assigned F and reasoning aligns with rubric.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
trial_title: A Phase IIIb, Randomized, Multicenter, Open-label Study to Assess the Efficacy of Durvalumab Plus Tremelimumab Versus Pembrolizumab in Combination With Platinum-based Chemotherapy for First-line Treatment in Metastatic Non-small Cell Lung Cancer Patients With Non-squamous Histology Who Have Mutations and/or Co-mutations in STK11, KEAP1, or KRAS (TRITON)
inclusion_criteria: Histologically or cytologically confirmed Stage IV non-squamous NSCLC not amenable to curative surgery or radiation | Tumor harbors STK11 or KEAP1 or KRAS mutation (co-mutations allowed) | Tumor lacks activating EGFR mutations and lacks ALK fusions | No prior chemotherapy or other systemic therapy for metastatic NSCLC | Prior platinum-containing adjuvant, neoadjuvant, or definitive chemoradiation allowed if progression > 6 months from end of last therapy | No prior exposure to immune-mediated therapy (excluding therapeutic anti-cancer vaccines) within 6 months of randomization | ECOG performance status 0–1 | Life expectancy >= 12 weeks | At least one measurable lesion per RECIST 1.1 (>= 10 mm) not previously irradiated and suitable for repeated measurements | Adequate organ and bone marrow function | Negative pregnancy test for women of childbearing potential | Use of effective contraception (male and female) | Body weight > 30 kg
exclusion_criteria: Acute or uncontrolled diseases or history of allogeneic organ transplant | Mixed small cell lung cancer and NSCLC histology | Major surgery within 28 days prior to first dose or need for major surgery during study | Active or prior autoimmune or inflammatory disorders (exceptions: vitiligo, alopecia, stable hypothyroidism on replacement, chronic skin conditions not requiring systemic therapy, inactive disease > 5 years after consultation, celiac disease controlled by diet) | Medical contraindication to platinum-based doublet chemotherapy | History of another malignancy except curatively treated with no active disease >= 2 years or adequately resected non-melanoma skin cancer or curatively treated in situ disease | Persistent CTCAE Grade >= 2 toxicities from prior therapy (except alopecia and vitiligo); Grade <= 2 neuropathy may be allowed per investigator | Spinal cord compression unless asymptomatic and stable | Significant cardiac disease (e.g., symptomatic CHF, unstable angina, uncontrolled significant arrhythmias, symptomatic/uncontrolled atrial fibrillation, sustained ventricular tachycardia) | Concurrent anticancer chemotherapy, investigational product, biologic, or hormonal therapy (non-cancer hormonal therapy allowed) | Radiation therapy not meeting allowed criteria (definitive >= 6 months prior; or specific palliative settings) | Untreated or unstable brain metastases (must be treated and stable; not RECIST target lesions) | History of leptomeningeal carcinomatosis | Active tuberculosis infection | Active hepatitis: HBsAg positive or anti-HBc with detectable HBV DNA; HCV antibody positive with detectable HCV RNA; HBV/HCV or HBV/HDV coinfection | HIV infection not well controlled | Immunosuppressive medication within 14 days before first dose (exceptions: local/topical/inhaled steroids; physiologic doses <= 10 mg/day prednisone equivalent; premedication/single palliative dose) | Receipt of live attenuated vaccine within 30 days before first dose | Concurrent enrollment in another interventional clinical study (except observational or follow-up) | Hypersensitivity to study drugs or excipients | Pregnant or breastfeeding or planning pregnancy; breastfeeding restrictions apply during and after therapy
prior_therapies: No prior systemic therapy for metastatic NSCLC; Prior platinum-containing adjuvant/neoadjuvant or definitive chemoradiation allowed if progression > 6 months from last therapy; No prior immune-mediated therapy within 6 months before randomization
reasoning: The trial requires tumors to lack activating EGFR mutations and to be treatment-naïve for metastatic disease; the patient has an activating EGFR exon 19 deletion and has received osimertinib. These are explicit exclusion conflicts.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Non-small cell lung cancer; De novo metastatic disease (bone, liver); EGFR exon 19 deletion; ECOG 0; Age 40 years
judge_comment: The trial explicitly excludes tumors with activating EGFR mutations and requires no prior systemic therapy for metastatic NSCLC. The patient has an EGFR exon 19 deletion and received osimertinib, triggering hard exclusions. Grade F is correct.

question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.
trial_title: Effect of Acetylcholinesterase Inhibitors on Bone Metabolism and Fracture Risk Factors Among Older Adults With Mild to Moderate Alzheimer's Disease
inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of cognitive impairment (clinical, radiographic, or laboratory biomarker assessment) | Female: age >55 years or <55 years and >=12 months postmenopausal | Male: age >50 years | Geriatric Depression Scale score <6
exclusion_criteria: Current use of acetylcholinesterase inhibitor or memantine | History of bradycardia, heart block, long QT, unexplained syncope, or other contraindication to donepezil | ECG: heart rate <50 bpm, PR interval >200 ms, QTc >440 ms (men) or >460 ms (women), or atrioventricular block | Current use of osteoporosis medications (e.g., bisphosphonates, SERM, denosumab, teriparatide, abaloparatide, calcitonin) | Bisphosphonate use within the last 5 years | Use within the last 6 months of estrogens, testosterone, androgen deprivation therapy, aromatase inhibitors, antiepileptics, heparin, or thiazolidinediones | Disorders associated with secondary osteoporosis (e.g., collagen vascular disease, malabsorption, inflammatory bowel disease, severe liver disease/cirrhosis, hyperthyroidism) | History of low-trauma fracture of the humerus, wrist, or vertebra | History of hip fracture, hip replacement, or non-ambulatory status | Long-term corticosteroid use (>6 months) | History of Parkinson's disease, HIV, or Huntington's disease | History of solid organ transplantation | History of bariatric surgery or planned weight loss by bariatric surgery or weight loss medication in the next 12 months | Severe renal impairment (eGFR <30 mL/min) | Active malignancy undergoing chemotherapy, surgery, or radiation therapy (except non-melanoma skin cancer) | Estimated 1-year mortality >25%
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: The trial targets mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease, while the patient’s listed condition is dementia without an Alzheimer's diagnosis (amyloid PET and CSF amyloid are negative). This is a disease mismatch per the trial’s disease focus.
patient_biomarkers: Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 68 years; Male; Two-year history of progressive cognitive decline; MMSE score 19; Moderate-stage dementia; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
judge_comment: Disease mismatch is a hard exclusion. The trial targets Alzheimer’s disease (mild–moderate), while the patient is listed with dementia without an AD diagnosis; amyloid-negative profile further argues against AD. Thus F per rubric; no need to assess anchors.

question_text: What are trial options for a 3-month-old male infant with genetically confirmed Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency? He presented on day 3 of life with a severe hyperammonemic crisis (ammonia 720 μmol/L) and is now stable on a regimen of dietary protein restriction and ammonia scavengers.
trial_title: The ENERGY 3 Study: A Randomized, Controlled, Open-Label, Phase 3 Study to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of INZ-701 in Children With Ectonucleotide Pyrophosphatase/Phosphodiesterase 1 (ENPP1) Deficiency
inclusion_criteria: Biallelic ENPP1 mutations confirmed by a CAP/CLIA-certified (or regional equivalent) laboratory | Age >=1 and <13 years at Study Day 1 | Open growth plates of the distal femur and proximal tibia in both legs | Plasma pyrophosphate (PPi) <1400 nM at screening | 25-hydroxyvitamin D >=12 ng/mL at screening | Radiographic evidence of skeletal abnormalities with RSS >=2 | Negative serum pregnancy test for females of childbearing potential | Use of highly effective contraception for participants of childbearing potential during the study
exclusion_criteria: Clinically significant disease or laboratory abnormality not associated with ENPP1 Deficiency that would preclude participation or confound results | Use of prohibited medications: systemic corticosteroids >5 mg prednisone equivalent per day, anti-FGF23 agents, or oral/IV bisphosphonates | Unable or unwilling to discontinue calcitriol or other active vitamin D analogs within 7 days prior to Study Day 1 | Unable or unwilling to discontinue oral phosphate supplements within 36 hours prior to Study Day 1 if randomized to INZ-701 | Planned orthopedic surgery during the 52-week randomized treatment period | Known intolerance to INZ-701 or its excipients | Positive COVID-19 test within 5 days prior to randomization (if required per local policy) | Previous treatment with INZ-701 | Concurrent participation in another interventional clinical study or receipt of an investigational drug within 5 half-lives or 4 weeks prior to randomization (whichever is longer), or use of an investigational device
prior_therapies: Discontinue calcitriol or other active vitamin D analogs >=7 days prior to Study Day 1; Discontinue oral phosphate supplements >=36 hours prior to Study Day 1; No investigational drugs within 5 half-lives or 4 weeks prior to randomization (whichever is longer)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets ENPP1 deficiency requiring biallelic ENPP1 mutations, while the patient has OTC deficiency with an OTC mutation. Additionally, the patient is 3 months old, below the trial’s minimum age of 1 year.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Genetically confirmed ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency; History of severe neonatal hyperammonemic crisis; Currently clinically stable on therapy; Male; Age 3 months
judge_comment: Correct: There is a hard disease mismatch (ENPP1 deficiency vs patient’s OTC deficiency) and the patient is below the trial’s minimum age (3 months vs ≥1 year). Either triggers F.

trial_title: A Phase II, Escalating Dose, Open Label Study to Evaluate the Safety of Triheptanoin for the Prevention of Hypoglycemia in Patients With Medium Chain Acyl-CoA Dehydrogenase Deficiency (MCADD)
