reasoning: Hard exclusions: the trial targets MCAD deficiency, not OTC deficiency, and the minimum age is 16 years while the patient is 3 months old.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Genetically confirmed ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency; History of severe neonatal hyperammonemic crisis; Currently clinically stable on therapy; Male; Age 3 months
judge_comment: Correct: There is a hard disease mismatch (trial is for MCAD, patient has OTC deficiency) and a hard age conflict (trial min age 16 years vs patient 3 months). Either triggers F. The grader identified both.

question_text: What are trial options for a 3-month-old male infant with genetically confirmed Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency? He presented on day 3 of life with a severe hyperammonemic crisis (ammonia 720 μmol/L) and is now stable on a regimen of dietary protein restriction and ammonia scavengers.
trial_title: Promoting Prosocial Behavior in Syndromic Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities
diseases_targeted: Angelman Syndrome; Chromosome 15q Partial Deletion; Creatine Deficiency (X-linked); Fragile X Syndrome; Hamartoma Syndrome, Multiple; Rett Syndrome; Telomeric 22q13 Monosomy Syndrome; Tuberous Sclerosis
inclusion_criteria: Age 2-12 years at enrollment | Existing genetic syndrome confirmed by clinical or genetic diagnosis | Documented global developmental delay or intellectual disability | Estimated intellectual disability in any range | Disruptive behavior appropriate for remote, parent-implemented coaching per clinician judgment | Stable psychosocial and psychiatric treatments for 3 months prior to baseline
exclusion_criteria: High levels of aggression precluding remote or outpatient treatment or ABC Irritability score > 20 | Medical or psychiatric instability that may limit participation | Meaningful change in medication or psychosocial interventions within 3 months prior to baseline
prior_therapies: Stable psychosocial and psychiatric treatments for >=3 months prior to baseline
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets specific syndromic developmental disorders, not ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency. Additionally, the patient is 3 months old, below the trial's 2–12 year age range.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Genetically confirmed ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency; History of severe neonatal hyperammonemic crisis; Currently clinically stable on therapy; Male; Age 3 months
judge_comment: Correct: The trial does not include OTC deficiency (disease mismatch), and the patient is 3 months old vs trial minimum age 2 years. Either constitutes a hard exclusion, so F is appropriate.

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Phase 1, First-in-human, Multicentre, Open-label, Dose Escalation Study of [225Ac]-FPI-2068 in Adult Patients With Advanced Solid Tumours
diseases_targeted: Gastric Cancer; Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma; Metastatic Colorectal Carcinoma; Non-small Cell Lung Cancer; Pancreatic Ductal Adenocarcinoma; Renal Cell Carcinoma
inclusion_criteria: Histologically or cytologically confirmed solid tumor that is metastatic, locally advanced, recurrent, or inoperable | Disease progressed despite prior treatment and no additional effective standard therapy available, contraindicated, not tolerable, or refused | Measurable disease per RECIST v1.1 | ECOG performance status 0–1 | Adequate organ function
exclusion_criteria: Previous treatment with any systemic radiopharmaceutical | Prior anti-cancer therapy unless adequate washout and recovery from toxicities | Contraindications to or inability to perform required imaging procedures | Radiation therapy within 28 days prior to the first dose of [111In]-FPI-2107 | Uncontrolled pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, or ascites requiring recurrent drainage procedures (>= once per month) | Known CNS metastatic disease unless treated and stable
prior_therapies: Prior anti-cancer therapy permitted with adequate washout and recovery; Prior radiation therapy permitted if >28 days before first [111In]-FPI-2107 dose
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets gastric, head and neck SCC, metastatic colorectal, NSCLC, pancreatic ductal, and renal cell cancers; urothelial carcinoma is not listed. Therefore the patient’s metastatic urothelial carcinoma is not eligible.
patient_inclusion_criteria: (none)
judge_comment: Disease mismatch is a hard exclusion: trial diseases targeted do not include metastatic urothelial carcinoma. Despite broad inclusion text, the provided diseases_targeted list governs per rubric. F is correct.

question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.
trial_title: A Master Protocol for Three Independent, Seamlessly Enrolling, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled Efficacy and Safety Studies of ACP-204 in Adults With Alzheimer's Disease Psychosis
inclusion_criteria: Age >=55 and <=95 years | Possible or probable Alzheimer's disease per 2011 NIA-AA criteria | Psychosis meeting International Psychogeriatrics Association criteria in major or mild neurocognitive disorder | Evidence of amyloid plaque deposition by blood-based biomarker, PET, or CSF consistent with Alzheimer's disease | Prior brain MRI or CT consistent with Alzheimer's disease | MMSE score >=6 and <=24 | Psychotic symptoms for >=2 months | Stable dose of a cholinesterase inhibitor or memantine, if applicable
exclusion_criteria: Psychotic symptoms primarily attributable to delirium, substance abuse, or a medical or psychiatric condition other than dementia | History of cerebral amyloid angiopathy | History of epilepsy | History of central nervous system neoplasm | History of unexplained syncope | Atrial fibrillation | Symptomatic orthostatic hypotension | Protocol-defined exclusionary clinical laboratory findings | Treatment with anti-tau therapy or donanemab within 2 months prior to screening | In hospice receiving end-of-life palliative care or bedridden
prior_therapies: Stable dose of cholinesterase inhibitor; Stable dose of memantine
reasoning: The trial requires evidence of amyloid plaque deposition consistent with Alzheimer's disease, whereas the patient’s PET and CSF amyloid are negative. This fails a required biomarker criterion.
patient_biomarkers: Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 68 years; Male; Two-year history of progressive cognitive decline; MMSE score 19; Moderate-stage dementia; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
judge_comment: The trial requires evidence of amyloid plaque deposition; the patient’s PET and CSF amyloid are explicitly negative, indicating the required biomarker is definitively lacking. This triggers a HARD EXCLUSION, so F is correct.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
trial_title: A Phase 1b/2, Open-label, Randomized Study of Vudalimab in Combination With Chemotherapy or Pembrolizumab in Combination With Chemotherapy as First-line Treatment in Patients With Advanced Non-small Cell Lung Cancer
inclusion_criteria: Histologically confirmed locally advanced (unresectable) or metastatic nonsquamous non-small cell lung cancer | Documented absence of tumor-activating EGFR mutation, ALK rearrangement, ROS1 rearrangement, and other actionable driver alterations with approved first-line targeted therapies | PD-L1 IHC TPS < 49% | No prior systemic treatment for advanced/metastatic NSCLC | Measurable disease per RECIST 1.1 | ECOG performance status 0–1 | Life expectancy >= 3 months | Adequate liver function | Adequate kidney function | Adequate thyroid function | Adequate bone marrow function
exclusion_criteria: Active central nervous system metastases or carcinomatous meningitis (treated, radiologically stable brain metastases allowed) | Active known or suspected autoimmune disease | Systemic corticosteroids or other immunosuppressive medications within 14 days prior to first dose | Symptomatic interstitial lung disease | HIV infection with CD4+ T-cell count < 350 cells/µL, HIV viral load > 400 copies/mL, history of AIDS-defining opportunistic infection within 12 months, or not on stable ART >= 4 weeks | Positive test for hepatitis C RNA | Positive hepatitis B surface antigen or positive hepatitis B core antibody unless HBV DNA negative with ongoing monitoring | Clinically unstable or uncontrolled disorder or disease that could pose risk or interfere with study
prior_therapies: No prior systemic therapy for advanced/metastatic NSCLC
reasoning: Ineligible: the trial requires documented absence of activating EGFR mutations, whereas the patient has an EGFR exon 19 deletion, and it is restricted to first-line therapy with no prior systemic treatment for metastatic disease, but the patient has received osimertinib.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Non-small cell lung cancer; De novo metastatic disease (bone, liver); EGFR exon 19 deletion; ECOG 0; Age 40 years
judge_comment: Correct: The trial requires absence of activating EGFR mutations and no prior systemic therapy for advanced/metastatic disease. The patient has an EGFR exon 19 deletion and prior osimertinib. These are hard exclusions, so F is appropriate.

question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.
trial_title: A Phase I/IIa, Study to Evaluate the Safety, Tolerability and Exploratory Efficacy of SNK01 in Participants With Moderate Alzheimer's Disease
inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of Alzheimer's dementia per 2011 NIA-AA guidelines | Age 40 to 85 years | At least 6 years of formal education and fluency in test language | Females of childbearing potential: negative urine pregnancy test at screening and before first dose | Participants of reproductive potential agree to abstinence or effective contraception during treatment and for 30 days after last dose | Positive amyloid PET of the brain within the past 6 months | CDR-SB score >= 9.5 and < 16.0
exclusion_criteria: Substantial concomitant cerebrovascular disease (Fazekas Grade 3) | History of stroke or intracranial hemorrhage temporally related to worsening cognition | Substance use disorder not in remission for at least 12 months | History of cancer (except basal cell carcinoma) or cancer treatment within the last 5 years | Uncontrolled cardiovascular illness (e.g., chronic congestive heart failure, tachycardia, arrhythmias, uncontrolled hypertension) | Cerebrovascular accident, transient ischemic attack, or unexplained loss of consciousness within the last year | Significant pulmonary disease predisposing to hypoxia | Significant ischemic heart disease, myocardial infarction within the last 2 years and/or residual angina, orthopnea, conduction defects, or NYHA class III or IV heart disease | Significant liver disease (e.g., cirrhosis, active hepatitis B or C, primary or metastatic liver neoplasm) | ALT, AST, or alkaline phosphatase > 3 x ULN | Significant gastrointestinal disorders (e.g., GI bleeding within 2 years, malabsorption syndromes, post-gastrectomy, active peptic ulcer disease) | Clinically significant immunological disorders (e.g., significant allergies, lupus erythematosus, scleroderma) | Uncontrolled or unstable hematological disease (e.g., refractory anemia, refractory myelosuppression) | Neurological diseases affecting cognition (e.g., primary Lewy body dementia, Huntington's disease, Parkinson's disease, encephalitis, epilepsy, vascular or multi-infarct dementia, stroke, congenital mental deficiency, multiple sclerosis) | Psychiatric disorders impacting cognition (e.g., schizophrenia, intellectual disability) | Unstable or uncontrolled major depression or anxiety within the last 12 months | History of seizures in the past 3 years | Uncontrolled endocrine disease (e.g., uncontrolled diabetes mellitus, manifest hyperthyroidism) | Severe renal impairment (GFR < 30 mL/min/1.73 m2) | Infection with HIV, hepatitis B, hepatitis C, or any other active infection or active systemic disease | Current treatment with anticoagulants (except aspirin at or below a prophylactic dose) | Use of memantine or acetylcholinesterase inhibitors above recommended dose range or not on a stable dose for 30 days prior to enrollment | Any contraindication to brain MRI and/or amyloid PET | Any condition that, in the investigator's opinion, puts the participant's safety at risk | Medically unstable or uncontrolled conditions | Any suicidal behavior in the past 2 years | Suicidal ideation type 4 or 5 on C-SSRS in the past 3 months
prior_therapies: Stable dose of memantine or acetylcholinesterase inhibitors for >=30 days prior to enrollment
reasoning: The trial requires a positive amyloid PET (and AD per NIA-AA), but the patient has negative amyloid PET and CSF amyloid, constituting a required biomarker mismatch. Age and stage otherwise fit, but this hard exclusion applies.
patient_biomarkers: Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 68 years; Male; Two-year history of progressive cognitive decline; MMSE score 19; Moderate-stage dementia; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
judge_comment: The trial requires a positive amyloid PET; the patient has negative amyloid PET (and CSF amyloid negative), which is a definitive required biomarker mismatch. This is a HARD EXCLUSION per the rubric, so grade F is correct. Other factors (age, stage) do not override the hard exclusion.

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 8-year-old female with PMM2-CDG (Congenital Disorder of Glycosylation). She has confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2 and exhibits moderate cerebellar dysfunction with a recent ICARS score of 35. Her family is highly motivated for research participation.
trial_title: Safety and Efficacy of Dual Menin and FLT3 Inhibition in Patients With Relapsed/Refractory FLT3- Mutated Acute Myeloid Leukemia Containing a Concurrent MLL-Rearrangement or NPM1 Mutation: A Phase I (Ph I) Study of SNDX-5613 + Gilteritinib
diseases_targeted: Acute Myeloid Leukemia (relapsed/refractory); Acute Myeloid Leukemia With FLT3 Mutation; Acute Myeloid Leukemia With NPM1 Mutation; Acute Myeloid Leukemia With KMT2A Rearrangement
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Morphologically confirmed relapsed/refractory acute myeloid leukemia (WHO 2022) | Refractory disease after >= 2 cycles intensive induction or >= 2 cycles HMA + venetoclax with persistent >= 5% marrow blasts and/or reappearance of peripheral blasts | FLT3 mutation (ITD or TKD) AND concurrent NPM1 mutation or KMT2A (MLL) rearrangement or other mutation causing HOXA-MEIS1 overexpression (e.g., NUP98, UBTF-TD, MLL-PTD) | Receiving itraconazole, ketoconazole, posaconazole, or voriconazole for antifungal prophylaxis >= 24 hours prior to enrollment and during treatment; no other strong CYP3A4 inhibitors/inducers | Not suitable for immediate myeloablative/intensive chemotherapy | ECOG performance status 0-2 | AST <= 3 x ULN | ALT <= 3 x ULN | Total bilirubin <= 1.5 x ULN (except Gilbert syndrome) | eGFR >= 60 mL/min | Left ventricular ejection fraction >= 50% by echocardiogram or MUGA | Able to swallow oral medications | Prior treatment-related toxicities resolved to <= grade 1 (except <= grade 2 neuropathy or alopecia) | Required washouts from prior therapies per protocol | Prior gilteritinib allowed
exclusion_criteria: Acute promyelocytic leukemia | Extramedullary AML or myeloid sarcoma (WHO 2022) | Suspected CNS involvement unless cleared or receiving active CNS-directed therapy | Active second malignancy requiring anticancer therapy (therapy-related neoplasms not eligible) | Known allergy or hypersensitivity to gilteritinib or revumenib | Active uncontrolled HIV, HBV, or HCV infection (controlled/treated cases with undetectable viral load are eligible) | QTcF > 450 ms at screening | Clinically significant ventricular arrhythmia (e.g., VT, VF, Torsades de pointes) | Unstable angina, serious cardiac arrhythmia, myocardial infarction within 2 months, or NYHA class III/IV heart failure | Uncontrolled infection | Psychiatric illness preventing informed consent | Pregnant or breastfeeding | Malabsorption syndrome or condition precluding enteral administration | Any condition that, in the investigator’s opinion, would adversely affect participation or interpretation of results
prior_therapies: Prior gilteritinib permitted; Radiation: >= 60 days from TBI/craniospinal or >= 50% pelvic radiation; >= 14 days from local palliative RT; HSCT: >= 60 days post-transplant; DLI: >= 4 weeks; Immunotherapy (vaccines, checkpoint inhibitors): >= 42 days; CAR-T or other modified T-cell therapy: >= 21 days; Antileukemia therapy (small molecule or cytotoxic/myelosuppressive): >= 14 days or 5 half-lives (whichever is shorter); Hydroxyurea for cytoreduction allowed before and during treatment (with approval); Prophylactic intrathecal chemotherapy allowed; Hematopoietic growth factors: >= 7 days (short-acting) or >= 14 days (long-acting); Antineoplastic biologics: >= 90 days or 5 half-lives (whichever is shorter); Systemic steroids: >= 7 days unless physiologic dosing
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets relapsed/refractory FLT3-mutated AML, while the patient has PMM2-CDG. Additionally, the trial requires age ≥18 years and the patient is 8 years old.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of PMM2-CDG; Confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2; ICARS score 35 (moderate cerebellar dysfunction); Age 8 years
judge_comment: There is a clear disease mismatch (patient has PMM2-CDG; trial is for R/R FLT3-mutated AML with specific co-mutations) and an age hard exclusion (trial requires ≥18; patient is 8). Either triggers an F. The grader’s reasoning correctly identified these hard exclusions.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: An Interventional Study to Evaluate Treating to a Target of Transmural Healing in Patients With Moderately to Severely Active Crohn's Disease
inclusion_criteria: Age 18 to 80 years | Moderately-to-severely active Crohn disease: CDAI 220 to 450 and SES-CD >= 6 (or >= 4 if isolated ileal disease) | C-reactive protein >= 5 mg/L and/or fecal calprotectin >= 250 µg/g at screening | Bowel wall thickness on intestinal ultrasound > 4.0 mm in the ileum or any colonic segment (excluding rectum) | Biologic-naive or prior exposure to no more than 1 advanced therapeutic (approved biologic or small molecule) for Crohn disease | Stable dose of 5-ASA initiated >= 4 weeks prior to screening may be continued | Persons of childbearing potential: negative serum pregnancy test prior to randomization and use of highly effective contraception during study
exclusion_criteria: Prior treatment with vedolizumab, etrolizumab, or natalizumab | Previously exposed to 2 or more advanced therapeutics (approved biologic or small molecule) for Crohn disease | Change in oral corticosteroid dose within 2 weeks prior to randomization or prednisone > 40 mg (or equivalent) at randomization | Inflammation only proximal to terminal ileum not reachable by ileocolonoscopy | Crohn disease complication requiring procedural intervention (e.g., symptomatic small bowel stricture with > 3 cm prestenotic dilatation) | Previous extensive colonic resection or missing > 2 of 5 segments; ileorectal anastomosis; proctocolectomy | Ostomy or ileoanal pouch | Short bowel syndrome | Fibrotic-only stricture in ileum or colon without active inflammation, including any impassable stenosis | Abscess > 2 cm detected by intestinal ultrasound (participants with draining fistulas are not excluded) | Serious underlying disease other than Crohn disease that may interfere with participation or compromise safety | Positive stool test for Clostridioides difficile toxin | Known HIV infection | Known hepatitis B or hepatitis C infection | Known active or latent tuberculosis | Other systemic or opportunistic infection (including cytomegalovirus), any other clinically significant extraintestinal infection, or recurring infection within 6 months of randomization | Active cerebral or meningeal disease, signs, symptoms, or any history of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy | Hypersensitivity, allergy, or intolerance to vedolizumab excipients or any contraindication to vedolizumab | Active severe infection such as sepsis, cytomegalovirus, listeriosis, or opportunistic infection | Unwilling to withhold protocol-prohibited medications during the trial | Participation in another clinical trial with investigational therapy within 30 days or 5 half-lives (whichever is longer) prior to randomization | History of alcohol or drug abuse that may interfere with compliance | Prior enrollment in the current study and received study treatment | Pregnant, lactating, or intending pregnancy; or intending to donate ova or sperm during and up to 18 weeks after last dose | Live or live-attenuated vaccine within 4 weeks prior to randomization or planned during the study
prior_therapies: Biologic-naive or <= 1 prior advanced therapeutic for Crohn disease allowed; Stable 5-ASA for >= 4 weeks prior to screening allowed; No change to oral corticosteroid dosing within 2 weeks prior to randomization
reasoning: The patient has received two prior advanced therapies (infliximab and ustekinumab), while the trial excludes participants previously exposed to ≥2 advanced therapeutics and allows ≤1. Although age and disease activity align, this explicit exclusion makes the patient ineligible.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe Crohn's disease; Fistulizing disease; CDAI score 350; Active perianal fistula with draining seton in place
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab
judge_comment: Patient has prior exposure to two advanced therapies (infliximab and ustekinumab), and the trial explicitly excludes those with ≥2 prior advanced therapeutics. This is a hard exclusion under the rubric, so grade F is correct.

question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.
trial_title: Developing a Nonpharmacological Pain Intervention for Community-dwelling Older Adults With Dementia
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 60 years | Mild or very mild dementia | Knee pain lasting >= 3 months | Average knee pain intensity >= 2/10
exclusion_criteria: Life expectancy < 1 year | Recent changes to pain or psychotropic medications within 60 days | Knee surgery within the past 1 year | Medical condition that contraindicates exercise | Currently receiving rehabilitation services
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: The trial requires mild or very mild dementia, but the patient has moderate-stage dementia (MMSE 19), which fails a required inclusion criterion. Age and sex fit; knee pain requirements are unknown but do not offset the stage mismatch.
patient_biomarkers: Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 68 years; Male; Two-year history of progressive cognitive decline; MMSE score 19; Moderate-stage dementia; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
judge_comment: The trial explicitly requires mild/very mild dementia; the patient has moderate-stage dementia, a required stage/severity the patient definitively lacks. This qualifies as a hard exclusion per the rubric. Age and sex fit; knee pain/OA status is unknown and not used to penalize. F is correct.

question_text: A 55-year-old female has severe, seropositive rheumatoid arthritis refractory to methotrexate and two prior biologic agents (adalimumab and tocilizumab). She has active disease with a DAS28 score of 5.5. Critically, she has a history of treated Hepatitis B (HBsAg negative, anti-HBc positive) and moderate chronic kidney disease with an eGFR of 45 mL/min/1.73m². What are trial options for her?
trial_title: A Pilot and Feasibility Study Focusing on Lifestyle, Environmental Modifications, and Transdisciplinary Clinical Care for Children With Chronic Illness: Protocol for the FLIGHT Study
diseases_targeted: Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis; Asthma; Eczema; Allergies; Crohn's Disease; Ulcerative Colitis; Lupus; Obesity; Type 2 Diabetes; Autism Spectrum Disorder; Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder; Depression; Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder; Anxiety Disorder
inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis in immune/autoimmune conditions (e.g., juvenile idiopathic arthritis, juvenile rheumatoid arthritis, asthma, eczema, atopic illness, allergies, Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis, lupus) | Diagnosis in conditions of metabolic dysregulation (e.g., obesity, type 2 diabetes) | Diagnosis in mood/behavioral/developmental conditions (e.g., autism spectrum disorder, ADHD/ADD, depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder, anxiety)
exclusion_criteria: Condition severe enough to preclude participation in an intensive, multi-modal lifestyle intervention | Pregnancy
prior_therapies: (none)
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets pediatric conditions (juvenile idiopathic/rheumatoid arthritis), not adult rheumatoid arthritis. Age window conflict: the trial enrolls ages 2–15, while the patient is 55.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 55 years; Female; Seropositive rheumatoid arthritis; Active disease (DAS28 5.5)
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to methotrexate; Prior adalimumab; Prior tocilizumab; Failed two prior biologic agents
judge_comment: Correct: There is a hard age window conflict (trial ages 2–15 vs patient 55) and a disease mismatch (trial lists juvenile arthritis, not adult rheumatoid arthritis). Either triggers F. The grader’s reasoning aligns with the rubric.

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 8-year-old female with PMM2-CDG (Congenital Disorder of Glycosylation). She has confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2 and exhibits moderate cerebellar dysfunction with a recent ICARS score of 35. Her family is highly motivated for research participation.
trial_title: A Phase 1-2, Double-Blind, Sham-Controlled Multiple Ascending Dose Study to Evaluate Safety, Tolerability, Pharmacokinetics, and Pharmacodynamics of Intrathecally-Administered ION440 in Patients With MECP2 Duplication Syndrome
inclusion_criteria: Males age 2 to 65 years (cohort-dependent; Group A: 8–65 years; Group B: 2–7 years). | Documented MECP2 Duplication Syndrome with genetic confirmation of MECP2 duplication. | Stable doses of concomitant medications for >= 3 months prior to baseline (or per investigator judgment). | Completed Part 1/MAD to enroll in Part 2.
exclusion_criteria: Complex MECP2 duplication/triplication or clinical features suggesting complex variant if structure unknown (e.g., seizures onset < age 5 for those >=5 years, oxygen dependence, microcephaly). | Clinically significant vital sign or ECG abnormality at screening (e.g., HR < 45 bpm; SBP < 90 mmHg; confirmed BP > 170/105 mmHg). | Known brain or spinal disease interfering with lumbar puncture, CSF circulation, or safety of the procedure. | Any concomitant disease/condition or finding making participation unsuitable or posing unacceptable risk, per investigator. | Treatment with an investigational drug/biologic/device within 30 days or 5 half-lives, whichever is longer. | Previous treatment with an oligonucleotide (including siRNA) within 4 months (single dose) or 12 months (multiple doses); centrally administered ASOs require >= 12 months washout. | Currently enrolled in another clinical trial of an investigational agent/device or used any investigational agent within 5 half-lives. | History of gene therapy, cell transplantation, or experimental brain surgery. | Active infection requiring systemic antiviral/antimicrobial therapy not completed before baseline. | Status epilepticus within the past 6 months.
prior_therapies: Washout from investigational agents: 30 days or 5 half-lives, whichever is longer.; Washout from oligonucleotides (including siRNA): >= 4 months after single dose; >= 12 months after multiple doses; centrally administered ASOs: >= 12 months.
reasoning: Hard exclusions: the trial targets MECP2 Duplication Syndrome with required MECP2 duplication and enrolls males only, whereas the patient has PMM2-CDG with PMM2 variants and is female. Age fits, but disease, biomarker, and sex criteria do not.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of PMM2-CDG; Confirmed biallelic pathogenic variants in PMM2; ICARS score 35 (moderate cerebellar dysfunction); Age 8 years
judge_comment: Correct: There is a hard disease mismatch (trial is for MECP2 Duplication Syndrome; patient has PMM2-CDG) and a sex restriction conflict (trial male-only; patient female). Either triggers an immediate F. Age fit is irrelevant. The grader’s reasoning appropriately identified these hard exclusions.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
trial_title: A Phase 3 Open-label, Randomized, Active-controlled, Multicenter Trial to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of Orally Administered BAY 2927088 Compared With Standard of Care as a First-line Therapy in Patients With Locally Advanced or Metastatic Non-small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) With HER2-activating Mutations
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Histologically or cytologically confirmed locally advanced non-squamous non-small cell lung cancer not suitable for definitive therapy or metastatic non-squamous non-small cell lung cancer (Stage III–IV) | Activating HER2 mutation in the tyrosine kinase domain confirmed by tissue molecular test in an accredited laboratory | No prior systemic therapy for locally advanced or metastatic disease | No prior HER2 exon 20 insertion–targeted therapy | Prior adjuvant or neoadjuvant therapy allowed if completed >= 12 months before screening | Eligible to receive platinum-pemetrexed doublet chemotherapy and pembrolizumab per product information
exclusion_criteria: Prior malignancy unless curatively treated with no recurrence for 5 years (specific in situ cancers, superficial bladder cancer, limited-stage prostate cancer, and basal or squamous skin cancers allowed if appropriately treated) | Tumors harboring other targetable alterations with approved available therapy (except HER2 mutation in the TKD) | Inability to discontinue chronic systemic corticosteroids | Pre-existing peripheral neuropathy Grade >= 2 (CTCAE v5.0) | History of severe hypersensitivity reaction to a monoclonal antibody | Radiotherapy outside of the brain within 21 days prior to start of study intervention or unresolved radiation-related toxicities or requirement for corticosteroids
prior_therapies: No prior systemic therapy for locally advanced or metastatic disease; No prior HER2 exon 20 insertion–targeted therapy; Adjuvant or neoadjuvant therapy allowed if completed >= 12 months before screening
reasoning: The trial requires a HER2-activating mutation and first-line (no prior systemic) therapy, and excludes tumors with other targetable alterations; the patient has an EGFR exon 19 deletion and has already received osimertinib, which explicitly violates these criteria.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Non-small cell lung cancer; De novo metastatic disease (bone, liver); EGFR exon 19 deletion; ECOG 0; Age 40 years
judge_comment: Correct. Although HER2 status is unknown, the trial explicitly excludes tumors with other targetable alterations with approved therapy; the patient has an EGFR exon 19 deletion (targetable) and has received osimertinib. This is a hard exclusion, so F is appropriate.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: A Phase 2b, Multicenter, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled Study to Evaluate the Efficacy, Safety, Pharmacokinetics, and Pharmacodynamics of Obefazimod in Subjects With Moderately to Severely Active Crohn's Disease
inclusion_criteria: Age 18 to 75 years | Confirmed Crohn disease by endoscopy and histology | Moderately to severely active Crohn disease: CDAI 220–450 | SES-CD >= 6 for ileo-colonic or colonic disease, or SES-CD >= 4 for isolated ileal disease (per central reading) | Documented inadequate response, loss of response, or intolerance to at least one: corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, biologic or biosimilar therapies, or JAK inhibitors
exclusion_criteria: Ulcerative colitis or indeterminate colitis | Crohn disease without ileal and/or colonic involvement | Untreated active external or perianal fistula or abscess (recent abscess must be drained and adequately treated per protocol timelines) | Symptomatic bowel stricture or stenosis not passable on endoscopy | Current stoma or ileoanal pouch | More than two missing complete segments among terminal ileum, right colon, transverse colon, left colon, and sigmoid/rectum | Combined prior small bowel resections > 100 cm | Surgical bowel resection within 3 months prior to baseline | Any manifestation likely to require surgery during the study | Use of prohibited concomitant therapies for Crohn disease | Prior natalizumab or any other alpha4beta1 integrin agonist | Failure of more than three advanced therapies for Crohn disease, or failure of two different mechanisms of action of advanced therapies | History of or active malignancy (except subjects with >= 5-year disease-free survival) | History of colonic cancer or dysplasia adenomatous polyps, or evidence of such polyps at screening endoscopy | Primary sclerosing cholangitis, autoimmune hepatitis, or primary biliary cirrhosis | Serious illness requiring hospitalization (not related to Crohn disease) within 4 weeks prior to screening | Chronic or recurrent grade 3–4 infection within 2 months prior to screening or history of opportunistic infection while not on immunosuppressive therapy | Herpes zoster reactivation within 2 months prior to screening | Active infection at screening or major infection requiring hospitalization or IV antibiotics within 1 month prior to or during screening | Positive stool assay or culture for pathogens requiring treatment or positive Clostridioides difficile toxin at screening | HIV infection | Acute or chronic hepatitis B infection | Acute or chronic hepatitis C infection (unless successfully treated with no detectable HCV RNA for >= 1 year) | Active tuberculosis or untreated latent tuberculosis | Uncontrolled ischemic heart disease or history of congestive heart failure | Congenital or acquired long QT syndrome or marked baseline prolonged QTc | History of torsade de pointes | Clinically relevant pulmonary, hepatic, or renal abnormality; encephalopathy; neuropathy; unstable CNS pathology including seizure disorder; or other significant medical problems | Live vaccine within 3 months prior to screening or planned during the study | Acute or chronic pancreatitis | Hemoglobin <= 8.0 g/dL | Absolute neutrophil count < 750/µL | Platelets < 100,000/µL | eGFR < 60 mL/min | Total bilirubin > 1.5 x ULN (except Gilbert syndrome) | AST > 2 x ULN or ALT > 2 x ULN | Did not meet protocol-specified washout periods prior to screening endoscopy | Use of any investigational or nonregistered product within 3 months or within 5 half-lives prior to baseline, whichever is longer | Prior obefazimod exposure or known hypersensitivity to obefazimod or excipients | Illicit drug or alcohol abuse or dependence | Any condition that could compromise safety or adherence in the investigator's opinion
prior_therapies: Inadequate response, loss of response, or intolerance to at least one of: corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, biologic or biosimilar therapies, or JAK inhibitors for Crohn disease; No investigational or nonregistered product within 3 months or 5 half-lives prior to baseline; Meet protocol-specified washout periods before screening endoscopy
reasoning: Explicit exclusion: the trial excludes subjects with failure of two different mechanisms of advanced therapies; this patient is refractory to infliximab (anti-TNF) and ustekinumab (anti–IL-12/23), meeting that exclusion.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe Crohn's disease; Fistulizing disease; CDAI score 350; Active perianal fistula with draining seton in place
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab
judge_comment: The trial explicitly excludes patients with failure of two different mechanisms of advanced therapies. The patient is refractory to infliximab (anti-TNF) and ustekinumab (anti–IL-12/23), satisfying this exclusion. Thus, a hard exclusion applies and F is correct.

question_text: 40 year old man with recurrent glioblastoma. Diagnosed 1 year ago, underwent gross total resection with confirmation of GBM, IDH wildtype. Completed adjuvant radiation + concurrent temozolomide and then adjuvant temozolomide. Three months after completing adjuvant therapy, MRI shows recurrence. ECOG 1 and no other medical issues. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Pilot Trial of Adjuvant Hypofractionated Stereotactic Radiosurgery for Intermediate-risk Meningioma (SRS-AIM)
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | Histologic diagnosis of newly diagnosed WHO grade 2 meningioma or recurrent WHO grade 1 meningioma with radiographic evidence of recurrence and WHO grade 1 histology at most recent resection | Gross-total surgical resection (Simpson grade I–III) within 180 days of enrollment | ECOG 0–1 (Karnofsky >= 70%) | Post-operative MRI indicating anatomy suitable for hypofractionated stereotactic radiosurgery
exclusion_criteria: Extensive multifocal meningiomas (>= 3) or metastatic disease | Tumor within 2 mm of the optic apparatus or brainstem | Another active primary malignancy unless complete remission achieved >= 2 years prior and no additional therapy required during the study period | Pregnancy | Underlying medical or psychiatric condition that would interfere with evaluation of study treatment or interpretation of safety/results | Uncontrolled seizures (>3 disabling seizures per day while on anti-epileptic drugs) | Prior intracranial radiotherapy overlapping the planned stereotactic radiosurgery target
prior_therapies: Gross-total surgical resection (Simpson grade I–III) required within 180 days prior to enrollment
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial targets WHO grade 2 meningioma or recurrent grade 1 meningioma, while the patient has recurrent glioblastoma (IDH-wildtype). Thus, the patient is not eligible.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 40 years; Male; Recurrent glioblastoma; IDH wildtype; Status post gross total resection; Completed radiation with concurrent temozolomide and adjuvant temozolomide; ECOG 1; No other medical issues
patient_prior_therapies: Gross total resection; Adjuvant radiation with concurrent temozolomide; Adjuvant temozolomide
judge_comment: Disease mismatch is a hard exclusion: the trial is for meningioma (grade 2 or recurrent grade 1), while the patient has recurrent glioblastoma. The grader correctly assigned F based on this.

question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. He recently completed IV antibiotic treatment for a perianal abscess and still has an active, draining seton in place. What are his clinical trial options?
trial_title: A Phase III, Multicenter, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Study to Assess the Efficacy and Safety of Induction Therapy With RO7790121 in Patients With Moderately to Severely Active Ulcerative Colitis
inclusion_criteria: Confirmed diagnosis of ulcerative colitis | Moderately to severely active ulcerative colitis assessed by modified Mayo Score | Body weight >= 40 kg | Up to date colorectal cancer screening per local standards | Inadequate response, loss of response, or intolerance to at least one conventional or advanced ulcerative colitis therapy
exclusion_criteria: Complications of ulcerative colitis (e.g., fulminant colitis, toxic megacolon) | Crohn's disease, indeterminate colitis, microscopic colitis, ischemic colitis, infectious colitis, or radiation colitis | Presence of an ostomy or ileoanal pouch | Primary sclerosing cholangitis | Pregnancy or breastfeeding | Past or current colonic dysplasia, adenomas, or neoplasia not completely removed | Malignancy within 5 years except adequately treated non-metastatic basal cell or squamous cell skin cancer or in situ cervical cancer | Infection with Clostridioides difficile, cytomegalovirus, HIV, hepatitis B, or hepatitis C | Active tuberculosis or latent/inadequately treated tuberculosis | Prior exposure to anti-TL1A therapy or other protocol-prohibited medicines

patient_inclusion_criteria: Moderate-to-severe Crohn's disease; Fistulizing disease; CDAI score 350; Active perianal fistula with draining seton in place
patient_prior_therapies: Refractory to infliximab; Refractory to ustekinumab
judge_comment: Disease mismatch: patient has Crohn’s disease while the trial is for ulcerative colitis, and the trial explicitly excludes Crohn’s disease. This is a hard exclusion, so F is correct.

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?

exclusion_criteria: Fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma | Sarcomatoid hepatocellular carcinoma | Mixed cholangiohepatocellular carcinoma | Symptomatic extrahepatic disease | Received anti-cancer therapy or investigational drugs <= 3 weeks prior to first dose
prior_therapies: At least one prior line of systemic therapy for unresectable advanced or metastatic disease; Washout >= 3 weeks from prior anti-cancer therapy or investigational drugs
reasoning: Disease mismatch: the trial enrolls patients with advanced/metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma, while the patient has metastatic urothelial carcinoma. This is a hard exclusion regardless of other factors.
patient_inclusion_criteria: (none)
judge_comment: Disease mismatch: patient has metastatic urothelial carcinoma; trial is only for advanced/metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma. This is a hard exclusion per rubric, so F is correct.

question_text: 40 year old man with recurrent glioblastoma. Diagnosed 1 year ago, underwent gross total resection with confirmation of GBM, IDH wildtype. inclusion_criteria: Recurrent malignant glioma, IDH-mutant, WHO grade 3–4; progression on imaging with suspicion of histologic recurrence | Patients with prior WHO grade 2 IDH-mutant glioma now demonstrating high-grade (WHO grade 3–4) features | Failed standard-of-care treatment | MRI within 30 days showing an enhancing mass without significant mass effect | Tumor volume <32 cc and stereotactically accessible | Karnofsky performance status >=70% | Age >=18 years | Adequate organ and marrow function per protocol thresholds | Women of childbearing potential: negative pregnancy test within 7 days of entry and use of birth control; men and women must use contraception per protocol timelines
exclusion_criteria: Diffuse subependymal or cerebrospinal fluid disease | Tumors involving the cerebellum or both cerebral hemispheres | Active infection requiring treatment or unexplained febrile illness | Known HIV, hepatitis B, or hepatitis C positivity | Systemic diseases conferring unacceptable anesthetic/operative risk | Prior systemic topotecan for the tumor | Inability to undergo MRI or PET imaging | Allergy to topotecan, other topoisomerase inhibitors, or gadolinium compounds | Concomitant use of drugs metabolized solely by CYP3A4/5 with a narrow therapeutic index or strong CYP2C8 inhibitors, or agents with QT prolongation risk that are CYP3A substrates (must discontinue >=2 weeks before treatment) | Uncontrolled intercurrent illness (e.g., congestive heart failure, unstable angina, cardiac arrhythmia, significant psychiatric illness) | Positive pregnancy test within 7 days of registration | Breastfeeding

patient_prior_therapies: Gross total resection; Adjuvant radiation with concurrent temozolomide; Adjuvant temozolomide
judge_comment: The trial explicitly requires IDH-mutant recurrent malignant glioma, while the patient is IDH-wildtype. This is a required biomarker mismatch, which is a hard exclusion per the rubric, warranting grade F. The grader’s reasoning correctly identifies this.

question_text: I have a 40 year old patient with non-smallcell lung cancer. Diagnosed de novo metastatic disease (bone, liver) with EGFR exon 19 deletion. He has been on Osimertinib for 2 years with complete response. Unfortunately, began having headaches and recent MRI shows numerous lesions. Otherwise no past medical issues and ECOG 0. Are there any trial options?
trial_title: A Phase III, Randomized, Double-blind, Multicenter, Global Study of Rilvegostomig or Pembrolizumab in Combination With Platinum-based Chemotherapy for the First-line Treatment of Patients With Metastatic Squamous Non-small Cell Lung Cancer Whose Tumors Express PD-L1 (ARTEMIDE-Lung02)
inclusion_criteria: Histologically or cytologically confirmed squamous non-small cell lung cancer. | Stage IV metastatic NSCLC not amenable to curative treatment. | No actionable driver oncogenes with approved first-line targeted therapies per local testing. | Tumor PD-L1 expression on tumor cells (TC) >= 1%. | At least one measurable lesion by RECIST 1.1 not previously irradiated (>= 10 mm longest diameter; lymph nodes short axis >= 15 mm) suitable for repeated measurements by CT or MRI. | Adequate organ and bone marrow function.
exclusion_criteria: Presence of small cell or neuroendocrine histology components. | Active or uncontrolled brain metastases; allowed only if asymptomatic, stable, off steroids and anticonvulsants >= 7 days; >= 2 weeks since local therapy with recovery from acute effects. | Any prior systemic therapy for advanced or metastatic NSCLC. | Any prior treatment with an anti-PD-1 or anti-PD-L1 agent. | Any prior exposure to anti-TIGIT therapy or other anticancer therapy targeting immune-regulatory receptors or mechanisms. | History of another primary malignancy unless treated with curative intent with no active disease for >= 2 years and low risk of recurrence. | Active or prior autoimmune or inflammatory disorders requiring chronic steroids or other immunosuppressive treatment. | Active primary immunodeficiency or active infectious disease(s). | Active tuberculosis infection.
prior_therapies: No prior systemic therapy for advanced/metastatic NSCLC
reasoning: The trial requires no prior systemic therapy for advanced/metastatic NSCLC and absence of actionable driver oncogenes; the patient has received osimertinib and harbors an EGFR exon 19 deletion, both of which are explicit exclusions.
patient_inclusion_criteria: Non-small cell lung cancer; De novo metastatic disease (bone, liver); EGFR exon 19 deletion; ECOG 0; Age 40 years
judge_comment: Hard exclusions apply: the trial excludes any prior systemic therapy for advanced/metastatic NSCLC and requires no actionable driver oncogenes; the patient has prior osimertinib and an EGFR exon 19 deletion. The grader correctly assigned F and cited the right reasons.

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 8-year-old female with PMM2-CDG (Congenital Disorder of Glycosylation). question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. An amyloid PET scan was performed and was negative. CSF analysis was also negative for amyloid plaques but showed elevated p-tau. His family is seeking disease-modifying therapies.
trial_title: A Phase 1b, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled, Multiple Ascending Dose Study of the Safety, Tolerability, Pharmacokinetics, Pharmacodynamics, and Preliminary Efficacy of PMN310 in Patients With Early Alzheimer's Disease
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 50 years | Ambulatory with adequate vision and hearing for assessments | MCI due to Alzheimer’s disease or mild AD dementia per NIA-AA (Stage 3–4) | Global CDR 0.5–1.0 and memory box score >= 0.5 at Screening and Baseline | Objective episodic memory impairment (>= 1 SD below age-adjusted mean on WMS-IV Logical Memory II) | MMSE 20–28 inclusive at Screening | Positive amyloid PET scan within 6 months of Screening or during Screening | Body mass index 18.5–35 kg/m2 inclusive | Patients of reproductive potential agree to use effective contraception during treatment and for 120 days after last dose | Females of childbearing potential: negative pregnancy tests; not breastfeeding | Postmenopausal or surgically sterile patients are eligible | Reliable caregiver available for study visits and assessments | Adequate venous access for IV infusions and blood collection | Stable dose (>= 3 months) of acetylcholinesterase inhibitors or memantine allowed
exclusion_criteria: Residing in a continuous care or long-term care nursing facility | Other neurodegenerative or neurological disorders contributing to cognitive impairment (e.g., Parkinson’s disease, Huntington’s disease, frontotemporal dementia, dementia with Lewy bodies) | QTcF > 450 msec (males) or > 470 msec (females) | ALT >= 2 x ULN, AST >= 2 x ULN, or total bilirubin >= 1.5 x ULN | Creatinine clearance < 30 mL/min | Clinically significant physical or psychiatric illness posing risk or affecting study completion (including suicidal risk/behavior) | Unstable or clinically significant cardiovascular disease within 1 year (e.g., unstable angina, myocardial infarction, chronic heart failure, significant conduction abnormalities) | Clinically significant hepatic or renal impairment; positive hepatitis B surface antigen or hepatitis C antibody | Poorly managed hypertension (systolic > 160 mmHg and/or diastolic > 95 mmHg) or hypotension (systolic < 90 mmHg and/or diastolic < 60 mmHg) | Uncontrolled diabetes (HbA1c > 7.5%) or insulin-dependent diabetes | Significant systemic illness within 30 days before first dose | Seizure within 3 years prior to Screening | Prior malignancy (except adequately treated non-melanoma skin cancer or cervical carcinoma in situ) | Brain MRI findings: > 4 microhemorrhages; > 1 lobar microhemorrhage; superficial siderosis; subarachnoid hemorrhage; any other hemorrhage > 10 mm; > 2 lacunar infarcts or cortical infarct; severe perivascular spaces or multisport-pattern white matter hyperintensities (PI review required) | History of stroke or TIA within 12 months | Contraindication to PET or brain MRI | Negative amyloid PET scan within 6 months of Screening or during Screening | Pregnant or breastfeeding | Alcohol or substance abuse within 12 months prior to dosing | Positive alcohol breath test or positive illicit drug screen at Screening | HIV antibody positive | COVID-19 infection within 2 weeks of Screening or ongoing symptoms at Screening | Currently receiving anti-amyloid treatment or received within 9 months prior to Screening (marketed or investigational); investigational placebo recipients are not excluded | Contraindication to lumbar puncture (e.g., INR > 1.4, platelet count < 120,000/µL, local infection, anticoagulant use except low-dose aspirin, significant spinal abnormalities) | Blood or blood product donation within 56 days prior to first dose | Received an investigational active agent within 30 days or 5 half-lives (whichever is longer) | History of severe hypersensitivity to PMN310 components
prior_therapies: Stable dose of acetylcholinesterase inhibitors or memantine for >= 3 months allowed; Washout from anti-amyloid therapy >= 9 months prior to Screening; Washout from investigational active agents >= 30 days or 5 half-lives (whichever is longer)
reasoning: The trial requires early AD with a positive amyloid PET (and excludes negative PET); the patient has a documented negative amyloid PET/CSF amyloid. Additionally, the MMSE 19 and moderate-stage dementia conflict with the trial’s mild-stage (MMSE 20–28) requirement.
patient_biomarkers: Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
patient_inclusion_criteria: Age 68 years; Male; Two-year history of progressive cognitive decline; MMSE score 19; Moderate-stage dementia; Amyloid PET negative; CSF amyloid negative; Elevated CSF p-tau
judge_comment: Trial requires positive amyloid PET (and excludes negative); patient definitively lacks this required biomarker (amyloid PET and CSF amyloid negative), which is a hard exclusion. Age/sex okay; MMSE and stage also mismatch but F is already triggered by biomarker.

question_text: I'm looking for trial options for an 8-year-old female with PMM2-CDG (Congenital Disorder of Glycosylation). question_text: What are trial options for a 68-year-old male with a two-year history of progressive cognitive decline? His MMSE score is 19, consistent with moderate-stage dementia. question_text: A 32-year-old male has moderate-to-severe fistulizing Crohn's disease, refractory to both infliximab and ustekinumab, with a CDAI score of 350. diseases_targeted: Malignant Brain Tumor (recurrent); Diffuse Hemispheric Glioma (H3 G34-mutant)
inclusion_criteria: Age 3-25 years with malignant primary brain tumor at recurrence/relapse/progression after completion of up-front standard therapy | Age 26-39 years with diffuse hemispheric glioma, H3 G34-mutant, at recurrence/relapse/progression after completion of up-front standard therapy | Weight >= 10 kg and BSA > 0.5 m^2 | On stable or decreasing corticosteroid dose for >= 3 days prior to baseline MRI | Surgical resection of recurrence/relapse/progression is clinically indicated | Willing to provide archival FFPE and/or frozen tissue specimens, if available | Recovered from acute side effects of prior therapy | Therapy washouts from start of study treatment: >= 7 days after last biologic agent or beyond known AE window; 5 half-lives from any investigational agent; 4 weeks from cytotoxic therapy (23 days for temozolomide; 6 weeks for nitrosoureas); 6 weeks from antibody therapy (21 days for bevacizumab); 6 weeks from cellular therapy; 4 weeks or 5 half-lives (whichever shorter) from other antitumor therapies | Prior radiotherapy: >= 28 days from focal RT; >= 150 days from craniospinal irradiation | Bevacizumab for RT-induced edema allowed (up to 5 doses; no washout required) | Prior temozolomide during radiation at standard pediatric dosing allowed; prior dexamethasone allowed | ANC >= 1000/µL | Platelets >= 100000/µL (transfusion independent) | Creatinine clearance or GFR >= 70 mL/min/1.73 m^2 or serum creatinine within normal limits for age | Bilirubin <= 2 x ULN | ALT <= 3 x ULN | Serum albumin <= 2 g/dL | Performance score >= 60 (Karnofsky if >16 years; Lansky if <=16 years) | Females of child-bearing potential and males agree to use adequate contraception during treatment and for 30 days after last dose
exclusion_criteria: Not clinically appropriate for tumor resection per neurosurgeon | Disseminated disease including diffuse leptomeningeal disease or CSF dissemination | Primary brainstem or primary spinal tumors | History of prior gene therapy | Ongoing valacyclovir therapy that cannot be stopped due to a medical condition | Known allergy to valacyclovir | Concurrent use of other investigational agents (non-diagnostic) | Currently receiving anti-cancer agents | Known disorders affecting immune system (e.g., HIV, hepatitis B or C) or autoimmune disorder requiring systemic cytotoxic or immunosuppressive therapy | Uncontrolled infection or other uncontrolled systemic illness | Current diagnosis of bipolar disorder or major depressive disorder | Congenital immune deficiency syndrome or acquired autoimmune disease | Pregnant or breastfeeding; FOCBP must have negative pregnancy test prior to therapy | Active illicit drug use or diagnosis of alcoholism | History of kidney transplant | History of allogeneic stem cell transplantation | Another malignancy that is progressing or requires active treatment within 3 years
prior_therapies: Completed up-front standard-of-care therapy required; Washout: >= 7 days since last biologic agent or beyond known AE window; Washout: 5 half-lives from any investigational agent; Washout: 4 weeks from cytotoxic therapy (23 days for temozolomide; 6 weeks for nitrosoureas); Washout: 6 weeks from antibody therapy (21 days for bevacizumab); Washout: 6 weeks from cellular therapy (e.g., modified T cells, NK cells, dendritic cells); Washout: 4 weeks or 5 half-lives (whichever is shorter) from other antitumor therapies; Prior radiotherapy: >= 28 days from focal RT; >= 150 days from craniospinal irradiation; Bevacizumab for RT-induced edema allowed (<= 5 doses; no washout required); Prior temozolomide during radiation at standard pediatric dosing allowed; Prior dexamethasone allowed

patient_prior_therapies: Gross total resection; Adjuvant radiation with concurrent temozolomide; Adjuvant temozolomide

exclusion_criteria: Ulcerative colitis | Crohn disease responsive to medical therapy without corticosteroid-dependence or significant toxicity | Deleterious mutation in a gene expressed in epithelial or stromal cells but not in lymphohematopoietic cells (e.g., TTC7A), or mutation expected to be more deleterious outside lymphohematopoietic cells | Active hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis | Hepatic dysfunction: ALT >5 x ULN, AST >5 x ULN, or direct bilirubin >3 x ULN | Cirrhosis with bridging fibrosis (grade F3 or greater) or sclerosing cholangitis | Severe cardiovascular disease (e.g., left ventricular ejection fraction <40% or severe diastolic dysfunction) | Severe renal dysfunction: serum creatinine >1.5 x ULN or 24-hour creatinine clearance <50 mL/min/m2 | HIV infection or chronic hepatitis B or hepatitis C infection | Past exposure to therapeutic radiation | Previous allogeneic HSCT | Active malignancy or history of malignancy within 2 years (except nonmelanoma skin cancer or carcinoma in situ) | Pregnant or lactating | Severe concurrent uncontrolled disease increasing risk from study participation
prior_therapies: Failure or significant toxicity after at least two biologic or small-molecule therapies with different mechanisms (e.g., TNF inhibitors, anti-IL12/23 antibodies, JAK inhibitors, anti-integrin); Corticosteroid dependence despite prior biologic/small-molecule therapies

question_text: 55 year old male with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, now progressing after second line therapy. Initially diagnosed with MIBC 3 years ago. He received neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin x 4 cycles and then cystectomy with pCR. 6 months later he presented with new bone metastases. Biopsy confirmed metastatic urothelial cancer. He was started on EV+pembrolizumab and after 6 cycles, scans showed worsening osseous mets and now new liver lesions. He has a hx of T2DM, COPD, and CKD with eGFR 35. What are trial options?
trial_title: A Phase II Study of Consolidative Local Therapy in Patients With Locally Advanced or Oligo-metastatic Urothelial Carcinoma (la/mUC) Following Treatment Response to Systemic Therapy With or Without Metastasis-directed Radiotherapy
inclusion_criteria: Age >= 18 years | ECOG performance status 0–1 | Surgical candidate for extirpative surgery of primary site with bilateral pelvic lymph node dissection and urinary diversion | If applicable, surgical candidate for resection of non-irradiated metastatic lesion(s) | Histologically confirmed urothelial carcinoma, locally advanced or oligo-metastatic (<= 5 distinct metastatic lesions) | Variant histology < 50% with urothelial carcinoma predominant | Received first-line enfortumab vedotin-based systemic therapy started >= 3 months prior to surgery and total treatment duration <= 6 months | Most recent restaging scan shows stable disease, partial response, or complete response by investigator-assessed RECIST v1.1
exclusion_criteria: Systemic anti-cancer therapy within 3 weeks prior to surgery | Radiotherapy within 2 weeks prior to surgery | Positive pregnancy test or breastfeeding | History of central nervous system or leptomeningeal metastases | Concurrent medical, surgical, or psychiatric condition that may confound study interpretation or prevent completion of study procedures | Any medical condition posing undue risk to participation per investigator judgment
prior_therapies: First-line enfortumab vedotin-based systemic therapy initiated >= 3 months before surgery; total duration <= 6 months; Metastasis-directed radiotherapy allowed
reasoning: The trial requires patients in the consolidative setting after a response to first-line enfortumab vedotin-based therapy, whereas the patient is post–second-line therapy, which does not meet the required treatment setting.
patient_inclusion_criteria: (none)
judge_comment: Wrong line/setting is a soft mismatch, not a hard exclusion. The trial requires consolidative post–first-line enfortumab vedotin response; the patient is post–second-line, which mismatches Core Anchor 2 (line/prior) and likely stage/setting, but it’s not an explicit exclusion. Other required elements (oligo-metastatic status, surgical candidacy, EV exposure) are unknown, so no hard exclusion applies. Correct grade: D.
